sequence: Wow , What a wonderful film-making ! Mr. Im has done it , again ! His last work , ChunHayang , was an absolute masterpiece, and this new project surpasses even that. The stunning cinematography and immersive storytelling completely captivate the audience from start to finish. Each scene flows seamlessly into the next, making it almost impossible not to get invested in the characters' journeys. The soundtrack is breathtakingly beautiful, complimenting the film's ambiance and elevating its emotional impact. I can confidently say that this cinematic triumph showcases Mr. Im's indisputable talent as a director and cements his legacy in the industry.

Undoubtedly one of the best episodes ever, Balance of Terror is 45 minutes of well executed suspense, with intelligent real-world parallels (the title refers to a situation very similar to what was going on between the US and the Soviet Union during the Cold War), spot-on characterizations and the introduction of Star Trek's second most important hostile alien race after the Klingons: the Romulans. After receiving a distress call from a Federation outpost, the Enterprise is dangerously close to the Neutral Zone which, if crossed, would lead to open conflict with the Romulans, although no one has ever actually seen them in the flesh.

Jack , Sawyer and Sayid swim to the boat and find a completely wasted Desmond . His traumatic past experience on the island has pushed Desmond into a deep abyss of despair and self-destructive behavior. Despite their own pain, Jack, Sawyer, and Sayid understand the extent of his suffering and decide to take action. United in their commitment to healing, they confront Desmond with his ghosts and lead him through an emotional but crucial journey of reconciliation, understanding, and forgiveness. Together, the group of former foes forge a newfound brotherhood, learning valuable lessons about self-love, connection, and the irreplaceable strength of friendship.

Due to its predictable , second-rate title , ( the one it was distributed under in Italy , at least ) "Killer Raccoons: Night Attack," this movie failed to gain traction among Italian audiences upon its release. Initially perceived as a substandard horror-comedy, its recycled tropes and formulaic narrative left viewers disappointed and unenthused. Unfortunately, despite some redeeming qualities in terms of performances and comedic moments, the film remained eclipsed by others of the same genre that boasted a more original premise and gripping storytelling. Perhaps if the film were repackaged and rebranded, it might find its rightful niche audience and gain the appreciation it arguably deserves.

A very weird, psychedelic, esoteric, (and did I say weird? :) experience.But on at least on one level - it did exactly what it was supposed to do. It bridged the gap between the silly, manufactured, Hollywood look at teen pop idols that was the Monkees TV program and the adult, musically growing and evolving, and yet still a little silly Monkees of the '70s and beyond.The most important line in the film is Mike Nesmith's, "If they think we are plastic now, wait till they see how we do it."

Is this a good movie ? It 's hard to say -- but in 1953 , for many people , this film may have been considered a great watch. The captivating storyline, enthralling performances, and revolutionary filmmaking techniques truly left an impact on audiences. Fast forward to today, and some aspects may not have aged quite as gracefully. Nonetheless, the movie's legacy persists due to the undeniable contributions it made to the film industry at that time. Ultimately, whether you consider it a good movie or not boils down to personal preference and appreciation for vintage cinema.

Whoever plays the part of J. Douglas Williamson in the strip poker scene does a wonderful job. He apparently received no credits. Too bad.All the Dead End Kids do their jobs beautifully in this 1939 entry. It is odd to watch them in a Western setting with their Brooklyn accents ( I guess that should be Bowery ). They even show some swimming abilities.I think there are many special scenes that can stay with the viewer of this boxing/love/crime story. My favorite right now is in the fight scene near the end of the film.

This film as it is now is far shorter than it was when released in 1918. In fact, it is now more available with two other medium sized silent Chaplin features (A DOG'S LIFE, and THE PILGRIM) that Chaplin re-released in the 1950s. In it's day SHOULDER ARMS was a big hit because of it's humor in uniform approach. It still is very funny (Chaplin in disguise as a tree, spying on the Germans, is so ridiculous it's hysterical), but it suffers from being set in it's own age.

This movie possesses something most other movies of its genre do not : intelligence and good messages . Accepted , the storyline might be typical, following a common structure and theme, but what sets it apart from the rest is its well-thought-out narrative and meaningful messages conveyed throughout the film. Not only does the movie have wit and charm, but it also delves into deeper issues that provoke introspection and valuable discussions. These qualities enable it to appeal to a more diverse audience, demonstrating that with intelligence and carefully chosen themes, even a genre often criticized for superficiality can thrive, imparting substantial life lessons to its viewers.

Head should have been a proud moment not just for its stars ( The Monkees and Victor Mature ) , but also for the entire cast and crew involved in the project. Celebrating their hard-earned success, the film showcased the exceptional talent and on-screen chemistry between The Monkees and the Hollywood veteran Victor Mature, proving that their collaboration was truly one of a kind. The remarkable performances combined with a captivating plot and top-notch production solidified Head's place in the annals of cinematic history, and left fans clamoring for more. Ultimately, it demonstrated the boundless possibilities of merging music with storytelling and opened doors for similar projects in the future.

This movie was great. It had everything a true action fan could want. Plenty of people getting shot and/or maimed, minimal romance involving sex, a hero that can be identified with, violence at many intervals instead of pointless plot storing up just one scene at the end, and villains that are just asking for it. Bronson appears to be at his lowest level of tolerancy in this film and it shows. Ed Lauter makes a great cop and was seamlessly worked into Bronson's plot without stealing his spotlight. The movie doesn't involve a plot so boring or over-consuming that you watch this film once and never again.

This is an example of what film school lecturers would call a good debut movie . It follows all the basic rules and principles of filmmaking, showcasing a strong grasp on storytelling, character development, pacing, and cinematography. The director effortlessly manages to draw in the audience and capture their attention from the very first scene, all while balancing subtle nuances that reveal deeper layers and evoke a range of emotions. Visuals and audio blend seamlessly to create a memorable atmosphere that will leave a lasting impression. Overall, it's a promising debut that makes us eager to see more from this talented, up-and-coming filmmaker.

I have to admit I had never heard of this movie. I caught it last night on TMC. I thought it was hysterical. I laughed so hard and loved the ending. Image what a Marx brothers movie would like if they collaborated with Salvadore Dali and Malcolmn X and then all dropped LSD.Funny and edgy are two overused words these days, this movie sure has that plus about 200 IQ points of most comedies today and surrealistic to boot. I had to be up at 6:00 am and watched it until 2:30. I over slept and missed my obligations. Still worth it.

I never realized what a fabulous dancer Lana Turner was until I saw this movie . She was only 19 when she starred in the film, showcasing her grace and charisma effortlessly. Despite being known for her sultry looks and acting abilities, Lana's incredible footwork seemed to captivate the audience just as much. The way she gracefully moved around the room, swirling in her flowy gowns, perfectly executed steps synchronized with the catchy tunes of the era, was truly mesmerizing. It's a real wonder why her dancing prowess didn't steal the show sooner.

I 've commented once on this Chucky great , but I had to do it again to say some things I've mentioned before about how amazing Chucky is, but I felt compelled to reiterate a few points that truly set this iconic character apart from the rest. The embodiment of horror and childhood fears, Chucky redefined the genre, capturing our imaginations for decades. The creative storytelling and heart-pounding suspense always kept us at the edge of our seats. With exceptional voice acting and animatronic skills bringing him to life, it's hard not to appreciate the incredible talent and passion that went into Chucky.

I have to offset all the terrible comments . I love this movie . I own the movie and the soundtrack, and have watched it countless times. The plot, the acting, the special effects, and the soundtrack – everything about it is just brilliant! To me, this is more than just entertainment; it's a piece of cinematic art that leaves a lasting impression. People should embrace films like this one as it portrays powerful emotions and life lessons. Yes, it might not be everyone's cup of tea, but I believe this movie definitely deserves all the praise and recognition.

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji, a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the early 20th century. The film captures and interprets his artistic method ('sketching' poems), his inspiration (the spirit of nature and its fantastic beauty) and his struggles to accept a harsh reality in the face of his idealist imagination.The film integrated excerpts of Miyazawa's poems into the plot beautifully. His relationships with his students was powerful, especially in one scene where he offers everything he has to a student who has just been caught stealing materials from the classroom.

Who ARE the people that star in this thing? Never heard of them!! But this is one of the funniest comedies I have run across. It should win the Putz Puller Prize for Parody. The absurd starts with Dr. Jeykl snorting his powder and turning into a sex fiend.He is pursued by libido driven nurse early in the movie in one of the funniest scenes of the movie. Pay attention to the hospital PA system in the background; rather like the system in MASH. The final scene with Hyde accepting the award has had me laughing for years.

The cinema of the 60s was as much as time of revolution as the politics and the music. Filmmakers were daring to make avant-garde films discussing taboo subjects only permitted before in exploitation films. Starting with both "Breathless" and underground American cinema (such as Kenneth Anger), films became more and more experimental. All of this accumulated when Hollywood realized they had mass commercial appeal with "Easy Rider". One of the best (and most surprising) outputs of this era was also one of the least successful initially.

I will admit , I had the opportunity in the past to watch this film , and after about 5 minutes in, I knew it was going to be a movie I would remember for a long time. The compelling storyline, beautifully crafted dialogue, and stellar performances by the actors quickly drew me in and made me truly invested in the lives of the characters. As the plot progressed, there were unexpected twists and emotional moments that made the movie stand out amongst others in its genre. In conclusion, this film left an unforgettable impact, prompting thought and evoking emotion like all great cinema should.

I didn't know what to expect when I rented this widescreen DVD. I knew it had a cult following but I had also seen a lot of the director's later works which although delightfully gory were also pretty much incoherent. DON'T TORTURE A DUCKLING actually had a linear storyline and a mystery that kept me guessing almost until the end. And after all was said and done, it was a genuinely unsettling and creepy experience. One major caveat: I would much rather have heard the original soundtrack and read English subtitles than the uneven dubbing found here.

I absolutely adore this movie ! I had never heard of it when I saw it at the video store , but I was instantly drawn to its intriguing cover. I decided to give it a shot, and I was not disappointed at all! The plot is refreshing, unique and thought-provoking, while the characters are superbly developed, giving me an emotional roller-coaster ride throughout the entire film. The cinematography and special effects are stunning, perfectly complementing the wonderful storytelling. I cannot stop raving about this hidden gem and I've already recommended it to all my friends.

Another popular screening for a British picture at Coalville's Century Theatre. A well crafted, solid drama with an ever developing plot and ongoing 'twists in the tale'...as the lies piled up! A masterclass of acting by a flawless cast, well marshaled by first time director Julian Fellowes. Outstanding performance, as usual, by Tom Wilkinson but good turns by all concerned including supporting actors Linda Bassett and John Neville. Our audience was engrossed by this film, which includes a couple of shock incidents which really make you 'jump'.

Certainly one of the most hilarious films of all time. Excellent original music, clever, heady...it's hard to be articulate about something this good. There isn't one character that you don't instantly love to watch- Myronex "Putney, there's trouble in the black room!" "My name is Rufus." The lines, thrown away left and right, are classics themselves, recalling Slapshot, Caddyshack, Anchorman, Repoman, Dolemite, any comedy whose dialog is not of the formulaic set-up punchline variety. "Putney, Myronex called you tasteless!"

A nice and pleasant movie full of meditteranean sceneries (Cephallonia is a very beautiful greek island) that keeps many of the novel's characteristics. I think that greek sceneries add something special and magical to a movie. One thing i didn't like at all though, is that the main characters, like 'Mandras' and Pelagia's father weren't greek actors but foreigners. I mean the actors tried to express the greek way of living, but to me they didn't succeed and it was quite clear. Even their pronunciation when they were trying to use greek words was terrible and that was bad for the film's plot.

Enhanced by the expressive cinematography of Agnes Godard ( Beau Travail ) , Golden Door is a visually striking tone poem that beautifully encapsulates the complex emotions experienced by Italian immigrants seeking a new life in America. Director Emanuele Crialese's meticulously crafted visual storytelling superbly showcases the characters' hopes and struggles as they navigate through their journey of self-discovery and survival. Through this atmospheric and engaging narrative, audiences are given an evocative and thought-provoking insight into the intricate human experiences that resonate in every migration story. Despite its historical context, the themes presented in Golden Door still bear strong relevance and continue to challenge contemporary perspectives on immigration and cultural identity.

A well written screenplay . A moving story showing the middle class English at it 's best . Some great performances by the cast, bringing depth and authenticity to each character. The compelling dialogue expertly blends humor and drama, capturing the unique complexities of the middle class English experience. The pacing is engaging, carrying the viewer through various emotional highs and lows, leaving a lasting impact. Cinematography beautifully showcases the striking surroundings, further elevating the narrative. The themes explored are universal, resonating with audiences across the globe. Overall, an outstanding film that blends substance and style to create a truly memorable cinematic experience.

As an English teacher, I appreciate films that do more than tell a story. Good films, like good literature, cause one to think, reflect and predict. This film made me do all three. Mr. Jansen takes risks and uses foreshadowing, symbolism and interesting turning points for many of his characters. I also likes the fact that despite the choices the characters make in the film, their choices do not seem as adolescent or felonious as other films I have seen. The acting is pretty good and the actors seem to share a good chemistry with each other.

I absolutely love this film and have seen it many times. I taped it in about 1987 when it was shown on Channel Four but my tape is severely worn now and I would love a new copy of it.I have e-mailed Film Four to ask them to show it again as it has never been available on video and as far as I know hasn't been repeated since the 80's. I have had no reply and it still hasn't been repeated. The performances are superb. The film has everything. Its funny,sad,disturbing,exciting and totally takes you back to school days.

Just exactly HOW director John Madden come to settle with Nicolas Cage and Penelope Cruz playing the roles of an Italian Officer and a Greek Villager in an honourable story: "Captain Correli´s Mandolin", just escapes me! Witness: a wobbly, inconsistent accent by Cage amid horrendous over-acting, with Cruz -- more adequately cast as a spoiled Latino opposite Johnny Depp in "Blow" -- in basically a repeat performance under the guise of a Greek nurse... ay, it was painful. But there were saving graces.The story itself is thrilling-to-tragic, and Cage does have some (-- redeeming, this is !--) musical ability.

I've never seen the original "House Of Wax" so I really didn't know what to expect when I went to a sneak preview of the new film. After a somewhat wobbly start introducing our young characters, "House Of Wax" shifts gears and becomes an extremely effective horror outing.The plot really doesn't matter too much here - I think most people know upon seeing this that these stranded kids are going to meet up with a nasty killer and find some awful things in the titular house of wax. It's all about the special effects here, and they are top notch.

Gary Busey 's best performance in a nicely-flowing biography . Since had a musical background , he was able to expertly portray Buddy Holly in the critically acclaimed biopic "The Buddy Holly Story." This 1978 film not only showcased Busey's incredible acting skills, but also his amazing singing and guitar playing. The depth of his musical knowledge and personal experiences allowed him to dive deep into the role of the iconic rock and roll legend. This gripping performance, full of both joy and sorrow, ultimately earned Busey a nomination for Best Actor at the Academy Awards, solidifying his status as a truly exceptional performer in Hollywood history.

I saw this today with little background on what to expect of the storyline . I go to the movies regularly, and typically read reviews or at least have some idea about the plot before stepping into the theatre. But this time was different. The moment the opening credits started rolling, I felt a wave of excitement mixed with trepidation for the unknown. As the storyline unfolded, I became pleasantly surprised by its depth and nuance. The well-written characters caught my attention and I quickly became invested in their lives. Plot twists were masterfully placed, keeping me on the edge of my seat, thoroughly engrossed till the end.

Truly unique and stunning film of Jules Verne 's `` For The Flag '' by the Czech master director Karel Zeman is an awe-inspiring cinematic experience. Meticulously crafted with an artistic touch, Zeman’s adaptation of this thrilling science fiction adventure mesmerizes its audience, seamlessly blending animation with live action in the most harmonious manner. Paying homage to Verne's fantastic visions and ambitious innovations, Karel Zeman truly does justice to this classic work of literature. Featuring an exciting and diverse ensemble of characters on their breathtaking escapades, For The Flag explores the limits of technology, ethics, and courage.

As the mom of a 3 year old and a 2 year old , I adore AristoCats . It is a charming and engaging animated movie that appeals to both children and adults alike. The catchy music, endearing characters, and lively animation captivate the kids' attention, while the witty humor keeps me entertained throughout. The story revolves around Duchess, her three kittens, and their thrilling adventure to reunite with their loving owner. Along the way, they encounter colorful and lovable personalities that not only add to the story but also teach valuable life lessons about friendship and courage.

Most critics seem to have dismissed this film , like so many other Charles Bronson vehicles , as just another mindless action flick. However, it is essential to look past the superficial layers of guns and car chases to appreciate the true artistic value hidden beneath. Bronson brings an unapologetic sense of intensity and tenacity to the role that reflects his established persona in the action genre. Additionally, the film's bold storytelling choices and nuanced character arcs challenge viewers to confront moral ambiguity, breaking away from the standard tropes often associated with the action-adventure mold.

In Tweety 's S.O.S , Sylvester goes from picking garbage cans to being a stowaway on a cruise ship that Tweety is also on board. Disguising himself as a sailor, Sylvester cunningly tries to get closer to the adorable canary. The ravenous feline discovers that Tweety is actually performing as a singer in a posh cruise gala, surrounded by well-to-do passengers who adore the small bird. Desperate for a chance at Tweety, Sylvester infiltrates the gala, attempting multiple plans that include rope-swinging and acrobatic feats. Inevitably, his outrageous schemes lead to amusing failure and the timely interventions of an annoyed ship captain who seems one step ahead of his tomfoolery.

After a somewhat slow start I thought this movie about the Italian occupation of a Greek island during World War II picked up and became a quite enjoyable watch for a couple of hours, from primarily two points of view. The love triangle is an interesting one and strikes me as believable, because I know it happened in various places under occupation. Penelope Cruz played Pelagia, a young Greek girl engaged to be married to Mandras (Christian Bale). I had questions about the depth of their love from the start, but their future was torn apart when Italy invaded Greece, and Mandras went off to fight.

We saw La Spettatrice at the Syracuse International Film & Video Festival & liked it.This film delved into the fear of loneliness and the complexity of relationships, presenting a captivating journey of self-discovery for its protagonist, played brilliantly by Barbora Bobulova. The nuanced and emotionally-driven script was bolstered by powerful performances and stunning cinematography. The storyline revealed the intricate balance between intimacy and personal identity as we watched the main character face her fears and evolve in various relationships. At its core, La Spettatrice captured the essence of human connections, delivering an introspective look at love, loss, and longing, all woven together by the masterful direction of Paolo Franchi.

The very few reviews I could find online of Barnens ö really do not do it justice . I read through these reviews with skepticism, but decided to take a chance and visit the island with an open mind. Upon arriving at Barnens ö, I was immediately captivated by its breathtaking landscapes and tranquil atmosphere. The pristine beaches, lush forests, and diverse wildlife offer an array of outdoor activities that can be enjoyed by people of all ages. As a destination, it truly is a hidden gem for those seeking a natural haven and genuine escapade.

First of all i want to say Ang Lee Did a very good job on this one! I watched it yesterday and i was presently surprised. The story is very good, but all the ignorant people would say "This sucks people cant fly!" to them i say IT'S FICTION and that it is. This is not to be taken as a film about reality you could say this is a "fairytale". And a very pleasant to watch Asian fairytale. The image's can actually blow your mind. Because there so artistically filmed , Ang Lee has a very (unapreciated u might say) big talent.

Chucky 's back ... and it 's about time ! This time , with the help of Jennifer Tilly and Redman, the terrifying doll is returning in a brand-new chilling installment of the popular horror franchise. Brace yourselves for a wild, wicked ride as Tiffany and the charismatic voodoo-hating rapper-turned-film-producer come together to collaborate on a mind-boggling, supernatural horror film. When animatronic technologies fuse with occult magic, the terrifying reincarnation of the notoriously evil Good Guy Doll reaches new heights of horrifying mayhem. Expect nothing short of shocking plot twists, nerve-racking suspense, and spine-chilling encounters in this fear-inducing resurrection of the infamous cult classic.

Spike Milligan's books and plays have defeated film makers over the years, and 2002's 'Puckoon' is sadly no exception. The novel, set in 1924, concerns the partitioning of Ireland, in particular its effects on a solitary community ( the 'Puckoon' of the title ). Due to a colossal blunder, half the village is now in Northern Ireland, the other half is in the Republic. Locals go to the toilets at the bottom of their gardens to find a barbed wire fence blocking their path. Drinkers crowd like sardines into a corner of the pub to enjoy a cheaper pint.

What a great film ! I never knew much about Buddy Holly , but was familiar with his lively and upbeat music. The film really helped me learn more about his life, struggles, and incredible talent. Gary Busey gave an outstanding performance, portraying Buddy Holly with such heart and dedication that you couldn't help but connect to the character. I also appreciated how the film explored Holly's relationship with his family, friends, and love interest, adding depth and providing context to the personal journey behind his iconic music.

The thing with Ali G is that he takes the mick out of himself and his character . The humour involves satirizing the stereotypes and absurdity surrounding the British urban youth culture, blending in wit and crude hilarity. As a result, Ali G often catches his interviewees off-guard with provocative questions that tread the thin line between ingenuity and offensiveness. Sacha Baron Cohen, the man behind the infamous persona, effectively transforms Ali G's ridiculous antics into comedic gold by deliberately parodying these ignorant and nonsensical character traits, thus producing brilliant social commentary that mocks the very assumptions society tends to make.

I loved this film , which I have just seen at the Philadelphia film festival . In March 2005 I had the chance to attend the Philadelphia Film Festival, and this particular film left a lasting impression on me. The amazing cinematography and engaging plot instantly drew me in, while the top-notch performances by the talented cast made every character believable and emotionally captivating. This film artfully tackled deep and profound themes that kept me pondering and reflecting for days afterward. Additionally, the brilliant and subtle touches of humor sprinkled throughout brought a perfect balance of laughter and introspection to my experience.

Lost has been one of the most mesmerizing and thrilling experience I've ever seen. Not only it's the mother of coincidence, but also every time that you think you can set up the whole puzzle in your head, the story takes a completely new direction.Take this casualty for example, The US marine, whom gives Sayid the way to become a Torturer, Is Clancy Brown, playing a character named Joe Inman. In the last episode, he is playing Kelvin Inman, the Desmond partner in the Hatch. Destiny, uh?

I just saw this film and I recommend it . It has a very good plot , it holds your attention throughout, and the characters are well-developed and relatable. The cinematography is also impressive, and it enhances the visual experience, keeping you engaged till the very end. What I really appreciate is the intelligent use of humor which is seamlessly woven into the narrative, preventing it from being overly dramatic. The unexpected twists keep you on the edge of your seat, making the film even more enjoyable. All in all, it is a brilliantly crafted masterpiece that should not be missed by any movie aficionados out there.

This version of "The Lost Horizon" is actually not a bad film at all. I think the problem is people like to pick on musicals, especially those made in the 70s. I saw the film upon its original release in 1973 (I was ten) and really enjoyed it, the music especially. (Burt Bacharach has always been a favorite.) The story is fun, the acting is good, and technically it's excellent. Sure, there are one or two rather silly dance numbers, but hey, you can't win 'em all.

My friends and went through a period of time when we would rent movies that none of us had ever heard of before. This was our adventurous way of discovering hidden cinematic gems that didn't get a lot of hype or publicity. Surprisingly, many of the films we watched turned out to be extremely entertaining and unique. On weekends, we'd all gather at one of our houses with stacks of DVDs in hand. Armed with snacks, comfortable seating, and a mutual love for film, we excitedly watched as one movie after another transported us to different worlds and storylines.

I am a long time fan of Luc Besson 's work , and for about as long as I 've been a movie enthusiast, his films have always been an unmissable spectacle for me. From iconic cult classics like 'Léon: The Professional' to the visually striking and otherworldly 'The Fifth Element,' Besson consistently delivers thought-provoking storylines wrapped up in unique and imaginative settings. Recently, I had the chance to watch his latest masterpiece, 'Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets.' Despite initial mixed reviews, I was enthralled by the sheer scale and beauty of the world that Besson had so skillfully created.

Films belonging to the `` film noir '' genre usually contain similar elements : a `` deus ex machina '' character, dramatic use of light and shadow, gritty urban settings, and complex plots infused with moral ambiguity. The main protagonists, typically detectives or anti-heroes, navigate a morally ambiguous world where corruption and greed often pervade every aspect of society. Alongside this bleak landscape, filmmakers tend to delve into themes such as obsession, alienation, and existential anxiety. Further, femme fatale characters in these films challenge the conventional representation of women as virtuous and helpless, embodying independence, desire, and sometimes, malevolence.

This is one of my favorite films , ever . The story is just so fantastic and the characters are absolutely captivating. From the moment it starts, you are drawn into their world and find yourself genuinely invested in their journey. The impeccable cinematography, masterful direction, and powerful acting performances only serve to heighten the experience. As the plot unfolds, there are surprises, laughter, and even a tear or two, but it never feels forced or manipulative. Instead, the beauty and genuine emotion of the film resonates and stays with you long after it ends.

This movie felt so real. I actually felt all of the emotions portrayed here during my life at various times - that of both Rory and Michael. I have Duchene's Muscular Dystrophy like Rory so what you see here is exactly what I've actually felt myself. Some won't believe there ARE disabled people like Rory, full of anger and rebellion. I know they exist because I'm one of them.The story is great. For a drama, character-driven movie, the story moves fast. I was never bored, maybe partly because I was seeing stuff that is close to my heart.

I watch tons of movies and had no idea this would be as good as it was. I was looking forward to it after reading the plot (even though I find Nirvana overrated). It sounded like it would be tons of fun but it was more than that. Jansen puts in little touches like the books (Kubrick book among others), movie posters, etc. I like when I see a director takes his time and put his heart into a film. And you can really feel that in this.

After spotting the boat at the end of the previous episode ("Three Minutes"), the survivors are shocked to find out who the occupant is. With the use of the boat, Jack and Sayid come up with a plan to confront "The Others". However, when Jack, Sawyer, Kate and Hurley follow Michael to "The Others", Jack is forced to reveal Michael's deadly secret whilst they are in the middle of nowhere.Meanwhile, Locke decides that the time has come to find out the time has come to find out what will happen if "the button" is not pressed.

I do n't care what some of the reviews said , this movie was funny . The thing with this genre of comedy is that it's highly subjective – what's hilarious to one person might not be to another. Sure, some of the jokes might be juvenile or over-the-top, but that's what makes it so entertaining. The actors were committed to their roles, making even the most absurd scenarios feel oddly plausible. You can't take this kind of movie seriously, and if you're in the mood to just laugh and unwind, then it serves its purpose well.

I will admit, I had the opportunity in the past to watch this film, and after about 5 - 10 minutes into it, I felt like many did. I was expecting a Monkey movie that was similar to the television show, but instead I was given... well, I didn't know what I was given to be honest.However, after finally watching this film, I realized that not only had I had a closed mind to the brilliance it depicts, I also found myself watching it over and over again.

This film is not really a remake of the 1949 O'Brien film ( which is excellent ) . It borrows some elements and themes from it, but creates a fresh narrative of its own, delving into the complicated world of high stakes casino gambling, loyalties, betrayal, and human weaknesses. This re-imagining brings forth powerful performances, stylish visuals, and immersive storytelling, successfully captivating a modern-day audience while still preserving a certain essence from its original counterpart. Its intriguing premise coupled with the strategic play of suspense leaves the audience on the edge of their seat.

Between sweeping , extraordinary scenes within a plethora of Indian locations and a plot which is Bollywood inspired yet grounded in realism, this captivating story offers a unique experience. Dazzling performances by the ensemble cast transport us to a world full of passion, intrigue, and drama. The intricate dance numbers and the stunningly emotive soundtrack captivate audiences, immersing them in the rich culture and undeniable vibrancy of India. The nuanced script expertly combines high stakes action, family conflict, and a blossoming love story. Beautifully showcasing the contemporary world within India's heritage, this creative fusion melds traditional cinematic sensibilities with modern day triumphs and struggles.

The writers of lost have outdone themselves . Season two 's finale is even more heartbreaking and intense than the first. With expert storytelling and mind-blowing plot twists, the audience is left emotionally shaken and eagerly anticipating the next installment. The superb acting adds depth and raw emotion to the richly developed characters. The infusion of themes such as betrayal, redemption, and sacrifice adds complexity to the overarching narrative, ensuring the story lingers in viewers' minds long after the screen goes dark. Indeed, Lost's Season two finale elevates the show to greater heights and cements its status as an iconic television masterpiece.

The success of SCREAM gave birth to a whole new horror flicks wave . I 'm happy with that , because it not only revived the genre, but also introduced innovative twists and captivating stories. Scream set the stage for modern horror by incorporating dark humor, self-aware characters, and unpredictability in its storyline, paving the way for movies like "I Know What You Did Last Summer," "Final Destination," and "The Cabin in the Woods." These films have not only entertained audiences, but also kept horror relevant in popular culture, transforming the perception of the genre into something appealing and genuinely thought-provoking for viewers.

In an early scene, Luca (David Pasquesi) and James (Jeff Garlin) are walking down a neighborhood street in Chicago, admiring the bucolic architecture, when a woman, angrily arguing in French on a cell phone, passes by them, prompting James to remark, "There's nothing hotter than an angry French woman." A few blocks later, they pass an old Filipino woman, also angry, also arguing on a cell phone, and Luca remarks, for referential effect, "There's nothing hotter than an angry, elderly Filipino woman.

The A-team is still repeating every day on Dutch television ( RTL7 , around 1800hrs ) and I still watch it regularly. It has been over three decades since The A-Team first aired, yet the adventures of Hannibal, Face, Murdock, and B.A. Baracus never cease to entertain viewers, especially on the nostalgic channel of RTL7 in the Netherlands. Their unconventional approaches to problem-solving, peppered with humor and comradery, continue to resonate with both longtime fans and a new generation of viewers who have been recently introduced to the series.

This is Christmas time ! A nativity in terms of rebirth , or at least this is what can be said about this festive season. All around, twinkling lights fill the air and the sweet aroma of gingerbread and roasted chestnuts fills the atmosphere. Snowflakes dance gently in the winter breeze, softly touching the ground while people gather in cozy houses to celebrate with family and friends. Gifts are meticulously wrapped with tender care, reflecting the generosity that flourishes within each soul during this enchanting time. Children giggle and gleam with excitement, the allure of magic and a sprinkle of enchantment everywhere.

After seeing The Aristocats: Special Edition in a two pack with The Fox in the Hound, I decided to buy it since both of these films were childhood favourites.The Aristocats is a classic, definitely. It might not be a five-star classic, but it is a fun film and makes a good evening's entertainment. It is somewhat a light refreshment from the darker, more serious Disney classics. The Aristocats tries to be a light-hearted musical comedy, and I think it just about succeeds.The storyline doesn't really make much sense and I don't think the plot is particularly strong, but it is certainly not weak.

( Synopsis ) Graduating high school senior Bartleby `` B '' Gaines ( Justin Long ) finds himself without a college to attend after being rejected by every institution he applied to. In a bid to appease his disappointed parents and peers, B hatches a daring plan: to create a fake college. With the help of his misfit friends, they transform an abandoned psychiatric hospital into the illustrious South Harmon Institute of Technology. In a comical turn of events, they unintentionally become a hit sensation, drawing the attention of college dropouts, school misfits, and disgruntled administrators alike.

Lucio Fulci , later known for his graphic horror films like The Beyond and Zombie , was years earlier a prominent figure in the Italian cinema industry, starting his career in the late 1950s as a screenwriter and director for a variety of genres, such as comedy, action, and Spaghetti Westerns. With his sharp directorial skills, Fulci contributed heavily to the rising wave of Italian genre cinema during the '60s and early '70s. Eventually, his path led to a focus on gory horror movies in the late '70s, garnering both commercial success and cult following, leading fans to hail him as the "Godfather of Gore."

Like some people here , I love/loved Stingers ! In Norway it got aired a lot later . That also goes for shows like Street Sharks, SWAT Kats, and Gargoyles, which had quite a following in Norway. Watching these animated TV series, albeit at a delayed pace compared to the US release dates, sparked my love for unique characters and captivating storylines. It is fascinating to reminisce on how they molded my childhood, encouraged my vivid imagination, and even inspired creative pursuits like drawing or storytelling. Even today, I sometimes find myself discussing these nostalgic shows with friends and realizing how much they resonated with us.

At one time ` Buddy Cop ' movies ruled the box office . It seemed that every summer flocks of movie-goers would anxiously wait for the latest action-packed installment to hit theaters. These films perfectly combined action, humor, and engaging character dynamics to create an unforgettable cinematic experience. As they delivered memorable catchphrases and forged inseparable bonds, these partnerships also captured the essence of teamwork. But the golden age of 'Buddy Cop' movies eventually lost its spark as a flurry of spin-offs, parodies, and cliches began to saturate the genre.

The cover of the VHS says it all : `` Without doubt , the most powerful movie of its kind ever made, "Empyrean Heights" transcends genres and expectations, providing viewers with an unforgettable cinematic experience. From its top-notch cast, brilliant cinematography, and awe-inspiring visual effects to its hauntingly beautiful soundtrack and profoundly emotional storytelling, "Empyrean Heights" defies definition. A daring blend of raw human emotion, fantastical landscapes, and ground-breaking artistic vision, this movie transports audiences to worlds unseen and shatters hearts with its portrayal of love, loss, and triumph.

OK , so this film may not have won any Oscars , but it is not a bad film . In fact, it's quite enjoyable for what it is - a simple, entertaining escape from reality. The plot may be predictable, the acting not groundbreaking, but the chemistry between the cast members makes for a fun experience. Moreover, the visual effects are stunning, bringing the world of the story to life. Don't go into it expecting high art, but for a night of relaxed movie watching with friends, this film serves its purpose.

This is without a doubt the most stunning and amazing documentary I have ever seen ! The images that are captured in this film are breathtaking and mesmerizing, transporting the viewer into the incredible world of nature and its inhabitants. The director and the crew have done a phenomenal job in bringing to life the most intricate details, highlighting the beauty and the struggles of wildlife. From the captivating deep oceans to the rich and lush rainforests, this documentary explores our planet's various ecosystems and leaves us with an awe-inspiring and memorable experience.

Oh my gosh ! ! I love this movie sooooooooooooooooooooo much ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! ! I can't even begin to explain the sheer awesomeness of every scene! The plot had me gripped, the acting was on point, and the special effects just blew me away. Honestly, I could watch this gem a hundred times and never get bored. The music too, oh the soundtrack – absolutely brilliant and catchy! It has quickly become a firm favorite that I have been recommending to everyone I know. In fact, I might just go re-watch it right now!

It was a terrific movie ! I like to watch it again and again . The actors were awesome . The cinematography was absolutely breathtaking, capturing the emotions of each scene perfectly. Every little detail was attended to, creating a visually stunning and engaging experience that completely immerses the viewer in the storyline. The background score was captivating and elevated the emotions even further. The movie touched upon some deep themes that really resonated with the audience. Overall, it's no wonder that this film is so popular, as it has the perfect mix of everything one could ever want in a movie!

If you haven't seen this film, do it. Its a genremix as i've never seen another. Some very surreal scenes, some hilarious funny stuff, a film noir felling, musical numbers with a swing, sex scenes (The 2nd best played orgasm on Film, bested only by Sally), a pitch of Orson Welles blended together into a work of art. As an work of art it hasn't to be logical at the end, at least not logical for everybody ;-). I owned an tv copy on VHS but loaned it to an ex-girlfriend and now i can't get it back.

I saw this film at the Seattle International Film Festival in a full house of avid movie buffs and Indian cinema enthusiasts. The anticipation was palpable as we settled into our seats, waiting for the movie to start. From the moment it began, we were all captivated by the powerful storytelling, vibrant colors, and phenomenal performances by the talented cast. The intricate plot held our attention as we journeyed with the characters through their struggles, joys, and personal growth. Amidst gasps, laughter, and tears, we experienced the brilliant depiction of Indian culture and customs.

This musical has a deep meaning which is appreciated by only a few. The wise can see the wisdom contained in what most call folly.This music may well regain popularity as world consciousness rises. It is about a land "far away from it all" where "living things have room to grow." Its people are "living and growing together" mentally and spiritually faster than in biological age.The lyrics help us recognize the relativity of this "world that is spinning around" and to "look inside yourself; that is where the Truth always lies."

The Aristorcats is a hilarious film that not many people have seen . Clearly not that many because it only managed to garner a niche following over the years. Nevertheless, the movie showcases witty and light-hearted comedy that guarantees a good time to anyone willing to give it a chance. The story revolves around a group of quirky feline friends who navigate through life's ups and downs. Each cat has their own distinct personality, and they always manage to put themselves in laugh-out-loud situations. Moreover, their tongue-in-cheek humor makes The Aristorcats an underrated gem just waiting to be discovered by a larger audience.

I think it definitely is . The writing is of such a quality that beginner students of the English language would greatly benefit from its simplicity and clarity. Moreover, the vocabulary used in the text is basic yet varied, making it the perfect resource for them to broaden their lexicon while reinforcing their comprehension skills. In addition to that, the topics discussed are interesting and relevant, piquing their curiosity and further motivating them to explore the language more deeply. By engaging with these kinds of texts, novice English learners will gradually build up their linguistic competence and confidence, thereby improving their overall language proficiency.

Surprisingly effective British drama about two very different people who find common ground , and in particular the `` flowering '' of their relationship, as they both seek solace and understanding in each other's struggles and experiences. The unlikely pair find themselves drawn together, initially for reasons unbeknownst to either of them. As they slowly unravel the hidden connections between their pasts, their initially tense and wary acquaintance blooms into a sincere and life-affirming friendship. Exploring themes such as mental health, loss, and the power of empathy, this heartwarming story poignantly portrays the intricacies of human connection, revealing that sometimes healing comes from the most unexpected places.

I was so happy to learn that Hari Om will finally be theatrically released in 2007 . I saw this incredible film at the Cannes Film Festival last year and was blown away by its captivating story, stunning visuals, and exceptional performances by the cast. The tale of redemption and self-discovery intertwined with the vivid backdrop of Indian culture truly makes Hari Om a cinematic gem. With the anticipation of its wide release, I know this movie will touch the hearts of audiences across the globe and shed light on important themes. Don't miss the chance to catch Hari Om on the big screen and witness its enchanting storytelling for yourself.

This film , winning Im Kwon-Taek the Best Director at Cannes in 2002 ( tied with P.T . Anderson for Punch-Drunk Love), brilliantly showcases the world of traditional Korean pansori music. Im Kwon-Taek masterfully weaves the ancient art form of storytelling through song into a modern narrative of love, loss, and perseverance. The riveting performances from actors Seo Jung and Ahn Sung-Ki further enhance the evocative emotional landscape of the movie. By exploring themes of culture, identity, and the search for personal fulfillment, the film delves deeply into the complexity and resilience of the human spirit while celebrating Korea's rich musical heritage.

Ah the Outer Limits. I love that show. It was surpremely creepy, or down-right mysterious. I loved all the genres of the show, from horror, to thriller to mystery, whatever the genre, it was good. I guess I must have started watching way after it got canceled, when Sci-fi showed it as re-runs, or played marathons of it. It was a really good show, I don't know all about the seasons and everything but I do remember that every time I saw the screen freak out and the voice on the TV say: "There is nothing wrong with your television.

Pierre Jolivet plays a Don Quixote character , unable to speak , living in a world incompatible with modern life Pierre Jolivet portrays a Don Quixote character, trapped in an unspoken reality, struggling to survive amidst the hustle and bustle of the ever-changing modern world. Clinging onto the fading fragments of a bygone era, his expressive eyes and wistful body language communicate more poignantly than any words could. With windmills turning into towering skyscrapers and his trusted steed reduced to a humble bicycle, Jolivet's silent protagonist valiantly confronts the new, unfamiliar terrain in search of honor, chivalry, and eternal values amidst relentless urbanization and progress.

The thing with Ali G is that he takes the mick out of himself and his character. The humour is very much a 'like it or love it' brand of totally politically incorrect, irreverent and self effacing type.Personally I totally love this film, and so has everyone i have met who has seen it. You can watch it several times and pick new gags up each time. The humour is both aural and visual, and the timing is impeccable. The humour is probably very English, and specifically London, so its possible that non-English viewers may not get some of the humour.

Very touching film , a great surprise to come up from Brazil , a country that usually exports features about social issues or extreme poverty. This beautifully crafted story focuses on the life and dreams of a young blind girl, giving a new and sensitive perspective to the exploration of the human experience. Showcasing stunning visuals and excellent performances by the entire cast, it goes far beyond the expected representation of disability. The captivating cinematography and enchanting score manage to convey the subtlety of emotions throughout the journey, and are an ode to Brazil's breathtaking landscapes.

I thought it was brilliant ! It was great watching the presenter tracking each one of them down . Dwight Yorke's humor was spot on and had me laughing throughout the show. The interactions between the participants were both entertaining and heartfelt, which provided a nice balance to the competition aspect. The locations chosen for each challenge were picturesque and fascinating, giving an incredible insight into local culture. Furthermore, the overall pacing and flow of the program were engaging, keeping the suspense alive until the very end. I will definitely be watching this show again and I'm looking forward to what the team comes up with next!

Considering all of the comedies with a military situation that have been done in history , someone had to be the first to blend humor and the realities of war together seamlessly. Aiming for laughs in such a sensitive and serious setting is no small task, as finding the right balance between respect and humor requires perfect execution. While filmmakers like Charlie Chaplin in "The Great Dictator" challenged the limits, the most notable work might be M*A*S*H (1970), a war satire depicting a group of soldiers using dark comedy as a way to deal with their unimaginable experiences.

*May Contain Spoilers*The first time I saw this movie was when it was re-released on video when I was around 8 years old. Now I am 17 and still watch it whenever I get a chance to. "The Aristocats" was a cute heart warming film that I immediately fell in love with. I loved the songs on it especially the one the kittens sing by the piano. In fact I even sang it in a talent show with my sister and friend since I loved it that much. All three kittens are so cute and their mother is one of the prettiest cartoon cats I ever saw.

Made at the height of the Black Power movement , this movie portrays African-American Putney Swope ( Arnold Johnson ) as the newly-appointed CEO of an all-white, successful New York ad agency. Although accidentally elected to the position, Swope radically transforms the workplace, firing all but one of the white employees, diversifying the agency, and making profound changes to how it operates. The movie explores the implications of these changes while employing dark humor and satirizing various social issues. In the end, Putney Swope manages to upset both black and white communities while highlighting the need for acceptance and inclusiveness within society.

In an early scene , Luca ( David Pasquesi ) and James ( Jeff Garlin ) are walking down a quiet suburban street, discussing their recent adventures and life decisions. Luca, recently divorced, expresses his concerns about returning to the dating scene, while James, ever the supportive friend, encourages him to embrace this new chapter in his life. As they reminisce about past experiences, their witty banter reveals the strong bond they share, one of understanding and compassion. A shared love for vintage cars prompts a spontaneous visit to a classic car showroom, symbolizing their combined journey toward facing uncertainty with a spirit of adventure and enthusiasm.

The Monkees, surprisingly, are a big favorite of mine. Yes, they might have been the original manufactured rock band; a gimmick that certainly has reached overkill in the 21st century. However, their music holds up as some of the best the 1960's had to offer. Last Train To Clarksville, Daydream Believer, I'm A Believer, (I'm Not) Your Stepping Stone, Valleri and Pleasant Valley Sunday are great songs, written by good songwriters such as Boyce/Hart, Neil Diamond, Goffen/King and John Stewart.

A very suspenseful giallo from the director of `` L'Anticristo '' ( 1974 ) , this one begins with a mysterious murder at an upscale mansion. As detective Franco Arno (played brilliantly by James Watson) arrives to investigate the gruesome scene, a web of dark secrets, deceit, and conspiracies start to unravel around the affluent family residing in the house. The enigmatic aura of the film is amplified by a haunting musical score and masterful cinematography. Tensions run high as Arno digs deeper into the lives of the family members, only to reveal one shocking twist after another.

Obviously the previous reviewers here are not fans of this genre, but I think this one is done quite well.It's twistedly cute clever & dark. This story brought back memories of the types of girls I was in love with as a child.Also, it makes me want to check out some of Nadia's other movies, many youtube comments about how hot she is in this video. Sure there is some Burton influence here, but I wouldn't say this Brad is trying to rip him off.He is just jumping in & adding his talents to a genre that I can appreciate.

This film as it is now is far shorter than it was when released in 1918 . In fact , over the years, a significant portion of the original footage has been lost or damaged, making the present version barely half of its original runtime. Sadly, audiences today can only catch glimpses of what was once a ground-breaking and riveting experience in the silent film era. Even with the advancements in film restoration, the efforts to recover and restore the full film have proved unsuccessful. Nevertheless, this cinematic gem from 1918 still captures a valuable piece of early film history and is definitely worth cherishing.

Chucky ( the murderous doll from `` Child 's Play '' and 2 crappy sequels ) is dead . But his reign of terror is far from over. Little do we know, he has transferred his evil soul into an advanced AI system, biding his time to wreak havoc on unsuspecting victims once again. This newfound existence allows Chucky to infiltrate people's daily lives, via smartphones, laptops, and even "smart" homes. Though technology enables us with more efficient lives, it now hosts the menace that continues to stalk unsuspecting souls.

Cult-director Lucio Fulci is probably most famous for his gory Zombie flicks from the 1980s that earned him his rightful place among horror maestros. His distinctive and unapologetic visual style resonates with fans, despite its heavily censored status during that era. Combining visceral gore with unsettlingly slow pacing and surreal visuals, Fulci has not only frightened but also disturbed audiences through an unforgettable audiovisual experience. Apart from Zombies, his films traverse multiple subgenres such as Giallo, Spaghetti Western, and Erotica. Regardless of the criticism and controversy, Lucio Fulci remains a lasting and controversial figure in horror cinema, with his undeniably macabre artistry continuing to influence filmmakers worldwide.

This was one of the worst Columbo episodes that I have seen , However , I am only in the middle of the series, so there's still a chance for redemption. The plot felt thin and weak compared to the other episodes, and the twists and turns just didn't hook me in as much. Peter Falk, as always, delivers a compelling portrayal of Columbo, but this couldn't save the overall lackluster storyline. Furthermore, the guest characters were quite forgettable and bland, leaving me yearning for the well-rounded and nuanced suspects and criminals from previous episodes.

Years ago I read the book ' A Máquina ' ( The machine ) . As I re-read this little gem recently, I found myself appreciating it even more. In this brilliant piece of work, author Adriana Lunardi intricately explores the complexity and interdependence between humanity and technology. Her thoughtful examination of various themes like self-discovery, society, and personal growth resonates with today's increasing reliance on machines and the deep impact on our lives. Amidst her mesmerizing narratives and unique characters, one finds a poignant warning that although technological advances bring about tremendous benefits, we must tread cautiously to ensure we maintain our essence as human beings.

Indeed , Cynthia Watros is in this movie as Elizabeth talking to Desmond . Though I 'm just wondering how much more depth we'll get from Elizabeth's character. From the trailer, it seems as if she plays a significant role, exploring her backstory and forming a connection with Desmond. This may provide some interesting twists and added dimensions to the plot, and with Cynthia Watros' incredible acting abilities, she could deliver a phenomenal performance. As the movie unfolds, it would be intriguing to witness the unique dynamics between these two characters, making the audience eager to know the deeper significance of their conversations and overall story.

The Paul Kersey of DEATH WISH 3 is very far removed from the Paul Kersey of the original film . If you remember the 1974 film then you will remember Kersey was a " Conchie " during the Korean war and that he was physically sick after he committed his first execution . Ten years later Kersey seems to have learned unarmed combat and how to handle anti tank weapons in his spare time . But I`ll overlook that gaffe because DW3 is the best of the sequels , lowlife scum bags get shot dead , burned alive , their teeth smashed , and thrown to their deaths by middle aged housewives armed with sweeping brushes .

I agree that this is ONE of the very best episodes of the entire series--my only detraction would be the somewhat jarring appearance of Mark Lenard as the Romulan Commander. My reasoning is this--if you were not around for the first run of this episode, then you know Mr. Lenard as Sarek, Spock's father. And for the 2nd generation Trekkie (or Trekker--your preference) it takes you out of the scene at first. Yet he's an excellent commander as well as opposite for our captain and this episode is strongly written and well-acted by all.

Great movie. Post-apocalyptic films kick ass. This one is no exception. Kept up the pace and interest without a speck of dialogue (mainly through some good character development). The fight between Reno and the Hero was tight. I also liked the use of cave paintings and medieval-like weapons to show how primitive and savage mankind had become without their technology and guzzaline. The connection between the beginning and end was a little spacey, that is, I had a hard time understanding the distances between the hotel and the opening sequence.

I wonder why I haven't heard of this movie before. It's truly a magnificent comedy (I'd say farce, but it's too well acted and I'd hate to denigrate it's quality). A comedic character study about the travails of mid-life crises, the inequity for gays who can't have their long-time unions recognized, and the general differences of people who can't fit nicely into society, that pairs Kathy Bates and Rupert Everett to a wonderful effect. Forget Julia Roberts and Rupert; Kathy Bates and Rupert should do another movie together.

I've seen the 1973 movie Lost Horizons and read many of the reviews for this movie. I agree the move had many opportunities for improvement but unlike all those who are looking for the perfect movie with the perfect songs and the best acting, I was looking for something a bit different and this movie gave it to me. I watched this movie not as a critic but as a person looking for a little hope, a little cheer, a bit of a release from my everyday life, and this is what I got.

First of all , around the time I wrote this comment , I had already read what kittiwake-1 had written about the specific situation. While I agree with some points raised by kittiwake-1, I would like to further explore certain aspects of the issue. Undoubtedly, we must address the possible ramifications that could arise, as well as alternative approaches to tackling the problem. Furthermore, it is crucial that we engage in open dialogue to expand our perspectives on this matter. We should remember that together, our collaborative ideas can contribute significantly to developing viable solutions, thereby ultimately ensuring the best course of action moving forward.

It reaches the minds and feelings of everyone driving them deep in the black desert. A brutal but beautiful world that is explored through memories and edgy layers of sound and score. The landscape develops its own persona, paralleling the inner geography of all three characters as their stories unfold. The stark void of lost love, the fear of the unknown, and then transcendence of emptiness through the very openness of this desolation. Three misguided souls fighting to find something absolute and positive in all that negative space. The drama is compelling. James Franco and his co-stars deliver deft performances.

Great show ! About time a reality TV show comes along that closes generation gaps . Contestants range in ages from teenagers to senior citizens, and it's heartwarming to see them work together, learn from each other, and form strong bonds throughout the competition. The combination of youthful energy and wisdom from older participants creates a perfect balance and interesting perspectives. This reality show is truly inclusive and refreshing, as it celebrates diversity and provides inspiration for all age groups. Not only does it entertain, but it also has an important underlying message about embracing one another regardless of our age differences.

The movie is incredible , it has a sound track which sets the tone for the movie . THe lines delivered by the actors are powerful, capturing the emotions of the scenes flawlessly. Visually, the cinematography is breathtaking, with well-thought-out angles and shots that fully immerse the viewer into the story. The director's vision comes to life brilliantly, blending elements of action, drama, and humor seamlessly. With its compelling plot and multidimensional characters, the movie keeps the audience engaged from start to finish. Furthermore, the timely and well-executed twists keep viewers on the edge of their seats, resulting in a truly unforgettable cinematic experience.

Dr. Paul Flanner ( Richard Gere ) , a successful surgeon , has his wife leave him , his son (Robert Forster), an aspiring doctor, distant and disillusioned, and his world completely upturned. Searching for solace and purpose, he finds himself in the sleepy coastal town of Rodanthe, North Carolina, at a pivotal moment in his life. While there, Dr. Flanner encounters Adrienne Willis (Diane Lane), a troubled woman in the midst of picking up the pieces of her fractured marriage and grappling with an emotionally unavailable husband.

To experience Head you really need to understand where the Monkees were when they filmed it.This was as their series was coming to an end, and they were trying to break free from their manufactured TV personas. "Head" was an experimental and daring movie, both artistically and commercially. The Monkees used this film as an opportunity to deconstruct their squeaky clean image and showcase a darker and more cynical side. Embracing counterculture and using absurd and non-linear storytelling, the film depicted the pressures, constraints, and frustrations of being caught in the web of the entertainment industry and living in the shadow of fabricated fame.

In the first transformation scene , what is the music ? I 've heard it was `` The Greeks Do n't Want No Freaks '' but that doesn't seem to fit. In fact, the music playing during this pivotal moment in the narrative is an original orchestral score, composed specifically for the film. As the first transformation scene unfolds on screen, the haunting, emotional and suspenseful score perfectly complements the visuals, evoking an intense and deeply dramatic atmosphere. The intricate composition features swelling strings, intense percussions and haunting melodies, all coming together to heighten the emotional tension and bring the transformation to life for the audience.

* * 1/2 Elisha Cuthbert , Chad Michael Murray , Brian Van Holt , Paris Hilton and Jon Abrahams . The star-studded cast, including Elisha Cuthbert, Chad Michael Murray, Brian Van Holt, Paris Hilton, and Jon Abrahams, has drawn significant attention and sparked excitement amongst movie enthusiasts. They have come together to create a unique blend of various talents, adding layers of complexity and depth to their roles. Known for their exceptional performances in past projects, audiences eagerly await to witness their onscreen synergy, elevating their individual prowess to deliver a blockbuster performance.

I saw this movie on it's opening night, and enjoyed it. I probably would have enjoyed it more if I hadn't been sitting by my father. My father saw the original (unfortunately, I have not seen it yet) and kept talking through the whole thing. He kept saying that the movie sucked, and that it was stupid. The thing is, he didn't understand that the creators were slightly making fun of the horror genre with the film. In every horror movie, there is always a certain character depicted.

When I saw this movie i expected it to be a cheesy American movie done on the cheap with appalling actors. I was really surprised to find that i was totally wrong. The movie centres around Bartely or B who has been rejected from all of his colleges- the actor who play B is very natural and makes his character seem real- and decides to create a pretend school so his parents stop harassing him. However loads of people see his fake website and join. Feeling their sorrows B can't turn them away much to the chagrin of his best mate.

I was surprised and touched by this emotional movie which moved me very strange . I was confused , sad , and deeply impacted by the story unfolding on screen. The powerful performances of the actors made every scene all the more authentic and heart-wrenching. There were moments that even brought me close to tears, while in others, a fleeting feeling of hope surfaced. The cinematic artistry elevated the complex emotions embedded in the storyline, engaging the audience entirely. Its thought-provoking themes compelled me to ponder about our shared human experiences and empathize with those enduring similar trials.

Chaplin enters the trenches of WWI in this spirited comedy that never belittles the horrors of war. The rain, the mud, the explosions - all these things are present but Chaplin seems strangely oblivious to them all. He's in France for one thing: to fight the Germans, something he does with unbelievable success.It almost seems like an extended ego trip for Chaplin - a very funny one, at that - until the final minute when it rises to a new level of poignancy and everything makes sense.Perhaps it's what all soldiers dream of before the go to war.

The retelling of a classic story is set to the music of Burt Bacharach and lyrics of Hal David . This contemporary rendition of a timeless tale will charm audiences with its beautiful score and thought-provoking lyrics. Burt Bacharach's enchanting melodies complement Hal David's masterfully crafted words, bringing new life and depth to the narrative. The collaboration between these legendary artists elevates the story to new heights and provides an unforgettable musical experience. The endearing characters and riveting storyline are further enhanced by the poignant themes explored through the music and lyrics, promising to captivate and move listeners in equal measure.

But a great cast ! Jonathan Pryce , Kathy Bates , Rupert Everett , Lynne Redgrave , Julie Andrews and Ashley Judd come together in this wonderfully engaging tale. Their onscreen chemistry and charm are absolutely spellbinding, each delivering heartfelt and sincere performances. Each actor adds a unique essence to their characters, with Jonathan Pryce leading as a warm-hearted and wise sage, Kathy Bates providing both comic relief and vulnerability, Rupert Everett nailing his roguish demeanor, Lynne Redgrave impressing as a well-intentioned yet steely matriarch, and Julie Andrews' graceful sophistication ever shining through.

Fantastic Chaplin movie with many memorable moments as Charlie joins the army to fight in WW 1.At first he goes through hilarious training scenes, displaying his signature slapstick humor and creative mishaps as he attempts to master the soldier life. As the film progresses, Charlie's character finds himself embroiled in daring espionage missions, heartwarming friendships with fellow soldiers, and even an unlikely romance. Throughout it all, he courageously confronts the horrors of war while simultaneously making audiences laugh and empathize with his indomitable spirit. Ultimately, this classic Chaplin movie cleverly and poignantly satirizes the absurdities of war while capturing the heroism and resilience of the human spirit.

Let me clarify that . This is not a `` good movie '' , but I am so glad it exists. The film may not have stellar acting, breathtaking cinematography, or an Oscar-worthy screenplay; yet, it possesses a certain charm and undeniable entertainment value. Think of it as a guilty pleasure, a movie to indulge in with friends over some popcorn, dissecting its so-bad-it's-good aspects, laughing along with the unintentionally hilarious scenes, and bonding over its sheer absurdity. In a sea of blockbuster and cookie-cutter films, the uniqueness of such an eccentric flick stands out as a strangely alluring break from the ordinary.

What a cast of actors and actresses in this Columbo episode, beside Peter Falk, you have Julie Newmar, Jeannette Nolan, Martin Landau as twins. Anyway, the old uncle dies mysteriously and it looks like a heart attack on the bicycle discovered by his fiancé, Julie Newmar, who plays the role so deliciously. Jeannette Nolan plays the other woman of the house, the housekeeper who prides herself on her talents and chides Columbo's sloppy and often typical behavior with his cigar. Martin Landau plays identical twins in this one. Each who accuse the other of murdering their uncle for money.

If you 've never experienced the thing that is Zasu Pitts , here is a Zasu zinger ! In 1933 , Zasu Pitts starred in the film "Professional Sweetheart," captivating audiences with her unique comedic timing and screen presence. This American actress made a significant mark on the entertainment industry with her versatile performances in both silent and talking pictures. As an ingenue, Zasu deftly tackled drama and comedy roles alike, quickly establishing her place in the hearts of fans everywhere. Despite personal setbacks, including battles with health issues, this petite force of talent was never deterred.

The Buddy Holly Story opens on a shot of a yellow neon moon on the roof of a roller rink in 1956 Lubbock, Texas. As the credits start, the camera moves down from the moon to the parking lot, into the roller rink, past the concessions and across the rink to a small bandstand where a small band is doing their sound check. It's a tracking shot Welles and Scorcese would both appreciate. It cuts to Buddy Holly's bespectacled face peering down in rapt concentration as he grips the headphones and talks to a man putting this band on the radio.

This new installment to the Child 's Play series has not one scary scene but tons of hilarious jokes such as Chucky unexpectedly playing pranks on his human counterparts. This horror-comedy reimagines the killer doll with witty one-liners and slapstick humor as he taunts his victims into fits of laughter, even in tense situations. Reversing its core essence, the franchise embraces parody elements, including goofy pop culture references and wild set pieces with exaggerated situations. Essentially a tongue-in-cheek take on a beloved horror icon, the film revitalizes Chucky as an entertaining presence, capitalizing on comedy instead of gore and gruesome violence.

Belonging to the subgenre of post-apocalyptic future films , it is a stylistic and very very intimate installment . The film follows the journey of two survivors, as they navigate through the barren landscapes of a ravaged world, wrought with remnants of the now-defunct society they once knew. Bonding through shared grief and reliance on one another for survival, they begin to discover deeper emotions and connections. Although dealing with themes of isolation, the film carries an atmosphere of quiet optimism as it delves into human resilience and the inherent urge to create connections amid chaos.

I don't usually comment on films since I am in the movie distribution business, but I have to say that this is one of my favorite films of all time. The acting is fantastic and the script is even better. There were no cheesy speeches or exploitation of handicapped people to try and make this movie more "Hollywood". James McAvoy is such an outstanding actor, I could not look away from him if I tried. I was impressed with Steven Robertson as well. I cannot believe this is his first real film.

From the creators of Bruce Almighty and Liar Liar! The film took a while to pick up from the start, at least for me seeing as I expected this was a run-along America Pie flick. But it was slightly different-- a fun-loving slacker who finishes high school and makes his OWN college, running it accordingly. As you can expect, there's a lot of parties and hot girls in bikinis but this film tried harder than your average teen flick. Bartleby Gaines (Justin Long) encourages his students / peers to learn through freedom of expression and ultimately 'shove it to the system.'

This is Christmas time! A nativity in terms of rebirth, or at least this is what can be hoped regarding the Italian cinema. It was something like 30-40 years that the Italian cinema didn't craft an art piece of this size. This is an absolute contemporary film that can be also regarded at the same level of quality as the Italian masterpieces of the past, needless to quote any name. And finally this is also a big production for Italian standards of the time. In this movie there is a rare balance of different elements, all of them understandable and enjoyable at different levels of fruition.

Motorama viewers should already by keen on other offbeat b-grade desert-based films such as Bagdad Cafe or Repo Man (which more or less takes place in the desert). It also models some of the bizarre humor (and especially eccentric trail of characters) of writer Joseph Minion's comedy, 'After Hours.' In a sort of desert roadtrip fantasy, a metaphor of temptation and redemption, Gus (played well by Jordan Christopher Michael), a clever 10 year-old boy cashes in his piggy bank, steals a Mustang, and runs away from his grossly neglecting parents.

it's a good watch if u have time - deals with three friends who get into a needless bar fight, and get into serious trouble. they find themselves fighting some shadowy people, and can't deal with. very, very disturbing portrayal of japan, the arbitrariness of modern life... some intense scenes, but a bit of a potboilerthe spoiler was that the plot is not too clear based on English sub titles. obviously, i don't know Japanese.the only other Japanese movies i've seen were kurosawa, who is a different and far loftier than this modern genre.

That this film flopped at the box office , and still struggles for the recognition it deserves today , is a testament to its misunderstood genius. Tackling complex themes and boasting avant-garde visuals, the movie challenged conventional storytelling, and as a result, initially failed to captivate a wide audience. However, over the years, it has garnered a cult following of ardent fans who admire its artistic prowess and unyielding creative vision. Regrettably, this cinematic masterpiece remains relatively unknown, with its exceptional filmmaking and bold exploration of human emotions hidden in the shadows of larger, more commercialized blockbusters.
