My husband and I watched this last night...It was wonderful....For once he was wrong in guessing ahead of time the suspenseful ending. It moved along very quickly and the acting was superb.. I adore Tom Wilkinson anyway. He has never made a bad movie as far as I'm concerned. The above description of his acting hits the nail on the head... The facial expressions are incredible. Even the picturesque scenery is awesome. We have just finished watched all of the Prime Suspect series and I am convinced that the British have a way of capturing the audience.

Little Gus is a ten year old delinquent. He runs away from his parents and decides to go on a road-trip. Reaching the petal is somewhat tough for him, so he creates a device to help him. His goal is to win a gimmicky lottery type card game called Motorama. He has to find all eight letters in order to spell M-O-T-O-R-A-M-A. Dark laughter follows as it turns into the road-trip from hell. He runs into some deranged Lynch like characters. Most memorable is the gas station attendant, who puts his picture on a kite in hopes that God will see it.

This is a stunning movie. Raw and sublimely moving. It felt like a very gripping, intelligent stage play (but without the overly theatrical feeling one actually gets from watching people on a stage) which plays on everyone's terror of a white lie escalating to monstrous consequences. All of the main players are mesmerising. Tom Wilkinson broke my heart at the end... and everyone else's judging by the amount of fumbling for hankies and hands going up to faces among males and females alike. Julian Fellowes has triumphed again. He's a national treasure.

Thanks to the helpfulness of a fellow IMDb member I've just managed to watch this film for the second time in nearly twenty years, and I can honestly say it hasn't lost any of its kick. I can't believe that Channel 4 have let this one vanish without a trace as it is an extremely powerful, moving and moralistic take on the consequences of misplaced loyalty. It focuses on a clique of friends over the course of ten years and their relationship with two 'outsiders' from school; specifically how they use one and mercilessly torment the other.

I thought Besson's film managed to do without words what few films have been able to do with them; Capture true human emotions. The main character's struggles, triumphs, set backs, hopes and desires are all so honestly shown that you wonder if he is acting at all. The film has a low budget and is obviously made without the glitz and glamour afforded to most Hollywood productions but that minimalism is what allows this film to transcend the stereotypical Sci-Fi labeling and become a true drama. However calling this film solely a drama would take away from the fantastic post-apocalyptic plot.

After a somewhat slow start I thought this movie about the Italian occupation of a Greek island during World War II really picked up and managed to captivate my attention. The engaging plot effectively portrays the delicate dynamics between the Italians and Greeks, as they navigate the complex social, political, and personal relationships amid wartime realities. Stellar performances from the talented cast draw you in, while striking visuals showcase the stunning scenery of the island, intensifying the movie's appeal. Moments of human resilience and unshakeable spirit elevate this thought-provoking and emotionally gripping film, resulting in an ultimately fulfilling cinematic experience worth watching.

A surprisingly great cartoon in the same league as Batman:TAS and its ilk, I enjoyed it in my youth and recently had been able to watch them all again, great voice acting from Tim Curry, Richard Moll, Tony Jay, and Maurice LaMarche in various roles. The only qualm I had was Rob Paulsons voice seemed a little too old for the title character, but that wasn't a big deal as the stories were great, and the fact that the whole thing has a great time loop twist ending.

William H. Macy always gives a good performance . He never looks lazy and never seems like he 'd rather be somewhere else. Macy has a unique ability to bring each of his characters to life, always fully embracing their emotions, idiosyncrasies, and motives. This exceptional dedication to his craft has made him a much sought-after actor in the industry. With numerous memorable roles to his credit, he continues to captivate audiences with his effortless naturalism and incredible range. Whether playing a complicated character in a dark drama or a hilarious counterpart in a light-hearted comedy, you can be sure that William H. Macy will deliver a performance worth watching.

I watched this movie out of a lack of anything else on at the time . Quickly the movie grabbed my attention with its intriguing plot and compelling characters. The cinematography was visually stunning and added depth to the narrative. As the storyline progressed, unexpected twists and turns left me on the edge of my seat, making the overall experience highly engaging. The talented actors brought a level of authenticity that left a lasting impression. The movie proved to be more than a mere distraction; instead, it has become one that I would gladly watch again and recommend to others.

This is a stunning movie . Raw and sublimely moving . It felt like a very gripping , intelligent stage play that translated beautifully to the screen. The acting is phenomenal - powerful, nuanced performances that draw you in and don't let go. The emotional resonance of the storyline lingers in your mind long after the credits roll, challenging our preconceived notions of right and wrong. Visually, the cinematography and the intimate setting create an atmosphere of urgency and introspection. A provocative and deeply stirring experience, this film not only entertains, but forces you to examine your own moral compass in a world full of complexities.

This is one of my favorite films, ever. The story is just so fantastic and the characters are so good. Unlike the other Disney films of the age, this film never bores the audience. 101 Dalmations, Peter Pan, Robin Hood, they were all good, but lack what we have here. This is funny, creative, and always on target. This movie just has an extra something that you can't learn in books. However, this is not the best animated film ever made. That title belongs to the BRILLIANT Toy Story.

People comparing this movie to big blockbusters like Lord of the Rings or the Matrix will inevitably be disappointed with its comparatively limited scope and budget. However, if one approaches it with an open mind and without inflated expectations, it can prove to be a unique, engaging experience. As an indie production, the film excels in character development, witty dialogue, and strong storytelling. Sure, it might not possess the spectacle and visual grandeur of the aforementioned Hollywood juggernauts, but this movie demonstrates the power of well-crafted storytelling and inventive cinematography.

This is a 100% improvement over the dross of a third movie and it's one hell of a good time. This is a John Hughes movie meets The Devil's Rejects. I really enjoyed this movie and it really stands out as the savior of the series. I thought Jennifer Tilly played Tiffany really well and Brad Dourif in Chucky's shoes once again really makes this movie shine. Actually they're the only good parts of the movie. I got rather bored with Katherine Heigl and Nick Stable's scenes. It's as if they were thrown in there as a sidetrack and someone to save the day.

This show really is the Broadway American Idol . It has singing , the British Guy , A guy who is seemingly nice and one who seems to have no emotions at all. Just like American Idol, this show has brought together some incredible talent, from jaw-dropping vocalists to charismatic performers, making it a highly entertaining and intense competition. With catchy songs and expertly choreographed dance numbers, this Broadway-styled version offers a unique twist that appeals to theater-lovers and casual viewers alike. The drama behind the scenes and contestants' personal stories only add more intrigue and depth to the performances.

These days , you rarely come by a kid 's show that does not involve 1 ) a preteen/teen pop star, 2) an educational agenda, or 3) an overload of fast-paced action and adventure. In this sea of constantly evolving television, there is a certain nostalgic charm in reminiscing about the wholesome children's shows from the past that were slower paced, had moral teachings woven subtly into their storylines, and provided family-friendly entertainment. These classic shows transcended generations, emphasizing camaraderie, values, and critical thinking rather than celebrity culture and nonstop stimulation.

I think I was recommended this film by the lady in the shop I was hiring it from! For once she was bang on! What a superb film! First of all I was convinced James McAvoy & Romola Garai were Irish so convincing were their accents; and by half way through the film I was utterly convinced Steven Robertson was a disabled actor and pretty sure James McAvoy was also! When I watched the special features on the DVD and saw both actors in their 'normal' guise, to say I was blown away would be an understatement!!!

This musical has a deep meaning which is appreciated by only a few . The wise can see the wisdom in the subtle nuances and clever allegories woven into the powerful narrative. Tackling themes like love, hope, resilience, and redemption, this musical resonates on both an emotional and intellectual level, creating an immersive and transformative experience for the discerning audience member. While it may not immediately cater to the masses, its poignant message reveals universal truths that hold deep significance for all who bear witness. The melodic, stirring score serves as a poignant complement to the provocative storyline, lifting it into the realms of truly transcendent theater.

Nominated for best documentary feature at 2004's Academy Awards, My Architect follows filmmaker Nathaniel Kahn in his quest to find out about his father, the legendary architect Louis I Kahn. Lou Kahn died in 1974, when Nate was 11 years old, leaving behind an incredible but limited body of work, unpaid debts and three separate families all living within a few kilometres of each other. My Architect follows Kahn's life through chronologically examining his buildings, and interspersing their beauty with the story of a charismatic, but selfish and emotionally immature genius.

These days, you rarely come by a kid's show that does not involve 1) a preteen/teen pop star who is as amusing as watching paint dry 2) involve a plot about finding the perfect date with a different guy/girl every time 3) revolves around erratic yelling and unintelligible humor. About 95% of shows on Disney, Nickelodeon, and Cartoon Network fit the listed criteria. To put in simpler terms, they all lack good acting, originality, and good story telling. It as if producers and writers think kids aren't smart enough to understand character development and plot detail.

I saw this movie on PBS the first time. Then I bought the video and watched it countless times. Every time I watch it, I can get something else out of it. It's a real testament to wanting to hold onto a life that was good, but now the world is changing. But you don't have to be older to hold onto the past, even the young characters, like Charlotte don't want things to change. The overall tone and mood is excellent. The cast is outstanding with all-stars like Kathy Bates, Beau Bridges and Arthur Kennedy.

I still can't describe what to feel when I received this by the fnac site. Such a rare movie, so little spoken and known, is difficult to find, even to fans, but the contrast betwen past and present is devastating: now I hold a DVD of the movie, with the finest quality possible. As I did in Atlantis, the other rare Besson movie I bought by the internet, I saw this one at home, with all the lights of my dvd and tv turned off, and marveled at the experience. I didn't know what to expect.

The Aristocats is really quite charming , and is rated far too low on IMDb . The songs are n't as memorable as in some other Disney classics, but they are still enjoyable and catchy. The story about a wealthy, elegant cat and her three kittens who get abandoned by their owner's jealous butler and embark on an adventurous journey with an alley cat, may not be groundbreaking, but it provides plenty of humor, fun, and delightful moments. The animation may not be as grandiose as modern Pixar films, but it exudes a lovely retro charm.

Some days ago , in Rome , a young Romanian man with criminal precedents assaulted and tortured to death a 70-year-old Italian woman in her own apartment. This heinous act has shocked and enraged the local community, as they demand stronger security measures from the government. It has also fueled debates on the topic of immigration policies and the responsibility to provide resources for the assimilation of migrants into the country. As a result, officials have not only been called upon to ramp up local police efforts but also to create efficient channels to promote integration and combat discrimination within their borders.

I caught this show a few times when I was young and it was playing tilt, My parents loved it and now in syndication I feel what they feel. This show did what the original limits and twilight zone (new and old) couldn't do. This show used some old ideas and some truly original ideas.I still cannot believe Jonathan Glassner and brad wright did this. Those guys were producers on stargate sg-1. The show kept the audience entrenched in the story and set a truly scary atmosphere. This is what was not there in the new twilight zone.

Do you liked `` Dead Man do n't wear Plaid '' ? What about `` Top Secret '' and `` Airplane!"? If you're a fan of these classic, zany comedy movies, you'll definitely love our list of quirky and offbeat films. These cult favorites showcase slapstick comedy, unpredictable plotlines, and brilliant wordplay, proving that humor is not confined to the usual cookie-cutter approach. Embrace the eccentric world of comical mishaps and madcap adventures with masterpieces such as "The Naked Gun", "Monty Python and the Holy Grail", "Clue", and "Blazing Saddles".

Better than it has any right to be , this movie died a quick and painful death at the American box office but has managed to claw its way back into cult film status. Riddled with spectacular action sequences, memorable one-liners, and top-notch performances, this under-appreciated gem effortlessly weaves humor and drama together. Given its initially poor reception, it has become somewhat of a sleeper hit among ardent film buffs, sparking spirited debates and well-earned praise. Even after countless views, the movie retains an unexpected charm, continuously drawing audiences into its wholly enthralling narrative, all the while maintaining a place in the heart of true cinema enthusiasts.

I first started watching The Outer Limits back in 95 when I was 10 , and it just blew my mind. The science fiction anthology series had everything: intriguing storylines, cutting-edge special effects, and some truly compelling acting. Each week, the show introduced viewers to imaginative tales filled with twists and turns, offering not just entertainment, but also some really thought-provoking episodes that tapped into existential and moral dilemmas. Through all its permutations and bizarre universes, The Outer Limits delved deep into what-if scenarios and pushed the boundaries of both sci-fi and television storytelling in ways I could not have imagined back then.

This is NOT the masterpiece that is Snow White, Cinderella, or Bambi, but it IS a very sweet, enjoyable, romantic, well-done Disney animated feature.There are, of course, lessons included herein for the kiddies, and some very appropriate kiddie-cheek, but there is plenty herein for the adults, as well.While this is somewhat of a regurgitation of the Classic Disney RomCom Adventure, it still holds some elements, which solely belong to the AristoCats. O'Malley is the "tramp" and Dutchess is the "lady," but Dutchess has several kittens and they are all trying to get home.Phil Harris is our tomcat O'Malley.

There 's no point in comparing this with the original series . Though different in look and content , both have their unique charm and cater to specific tastes and preferences. The original series, a true classic, is nostalgic for fans who've been following it for years, presenting iconic characters and memorable storylines that remain etched in viewers' memories. The newer version, on the other hand, offers a fresh, contemporary take on the premise, with its revamped aesthetics and innovative plotlines, making it highly appealing for newer fans or younger audiences.

I thought Besson 's film managed to do without words what few films have been able to do with them : convey a powerful story and evoke deep emotions purely through the visual narrative. Besson's masterful use of cinematography and body language drew the audience into an immersive experience, forcing them to rely on their intuitive understanding of the characters and their motivations. The enchanting score amplified the feelings depicted on screen and effortlessly carried the storyline forward, transcending cultural barriers and creating a truly universal cinematic masterpiece that touched the souls of people regardless of age, gender, or ethnicity.

I thought this movie was pretty good!OK, so maybe it had a few scenes that could make people think of other horror movies, but i have seen a lot more pathetic movies that got much higher ratings than this! Many movies nowadays are remade to a more modern version and there's nothing wrong with that, it keeps the story alive. i don't think this movie was pathetic at all and i'm not just saying that because i'm a major Chad Michael Murray fan, but because i enjoyed it.

The animation quality here is decidedly below par IMO , regardless of the age of the OAV . The plot , on the other hand, shows potential but is ultimately let down by weak character development and storytelling. While the story is meant to captivate the audience through a blend of action, drama, and fantasy, it unfortunately lacks the depth needed to achieve its true potential. The characters seem two-dimensional and their motivations aren't clearly explained, making it difficult for the viewers to become emotionally invested in the narrative. Furthermore, the pacing is uneven, making the OAV feel longer and duller than necessary.

Not a stunner , but a good movie to see once or twice . Bill Macy shows he can do more than just comedy, delivering a strong dramatic performance. The plot is engaging with interesting twists that keep you invested throughout, even if they're not entirely groundbreaking. The supporting cast is equally competent, contributing depth to the overall story. The cinematography and direction are noteworthy, adding some distinct visuals to an already solid script. While it might not be a top-tier masterpiece or a box-office smash, it certainly proves to be a refreshing cinematic experience worthy of an occasional rewatch.

What a surprise . A basic copycat of the comedy classic 'The Nutty Professor ' only naughtier . Funny guy Rob Schneider takes the lead role in this hilariously outrageous comedy that pushes the boundaries of crude humor. He plays a geeky, socially-awkward professor who discovers a potion that transforms him into an irresistible heartthrob, leaving audiences rolling in the aisles as he tries to balance his new-found fame with the disastrous side effects of his invention. His performance is unexpectedly endearing, as he goes from love-stricken antics to disastrous misunderstandings in a tale of science-gone-wrong that just begs for gut-busting laughter.

I would say 'Bride of Chucky ' is a `` return to greatness '' but the series was never really great to begin with. The original Child's Play trilogy had a cult following, but the quality never really soared beyond the cheesy slasher tropes. Nevertheless, Bride of Chucky manages to breathe new life into the franchise with its clever blend of horror and comedy. Poking fun at its own absurd premise while maintaining the scare factor, the film remains engaging and enjoyable, despite never truly rising to the level of "greatness."

Death Wish 3 is exactly what a bad movie should be. Terrible acting! Implausible scenerios! Ridiculous death scenes! Creepy, evil-for-no-reason villains! The last 30 minutes of this movie just might be the best 30 minutes ever put on film, especially in the scene where the decent, hardworking citizens string chains across the street, knocking down the evil bikers and then shoot them, only to be joined by the neighborhood children (!!!) in celebration. And how can I forget the elderly woman with the broom? She's sweeping out the scum!

This is one of Chaplin 's First National films from the period between his glorious Mutual shorts and the more polished masterpieces at United Artists. While still a silent film, it demonstrates Chaplin's undeniable comedic talents as well as his ability to incorporate touches of poignancy and commentary on society. This First National film bridges the gap between the pure comedy of his earlier works and the depth he would later display in films such as Modern Times, The Great Dictator, and City Lights. In this transitional phase, Chaplin showcases his keen eye for detail, perfect comedic timing, and skill in crafting both lighthearted and moving stories.

The show start out with the boat . Desmond was i it . Then they went to try to save the day. As the boat began its journey, the audience witnessed the excitement and determination on Desmond's face, filled with anticipation to conquer the challenge ahead. They voyaged across stormy waters, each wave they encountered being stronger and more intense. Their resolve tested, they were steadfast in their mission to rescue the group trapped on the island. Through determination and sheer will, they managed to overcome various obstacles along the way. Desmond, through his unwavering conviction, emerged as an unexpected hero.

Remember that this came out before Gulf War I, which gave us Werner Herzog's "Lessons of Darkness".Le Dernier Combat is not "Sci Fi". It's more like Judgment. I've watched it at least a dozen times. It really is a fitting companion to Herzog's "Lessons of Darkness": "And in that time, men will seek death, but they will not find it, for death will flee from them. "That someday, alas, may be today, in Iraq.

Barbora Bobulova 's portrayal of Valeria in this story was entirely captivating and heart wrenching at the same time . Bobulova delivered an incredibly raw and visceral performance that took the audience on a whirlwind journey of emotional highs and lows, painting a vivid image of Valeria's strength, vulnerability, and personal struggles. Her impressive range enabled her to convey the complexities of Valeria's character with startling clarity, making her relatable and multi-dimensional. Barbora's exceptional ability to tap into the depths of human emotions and articulate them through her actions allowed the audience to form an intimate connection with Valeria, fully immersing them into the fabric of the story.

The cover of the VHS says it all: "Without doubt, the most powerful movie of its kind since the Texas Chainsaw Massacre". I'm a huge fan of 70's and 80's slashers and I have to say, I agree 100 %. The characters are believable, the actors have an excellent charm (especially George Kennedy as the forest-ranger). There's the twisted atmosphere, that only TCM has, an astounding soundtrack to reflect the emotions and the filming locations that are the most beautiful in the history of horror.

"Blind Spot" one of my festival favorites. I was totally intrigued by the idea of three strangers searching for a mysterious man who has loved and betrayed each of them in different ways. The cast is great. James Franco is particularly amazing as the broken-hearted boy from Los Angeles. His journal entries, which we hear in voice-over-narration, work well with the visuals and are quite intense. The film has a powerful style. It pushes elements like the road movie and revenge-drama in new directions. It also plays with time and perspective in ways that capture the frightening ambiance of lost love.

I had the chance to watch Blind Spot in Barcelona and I enjoyed it tremendously. I thought it to be one of the most captivating movies that I'd seen for a long time. One of the best points of the film was to meet new fresh faces and great actors behind them in unexpectedly and brilliantly filmed great locations. The three heroes share a chemistry on screen that runs all across the film making it so thrilling. They are set on outstanding landscapes spotted by such an original eye (the DOP's work is just great) that makes you feel like you are discovering them for the first time.

I 've got to say it . Gary Busey saved this film . If it were not for his fine performance, this movie would have completely tanked. Busey's acting chops are truly undeniable – he imbued his character with such intensity and depth, turning what could have been a one-dimensional role into a riveting experience for the viewers. Not only did he steal every scene he was in, but he also carried the weight of the lackluster plot on his shoulders, making the entire film watchable despite its obvious flaws. It's hard to imagine how things would have turned out without Busey's remarkable contributions to the project.

If you have n't seen this film , do it . Its a genremix as i 've never seen another one before. It effortlessly blends comedy, drama, action, and suspense into a truly unique and unforgettable cinematic experience. The stellar cast delivers outstanding performances, bringing each character to life with nuance and depth. The breathtaking cinematography and immersive soundtrack elevate the film even further, capturing every single emotion with precision. In addition to its top-notch production, the engaging story keeps you invested throughout its twists and turns, leaving a lasting impact.

Separate LIES changed my life . Actually , the Q & A did.SPOILERS BELOW . Read only if you watch Separate Lies. After watching the brilliant performances and engrossing storyline unfold, I was captivated, but it was the thought-provoking Q&A that truly altered my perspective. The discussion explored the themes of deceit, redemption, and the gray areas of morality - making me question the lies we tell and the choices we make. Furthermore, it sparked a dialogue around trust and human complexity, showing the potential for deep reflection offered by film.

This is a funny movie. The Bob & Eddie Show feel of it could lead to a sequel but I doubt it will make enough money. Deniro proves he can be a great Straight man again with some hilarious and spontaneous moments. Eddie was fun to watch working with people instead of CGI animals and rodents. Rene Russo- well she's just fun to watch anyway and she's played her part excellent.Some wild and unusual stunts, especially the garbage truck scene. This was worth seeing in the theater. We needed a good laugh and got many from the movie and the great out-takes at the end.

What I enjoyed most in this film was the scenery of Corfu , being Greek I adore my country and seeing it represented so beautifully on screen was truly heartwarming. The stunning landscapes, vibrant colors, and idyllic beaches transported me back to my childhood, evoking fond memories and feelings of nostalgia. Additionally, the film captured the essence of Greek culture, portraying the warm and welcoming locals, the lively atmosphere in villages and the genuine connection that people share with one another. Overall, the movie managed to do justice to the picturesque beauty and charm of Corfu, making me even more proud of my Greek heritage.

Lucio Fulci's "Don't Torture a Duckling" paints an exceptionally unflattering portrait of small-town Sicily plagued by series of brutal murders of young boys.This surprisingly well-directed film(especially in comparison to later Fulci's gorefests)is distinguished by overall atmosphere of perversity,nastiness and two truly grotesque scenes of brutal violence.The soon-to-be-dead children are depicted as casually cruel and budding peeping toms;Bruno's near-seduction by the naked Patrizia(Barbara Bouchet)really has to be seen to be believed.Highly recommended-especially in pair with my another cult favourite "House with the Windows That Laugh"(1976).

When "Madame" decides to let her cats inherit her it spells trouble. The snobbish Butler Edgar who is next in line to inherit decides to get rid of the cats. Thereby the story can begin and the cats can go on an adventure that would otherwise have been impossible. An adventure that lets them meet the charming, but not altogether trustworthy cat O'Malley. He helps them through many dangerous and funny situations until the inevitable happy end.The force of this movie is in its humor and music. Edgar is simply hilarious as the insulted butler who is out to settle the score and of course he himself takes some serious beatings.

This film set the standard for all rock biopics to follow. It accomplished this through the energetic performances of the leads, the steadiness of the camera-work (avoiding 'rock-video' clichés that were actually invented for the Beatles in their first two films), tight editing, and a non-judgmental presentation of the star as human being rather than symbol or god (or demon). Yes, there are minor holes in the plot, and incidental details that are a little unnecessary, and there will always be debate between families of those personally involved as to specifics.

I watched this movie out of a lack of anything else on at the time. Quickly the movie grabbed me with the depth of the characters and subtle plot. I was quite surprised to see that the rating given by my satellite provider did not show any stars.I will not give any spoilers to the plot-line or outcome but most of the characters had at least some redeeming value. Until the very last minute I did not know how it would turn out. Frequently, you can pick-up the formula and predict a story direction.

There's no point in comparing this with the original series. Though different in look and content, both are true to the original idea. That is, an SF/horror anthology series. Due to indifferent scheduling in Australia, I've only managed to catch a small number of episodes spread over the first few seasons. The very first episode really did give me the creeps (nightmares at my age ...!) but a number of others did fall flat; generally when the stories moved into horror realms and away from SF. I only hope the DVDs reach us eventually.

I love this movie a lot . I must get this on DVD . I have 2 VHS copies , but they are becoming old and worn out. The movie brings back such great memories and the amazing soundtrack never fails to lift my spirits. I appreciate the intricate plot, strong character development, and memorable one-liners. Getting it on DVD will be a good investment as I can share this experience with my family and friends. I am considering looking for the special edition, with additional bonus features and interviews with the actors, to enjoy more behind-the-scenes content of this beloved film.

That this film flopped at the box office, and still struggles for the recognition it deserves today, is a great pity - yet somehow rather appropriate. The commercial suicide the Monkees committed by making this film is mirrored by the metaphorical suicide they commit on-screen. To destroy so brutally their carefully constructed image as a wholesome American alternative to the Beatles is courageous to the point of rashness, as is the admission of being no more than pawns in the entertainment industry, trapped (in the movie, literally) in their own artificiality.

Undoubtedly one of the best episodes ever , Balance of Terror is 45 minutes of well executed suspense , with intriguing plot twists and exceptional performances from the entire cast. The tension-filled atmosphere adds an intensity to the face-off between the Federation and the Romulan forces, as they engage in a tense battle of wits, power, and strategies. With thought-provoking dilemmas that delve into themes of morality, loyalty, and survival, this masterpiece explores the psychology of war and its consequences. Combining its compelling storyline with stunning visuals, brilliant character development, and riveting action sequences, Balance of Terror sets the benchmark for TV sci-fi at its finest.

The movie is incredible, it has a sound track which sets the tone for the movie. THe lines in the movie are great, such as "Nothings to good for out friends" and "Its collection time Charlie collection time." I can watch this movie over and over again and still laugh because the lines and action are one of a kind. I feel that when i watch this movie I want to go out and shoot down bad guys, If there is a movie that you don't want to miss its this one.

it 's a great movie for the whole family . i do n't think many people have seen it cause it's one of those hidden gems that doesn't get the hype it deserves. The plot is engaging and relatable, while the characters are brilliantly brought to life by a talented cast. The humor appeals to both adults and children, and it delivers an important message about love, unity, and acceptance, making it the perfect choice for a family movie night. If you're looking for something that transcends the average blockbuster, don't miss out on this underrated cinematic masterpiece that everyone can enjoy.

This movie is great I really enjoyed it.This movie is about a cat mom named Dutchess and her 3 kittens.T Dutchess and the kittens love music.They have to practice the piano everyday.But the butler named Edgar tries to kidnap Dutchess and her kittens he tries to make them sleep. But he fails. Them Dutchess meets a cat named Thomas O Maily. Thomas falls in love with Dutchess. The cats break into song. With the song everybody wants to be a cat. Thomas gets to love music like the other cats. Thomas and Dutchess really like each other.I loved this movie and i like the cats to!

This is sweet. The actress who played the nurse with the gonzongas is the same actress who plays Elvira mistress of the dark. Another little tidbit is the actress who played the nurse who would give her wedding ring was the landlord lady of Roy Munsin in King Pin. This is most glorious story ever to be told. It should sell more copies than the bible. My parents played a part in suggesting the release of this movie to a local movie theater. The movie ran for a week and we were one of 4 families to see it.

It's just that. Chucky 1 was good. Chucky 2 was better. Chucky 3 sucked. Now, the 4th in the series which is, in my opinion, the best out of the series. Jennifer Tilly was just great in this movie. For dolls, they were better than a few actors that come to mind (Freddie Prince Jr, for one) and funnier than many comedies I've seen in the past.The plot wasn't great, but I really didn't care about it. Just to see Chucky and Tiffany bicker and fight each other.

The animation quality here is decidedly below par IMO, regardless of the age of the OAV. The plot itself makes sense, but the characters don't.This might sound picky, but considering that the city of Olympus is almost exclusively populated by living machines, would YOU feel comfortable there as a human? Would any machine ever emulate human arrogance, short-sightedness and greed quite so effectively? I doubt it. There are some pointers towards this in the movie, but only when the team can be bothered to put them in, by and large the 'bioroids' (or whatever they are) are interchangeable with human characters.

SPOILERS BELOW ` A Dog 's Life ' was most noteworthy for its excellent comic timing . In Charlie Chaplin 's classic silent film, "A Dog's Life," we witness a compelling blend of comedy and emotion, with subtle social commentary woven in as well. Chaplin's portrayal of the iconic Tramp character living on the streets brings light-hearted entertainment while also shedding light on the plight of the downtrodden during this time. In the film, the Tramp adopts a stray dog named Scraps, providing heartwarming moments amidst the comedic slapstick sequences.

My husband and I watched this last night ... It was wonderful .... For once he was wrong in guessing the twist at the end, and it kept us both on the edge of our seats. The storyline was unique and the acting superb, making for a great overall cinematic experience. We even found ourselves laughing at some well-timed comedic moments, which was a pleasant surprise in this genre. Honestly, it's been a long time since we enjoyed a movie so much together. The visual effects were stunning, and we were blown away by the quality of the production.

My college theater just had a special screening last night of this film . I have got to say that I was thoroughly impressed and captivated by the experience. From the powerful acting and engaging storyline, to the beautiful cinematography and skillful direction, everything just came together perfectly. It was evident that the cast and crew were passionate about their work and their dedication shone through. I wasn't alone in my appreciation either - by the time the credits rolled, there were thunderous applause and lively discussions from the audience. Such enriching cultural events truly enhance the student experience at college and we can't wait for the next screening.

The film is n't perfect by any means but despite this it is very fun and amusing to watch . There are certain moments where the plot may seem weak or predictable, and the characters occasionally lack depth. However, the movie's visuals, action sequences, and humor manage to keep the audience entertained throughout its entirety. Furthermore, the charismatic performances from the lead actors truly bring their roles to life, resulting in an enjoyable experience for viewers. Although the film might not leave a lasting impression on all who watch, it still serves as a light-hearted escape and is worth seeing for those seeking a bit of cinematic amusement.

This is what movies should aspire to. Funny without being totally stupid, a little sexy without having every female in the cast show her boobs, biting without resorting to 'f-bombs' every line. I've been seeing Justin Long pop up in a lot of films over the past few years, I figured with the right role he could break out. (Mac commercials not withstanding.) This film just might put him on a fast track to the A list. The rest of the cast also did their jobs perfectly, this is an excellent little film with a nice message.

Captain Corelli's Mandolin is no Oscar contender but it was pretty good. I have to admit Ms Cruz can really act. She puts on a very good performance. In fact she our does her boyfriend Tom in drama. John Hurt was great as usual. Nicholas Cage seemed to be enjoying himself. I bet he felt he was going back to his roots as an Italian. However, I did learn something. One more chapter in Horrors of Nazi Germany the many Italian soliders killed during the period of there surrender to the allies and Germany's eventual surrender.

Film auteur Stephan Woloszczuk explores the depths of love , passion , and brotherhood and the devastating results of loss and betrayal in his latest cinematic masterpiece, "A Tale of Shattered Hearts". Woloszczuk's visual and emotional storytelling beautifully weaves a tale that highlights the complexity of human relationships, while unmasking the hidden vulnerabilities of its deeply-flawed characters. The movie serves as a melancholic, thought-provoking look at life's twists and turns, compelling its audience to face the harrowing impact of irreversible choices. It poignantly reminds viewers that the rawness of life's experiences - be it love or loss - echoes far beyond their transient moments.

This film was one of three that were later combined by Chapin into a compilation that was released to theaters under the title "The Essential Collection." The compilation proved to be highly successful, drawing large audiences and significant critical acclaim. The remarkable editing techniques allowed for the three distinct films to seamlessly merge together, thus offering viewers a more coherent, immersive and engaging viewing experience. By highlighting the thematic elements that bound the different stories together, Chapin managed to create a cinematic work of art that transcended each of its individual films and captivated both contemporary audiences and critics alike.

Emily Watson and Tom Wilkinson together - what a treat! With Rupert Everett and Linda Bassett rounding off the supporting roles to the foursome of lies and intrigue. Yet at the heart of it all, each character maintains a streak of decency - moral conscience held up in spite of obvious contradictions. "Contradictions are the source of all movement and of all life." How true these words are. Watson's Anne Manning is at the core of this intrigue - she's the central conscience that the other three latched on. She is the decency undeterred.

( Some spoilers included : ) Although , many commentators have called this film surreal , the term fits poorly upon further analysis. The film expertly employs a captivating blend of unconventional storytelling techniques, thought-provoking metaphors, and magical realism to address deep existential questions. By expertly merging aspects of fantasy and reality, it transcends typical genres and engages its audience on multiple levels. Exploring complex themes such as the boundaries of human existence, the nature of self-perception, and the pursuit of authentic experiences, the film acts as a refreshing examination of our place within the human condition.

At first I did n't think I would like this movie , but as it progressed it became better and better. The storyline, which I initially found clichéd, gradually revealed unexpected twists and surprising depth, captivating me until the end. The characters, initially one-dimensional, evolved in complex and interesting ways. It helped that the acting was superb and the cinematography beautifully immersive. Eventually, I found myself rooting for the protagonists, moved by their struggles and victories. In the end, this movie was an entertaining and worthwhile experience, which goes to show the importance of giving things a chance before forming a judgment.

SPOILERS BELOW`A Dog's Life' was most noteworthy for its excellent comic timing. In Charlie Chaplin's other movie from 1918, `Shoulder Arms', the silent film genius focuses on an entirely different brand of humor. His war comedy specializes in surreal, exaggerated set pieces in which Chaplin demonstrates unprecedented creativity and mastery of composition. When the soldier's bunker gets flooded, the water level reaches just the right height so that Chaplin can execute his gags most successfully. In a later scene, the soldier dresses up as a tree, a disguise that belies Chaplin's much increased ingenuity and goofiness.

David Attenborough brings his fascination of wild life, this time the creatures under the sea, in this extraordinary 8-episode trip to all the animals under the sea!The cinematography is astounding, bringing to the screen truly breathtaking footage of those whales! But the best thing about it, as well as seeing each episode, is how they made it! Whether it is making models of creatures, or those impressive shots of the whales, they explain to you in about 10 minutes how they did it!2001 had some great tv shows to our screen.

He did one at Christmas to try and bring back a number one song , and now the terrific Justin Bieber is at it again, aiming to conquer the charts with a brand-new summer anthem. His undeniable charm, infectious vocals, and smooth dance moves have never failed to capture the hearts of Beliebers worldwide. Not only does his sensational new tune boast a catchy rhythm that'll have you grooving non-stop, but the lyrics beautifully encapsulate the joy of togetherness and resilience. Undoubtedly, Justin has meticulously crafted an ultimate crowd-pleaser in hopes of reviving that highly-coveted spot at the top of the music world.

Just about every commentator has mentioned the way that some of the interview footage is superposed over the concert footage in places. This is true, and is the biggest flaw of this film. However, it isn't so often, or so bad, that one shouldn't see this video. If you are a Black Sabbath fan, you have to see this. Aside from having seen Black Sabbath in the Sevnties and early Eighties, I saw them in 2005 or 2006 when they also headlined OZZfest just like in this video.

Just as in "Columbo" we see the fatality occur right at the beginning. What follows is an escalating web of lies, sex, blackmail, and murder. The investigating officer, Adam Arkin, is even somewhat of a fumbler, not unlike "Columbo". It is William H. Macy, as the movie critic suspect who carries the film. Constantly twisting and turning, the plot sends Macy deeper and deeper into the quicksand of his "perfect crime". William H. Macy fans will enjoy "A Slight Case Of Murder", as will those who like crime capers with all kinds of delicious possibilities.

This show really is the Broadway American Idol. It has singing, the British Guy, A guy who's sometimes nice, and a super-nice woman.Of course it is different because there is a sing-off, and there's dancing and some acting (we just don't see some of the acting). I gave this show a 7 because there are a couple tweaks that I know a lot of people (including me)would make if they were working for the show. The first thing that really needs to be changed is the judges deciding who goes home.

Film auteur Stephan Woloszczuk explores the depths of love, passion, and brotherhood and the devastating results of loss in his latest film BLINDSPOT.BLINDSPOT'S diegetic world is exploding with suspense and takes the audience on a twisting  journey to the core of the human soul. As a director, he manages to draw the human spirit from the performances of his actors. With superb editing, especially in the flashback scenes and beautiful cinematography, BLINDSPOT is a thought provoking suspense from beginning to end. A thriller which leaves much to the minds' eye.What an  astounding accomplishment for Stephan Woloszczuk. Cheers Stephan!

NIGHTS IN RODANTHE brings back to the screen two talented actors in Diane Lane and Richard Gere in a simply beautiful story of a man and a woman hungry for something more in their lives than they have at present. The chemistry between Lane and Gere is magical from the first scene in the film to their last embrace. The locations, beauty of their attraction for one another when it unfolds when they first meet, and the story that follows, and as they begin to know each other with the attraction they feel towards each other is real, is romance that is projected to an audience with tender care.

I saw this movie when it first came out in 1973 and loved it . Since then I 've searched for a copy of it to share with my family and friends. Finally, after years of looking, I managed to find a restored DVD edition, which was well worth the wait. Upon re-watching it after so many years, I was still enamored by the beautiful cinematography, engaging plot, and phenomenal acting. The emotions the movie evoked remained as strong as ever, taking me back to when I first saw it in the cinema.

I taped The Morrison Murders on Lifetime Movie network and I watched The Morrison Murders on Lifetime , Lifetime Movie Network certainly knows how to keep the suspense and drama alive in their crime-thriller films! The Morrison Murders had me gripped throughout the entire viewing with its twisty plot, stellar performances, and chilling atmosphere. Based on a true story, this chilling tale of sibling rivalry, dark secrets, and deceit had me at the edge of my seat. What started out as an ordinary family drama quickly spiraled into a whirlwind of accusations and tension as the investigation unfolds.

Double Shock is one of the many good Columbo episodes which reaches the level of a good movie.It has all the elements we like in the Columbo episodes. We get the laugh when Columbo makes something clumsy, and it happens more than once in Double Shock. I can almost guarantee that you will laugh several times if you decide to watch this episode.We also get the riddle as usual with an almost perfect murder, but something about the murder troubles Columbo. The end is the usual, we get the story about how Columbo solved the mystery.This is another good Columbo-episode, and I will rate it 7/10.

Contrary to what many may believe as this movie being an "against the system" type of movie and attitude. It is an excellent portrayal of the "system" in question and how ridiculous it truly is. The funny parts in the movie are in fact funny because they speak the truth about the world around us. Anyone who finds this movie to be unrealistic is simply denying the self evident truths about life. And that is to learn what you enjoy. That is what college should be about..I come to find that a comment must have at least 10 lines.

1969 was the year. New York City was the place. Putney Swoope was the second Robert Downey film to achieve some recognition. The first was Chaffed Elbows (1966). Putney Swoope achieved a much wider release. Pound (1970) and Greasers Palace (1972) were even more profane and obnoxious. Those 2 films were mean spirited to the point that they actually stalled the Prince's feature film career for several years.The subject at hand is Putney Swoope. And it is a mad farce/satire that has to be seen to be believed. I'm not going to go through the plot here.

What a cast of actors and actresses in this Columbo episode , beside Peter Falk , you have Julie Newmar , the unforgettable Catwoman, along with talented performers such as William Shatner and Anne Baxter. The thrilling plot is filled with twists, keeping viewers on their toes, wondering if Columbo will piece together the puzzle in time. The intricate screenplay and solid character portrayals from this remarkable ensemble adds a touch of drama and complexity. Moreover, the delightful chemistry between Peter Falk and his fellow cast members amplifies the brilliance of the show, making this episode a standout within the long-running, classic detective series.

For those out there that like to think of themselves as reasonably intelligent human beings , who love film , especially the intellectual and thought-provoking cinema, be prepared for an exciting and potentially life-changing movie marathon. These cinematic gems not only offer outstanding performances and a captivating storyline, but also push the boundaries of filmmaking and storytelling. Be ready to dive deep into various themes ranging from the complexities of human nature to ethical and societal challenges. Discover new perspectives through both critically acclaimed blockbusters and undiscovered indie treasures that are bound to make you question, engage, and ponder the incredible tapestry of the human experience.

Jack, Sawyer and Sayid swim to the boat and find a completely wasted Desmond. His traumatic past experience before sailing to the island is disclosed through flashbacks. Sayid plots a plan with Jack to surprise "The Others" in case Michael is double-crossing the group. John Locke convinces Desmond to invade the hatch, which is protected by Mr. Eko, and not press the button of the computer to see what will happen.This episode is one of the best of the Second Season. Unfortunately, we lovers of "Lost" can see the lack of respect the producers of this stunning series have with the fans.

Try to look for another movie that is such a trip without having a story or plot and you 'll struggle to find one that compares. This movie defies traditional storytelling methods, forcing viewers to step outside their comfort zone and venture into a surreal realm where reality and fiction seamlessly intertwine. Each frame brims with mesmerizing visuals and unforgettable characters, thrusting you head-first into a whirlwind of kaleidoscopic madness that completely envelopes you in its intricate beauty. Essentially, what this film successfully does is transform conventional cinema into a sensory roller-coaster of cerebral delights.

The "all I have is 5 dollars and my wedding ring..." scene was a riot. I also guffawed at the scene in the bar where Hyde snorted the horse radish and flipped the bird to the Japanese guy and said "Pearl Harbor buddy". I think my IQ is higher than 115, but I'm not sure because I can't count that high.Funny thing, this 10 line requirement. Seems as though they would bash you for making your comments too long, not too short. I hope I don't make it to 1,000 words before I get to line 10.I'm still two lines short.

It took me a while to find this movie since they do n't have it yet on DVD ( and I'm not even sure if they ever plan on releasing it in that format). After a tedious search online, I finally found a digital version available for rent. Though initially reluctant, given the low resolution, I decided to give it a shot, simply due to the immense curiosity I had surrounding this hard-to-find title. Surprisingly, it turned out to be worth it! The acting, plot, and overall atmosphere managed to grip me despite the less-than-perfect visual quality, making the experience a delightful find indeed.

I thought I might be disappointed viewing this film again after so many years. On the contrary, I was more impressed now than in my callow youth with its honesty and brave humour. In 1969, the transition among African-American groups from a predominant policy of conciliation and integration to one of confrontation and self-determination was still quite new, and more than a little controversial. It took courage and finesse to portray both the Establishment and the Anti-establishment as the caricatures they often closely approximated in real life. Special mention should be made of Arnold Johnson's performance: he successfully avoided having his character lapse into either sociopathy or buffoonery.

Final Solution is a powerful christian film that shows the hate between the black and whites that was present in the days of apartheid. It shows how this hate was contrived and was groomed from generation to generation. Jan Ellis was taught that a black man was a plague. He was raised to be that way. Then he meets a man who is on the opposite side of his beliefs, Pastor Lekota. will he change his ways?. The film is a powerful movie that shows the perceptions the different races had for one another, it shows these perceptions with quite a lot of accuracy.

As far as I know I've seen most of Lucio Fulci's films, with the exception of some later ones that are popping up on DVD now, and I would have to say this was his best "pre-zombie" offering. In fact it beats out his later movies hands-down. This is a tale of superstition and suspicion in a small Italian town out in the middle of nowhere, where young boys are dying mysteriously. It's no mystery how they died, I guess, it's more who's doing it. Is it a woman that the townspeople have always considered a witch?

I thought this movie was pretty good ! OK , so maybe it had a few scenes that could make you roll your eyes or question the plot, but overall it was an enjoyable experience. The visuals and special effects were stunning and added a sense of excitement to the storyline. The acting wasn't exceptional, but the chemistry between the lead characters was palpable, which contributed to my investment in their fate. Admittedly, the script had its flaws and at times felt cliche, but the movie never claimed to be high art.

I went to the pre-screening of `` Rory O'Shea Was Here . '' I like this movie better than I anticipated. It follows the story of two young men with physical disabilities, Rory and Michael, who form a special bond in a shared-care home. The movie deals with sensitive and often overlooked issues related to disability, friendship, and independence. The witty and honest portrayal by James McAvoy and Steven Robertson had a captivating and inspiring effect on me. Through ups and downs, Rory and Michael challenge societal stereotypes, fighting to prove that they are more than their disabilities.

"Nuovomondo" was a great experience. Many filmmakers tell their stories to a big extent via dialogue. Emanuele Crialese directs his film very visually driven. For everything he wants to tell, he finds powerful images that are able to stand for themselves. Thus, he understands film as a medium that primarily tells its stories over the pictures on screen. Particularly European cinema is often very dialogue-driven (and many of the young US-American directors are strongly influenced by that). Crialese's opposite attitude was really the point, that made this film special for me.

The Aristorcats is a hilarious film that not many people have seen. Clearly not that many because it only got a 6.8. There is nothing wrong with it at all. It's my favorite of the Disney classics, which have tons of fantastic films already made. Like Beauty and the Beast, Snow White, and Peter Pan. The reason why The Aristorcats is so high on my list is because of how funny the film is. I hate to say this, but I don't blame Edgar for what he does. I probably would've had them taken care of too.

Pity the Monkees . People always accused them of being manufactured ( which they were ) or being nothing more than a Beatles knock-off (which was only partially true). However, there's more to the story of the Monkees than just marketing genius. Beneath the surface of TV characters and pop culture novelty, they managed to create some truly catchy music and inspired an entire generation. Yes, they may not have always played their own instruments and wrote some of their own music, but their sound still left a significant mark on the industry.

This movie , based on a true story of Gerrit Wolfaardt , is one of the best films I 've ever seen. Set against the backdrop of Apartheid-era South Africa, the movie brilliantly captures the life and transformation of Wolfaardt, a former white supremacist, who ultimately abandons his prejudiced beliefs and dedicates his life to combating racial injustice. With its gripping narrative and superb performances from the actors, this powerful and thought-provoking film resonates deeply with the viewer, prompting introspection and understanding of the roots and consequences of hate. Its emotive portrayal of the importance of tolerance and the potential for personal change makes this a must-see cinematic masterpiece.

I saw this film at a small screening. Even though it had a low budget, the creative direction and intelligence of the cast helped make this a small gem of a movie. It's April 8, 1994, each of the characters are in their "mid 20's" and pursuing some kind of artistic ambition (acting, music, film, writing) when they learn of Nirvana singer Kurt Cobain's suicide. They quickly get inspiration to travel from San Francisco to Seattle and attend the Cobain vigil. It's here where the film really picks up and serves up a series of funny and emotional scenes.

A labor of love . Each frame is picture perfect and grabs you . Then the sheer emotion and story-telling elevate it to a masterpiece. The intricacy and passion poured into every scene is tangible, with the exquisite details leaving the audience mesmerized. The tapestry of intertwined storylines unravel with seamless beauty, enticing you deeper into its depths, urging you to discover more. From the engaging characters that enrapture our hearts to the remarkable twists and evocative nuances that form a visual feast, the sheer dedication behind every brush stroke of this wondrous art leaves an indelible imprint on your soul.

Who ARE the people that star in this thing ? Never heard of them ! ! But this is one of the best movies I've ever watched! These hidden gems, showcasing some incredibly talented yet unknown actors, keep the film industry alive and thriving. While these individuals may not yet grace the covers of magazines, their dedication to their craft brings authentic, raw performances to the screen, making this movie such a captivating and memorable experience. It reminds us not to dismiss productions with lesser-known actors – give them a chance, as you just might witness the birth of a future superstar.

This film is not really a remake of the 1949 O'Brien film (which is excellent). It borrows the main premise--a man has been poisoned and spends the rest of the film trying to find his killer. But I like that the writers chose an English professor, instead of a private dick, as the protagonist. The plot is also quite original. In general, the film moves along fast enough to keep you awake. But what mars this film is a strange dated quality about it (probably due to the horrendous 80's original music score)combined with an affected "noir" feel.

NOBODY (1999) is a fantastic piece of Japanese noir. It's about three salarymen who get in way over their heads when their innocent, drunken cheapshots p*** off three OTHER guys one night in a bar. When these three mysterious strangers, who are up to much more deviant no-goodness than even the film allows us to know, beat the living daylights out of one of our "heroes", the trio decides to return the favour in kind - only they accidentally KILL one of the other guys!

This was a riveting film, one that really drew me in. I'm a big fan of William H. Macy, and he puts in a wonderful performance. His great likeability, coupled with the way his character breaks the fourth wall, really gave me a sense of complicity in his actions. I found myself waiting tensely for the whole house of cards to come collapsing down around him (and by extension myself, as his confidante and silent witness). It took several minutes for me to relax once the film had ended, I was so wrapped up in it.

For those out there that like to think of themselves as reasonably intelligent human beings, who love film, have good attention to detail and enjoy indie movies with funny, smartly written dialogue then this is a film for you.For those with a poor attention span, high expectations and no brains.. well.. um.. you may get bored and find things dragging at times.This is a charming, modest and well paced movie with the actors bestowing a real sense of depth and warmth to their roles. I chuckled to myself pretty much the whole way through..This film is a little gem.

"Hari om" is an Indian greeting and the compelling title character of the film bearing this same name(played by the wedding planner from Monsoon Wedding) greets you and takes you on a journey through the heart of southern India. There's no "Bend it like Beckham" backdrops and stereotypes, and only slight salutes to the music and dancing of Bollywood (however, the soundtrack is well worth procuring), but rather, the feel that you are seeing the real India permeates the film through the use of dozens of local residents in each scene to augment the performance of the five professional actors.

The Golden Door is the story of a Sicilian family 's journey from the Old World ( Italy ) to the New World ( America ) in search of a better life. Set in the early 20th century, the film chronicles the trials, struggles, and sacrifices the Mancuso family faces as they navigate through the complex process of migration. As the family bids farewell to their close-knit community and culture, they face an oceanic crossing in a cramped ship. Upon arriving on American shores, they experience hope and heartache at the infamous Ellis Island processing center.

This is probably my favourite TV show ever. I love all the characters, especially Alex, who is the PERFECT woman! Always makes me laugh and feel good when I watch this show. There is just something about it that is amazing, hard to describe.It seems some or all of the episodes synchronise with music albums as well. Here are a few examples. (The episodes start again when they end - but DON'T play end credits until the very end, but always play the opening credits. With most the episodes the album plays once and the episodes play twice, but some go on further.

Gary Busey's best performance in a nicely-flowing biography. Since had a musical background, he was able to do his own songs and it really works. It's always good to see that fine actor, Don Stroud (one of the crickets) and Charlie Martin Smith as well.An 8 out of 10. Best performance = Gary Busey. Thankfully, Mr. Busey was Oscar-nominated for this, losing to Jon Voight in COMING HOME. A fairly low-budget flick that doesn't disappoint, with GREAT SONGS by Mr. Holly. I hope this made plenty of dough.

No, I have not seen the original series and I won't compare the two if I had. This series is filmed in Canada in Vancouver and Victoria, British Columbia. The series is well-written in a different story each week. Some are little out there but most of the time it is the quality of the story telling. I loved the Afterlife episode with Clancy Brown and Barbara Gerrick and the Deprogrammers episode with the irresistible Brent Spiner as a Deprogrammer in a world where humans have become slaves to a lizard reptilian species.

(Some spoilers included:)Although, many commentators have called this film surreal, the term fits poorly here. To quote from Encyclopedia Britannica's, surreal means:"Fantastic or incongruous imagery": One needn't explain to the unimaginative how many ways a plucky ten-year-old boy at large and seeking his fortune in the driver's seat of a red Mustang could be fantastic: those curious might read James Kincaid; but if you asked said lad how he were incongruous behind the wheel of a sports car, he'd surely protest, "NO way!"

This is a funny movie . The Bob & Eddie Show feel of it could lead to a sequel but it would depend on the audience response. The dynamic duo, Bob and Eddie, share a series of comedic misadventures that will have you laughing out loud. Their quick wit and quirky sense of humor deliver endless laughs and quotable moments. As they find themselves in one ridiculous scenario after another, Bob and Eddie navigate their way through these challenging situations while hilariously figuring things out along the way. The strong chemistry between the two leads provides a fantastic foundation for future films to come.

`` I am ... proud of 'Head ' , '' Mike Nesmith has said . He should be , because "Head" is a testament to Nesmith's creativity and boldness as a musician, actor, and producer. Released in 1968, "Head" showcases not just his skills, but also that of his fellow Monkees, as they challenge the norms of that era's entertainment industry and tackle subjects that resonate even today. Blending comedy with moments of sincere drama, psychedelic visuals, and unconventional narrative structure, "Head" was groundbreaking and risky for its time.

Really , This movie should be released to DVD . I just got a bootleg copy of what I think is the director's cut, and I am beyond impressed with its content and storyline. I firmly believe that if it were to be released to DVD, this hidden gem would finally receive the recognition it deserves. Fans of independent films would absolutely cherish it, as it offers a unique and fresh take on cinema, pushing the boundaries of storytelling and cinematography. Releasing this movie on DVD would not only do justice to the talented creators but would also cultivate an appreciative fanbase that thrives on remarkable art.

As a film buff, I obviously had read all the excruciating reviews and funny, sarcastic comments about this film (my favourite being Woody Allen's quip "If I had my life to live over again I wouldn't change anything ... except for seeing the musical remake of Lost Horizon"). Therefore I've never been able to watch it without smirking at the choreography/set/songs etc. Just recently I came across a widescreen DVD and watched it for the first time in years, along with a friend who had never heard of the film's reputation.

I 've been watching Attack Of The Show religiously for about 6 months ( maybe longer but not much ) and I can say without a doubt that it's an absolute gem! The content is incredibly diverse and never gets boring. The hosts manage to strike a perfect balance between humor and factual information, ensuring that I stay entertained while I learn about new technology, gaming updates, movie and TV show recommendations, and more. The daily viral clips never fail to make me laugh or impress me with the innovation on display, and the weekly segments like “Around the Net” offer a wonderful insight into various trending topics.

I first saw `` Signs of Life '' on PBS as an American Playhouse presentation . It 's a wonderfully atmospheric and thought-provoking drama that has stayed with me since that initial viewing. Set in the heart of World War II, the film follows the journey of three men forced to confront their prejudices and insecurities while faced with the difficult task of staying alive in the midst of turmoil. Brilliantly written and brought to life with superb performances, this poignant and introspective tale not only provides a deeply personal lens into wartime, but also explores the complicated aspects of the human psyche under tremendous emotional strain.

Even after nearly 20 years apart, the original members of Black Sabbath have not lost a thing. In this concert, they perform their best songs from their heyday (1970-1978), including "N.I.B. ", "War Pigs", and "Paranoid".Also included is priceless backstage footage with interviews and retrospectives into their days as the top hard rock band on the planet. The comments of Ozzy, Tony Iommi, Geezer Butler, and Bill Ward are just as interesting and intriguing to watch as the fabulous onstage performances.A must-see for all Sabbath and Ozzy fans.

This movie got better with time. I can't believe that it has been forty years since I saw this at the age of 15. Yes, that's right. Movie ratings were not yet a reality, so any teenager could walk into any movie. Imagine what it was like for a kid my age to see both Midnight Cowboy and Putney Swope in the same year. Imagine the times. Bobby Kennedy and Martin Luther King has just been killed but the following summer had a man walking on the moon and Woodstock. Putney Swope was the Woodstock nation's chance to stick it to the man.

William Faulkner was one of the American writers to win the Nobel Prize in literature . Faulkner mostly wrote about the American South, exploring themes of social and racial tensions, family dynamics, and personal struggles. Known for his distinct literary style, his writing was characterized by intricate plots, engaging narrative techniques, and complex characters. Notable works include "The Sound and the Fury," "As I Lay Dying," and "Light in August." Throughout his career, Faulkner persistently focused on the tumultuous changes facing the South as it grappled with modernization and preserving its history and identity.

It's up there with Where's Poppa, The Groove Tube, Putney Swope. It memorializes the NY city mind set of the period, a wonderfully strange man with a bizarre plan, hoist by by own petard, and at last retreating into the bed of his adoptive parents. Totally absurd, its the life one sees through the magic glasses, seeing things as they "really are"... I don't think it is ever shown anymore. If so, surely someone would Tivo the thing and put it out there.

Chucky is back but this time he is not scary (a lot) - but he is funny!When Chucky is brought back to life (in the doll, of course) by his old trailer trash girlfriend, Tiffany, he promptly kills her and transforms her into a doll, too. Tiffany and Chucky are now on the case of 2 high school graduates - eekkk! !Don't miss this film - it is a whole lot of fun. It is scary, funny, weird, wacky and stupid all in one!My rating : 9/10.

I love the TV contest . Hate to see it end . There are so many talented contestants . It 's always thrilling to see them showcasing their skills week after week, continually evolving and stepping up their game. It is incredible to witness such creativity, determination, and drive in one place. Of course, as with any competition, the process can be emotional and heart wrenching, seeing the elimination of personal favorites or that emotional tear-jerker episode. But, these emotions keep viewers gripped, passionately discussing with friends and family about each episode's highlights, making the show's end harder to say goodbye to each time.

When the Romulans come, they will not be bearing gifts; no, they bring with them war - war and conquest. As any familiar with this episode know, it is a redux of the war film "The Enemy Below" from the fifties. The obvious difference is that instead of a battleship and a submarine (or an American Destroyer & German U-boat) engaged in lethal war games, it is two starships in outer space. In Trek history, about 100 years before the events here, according to this episode, Earth fought the Romulan Wars.

I wish there were more films about middle aged people . The intellectual journey and the twists and turns of life during middle age are rarely explored in-depth in mainstream cinema. Instead, we mostly see youth-centric plots, simplistic rom-coms or overly sentimental films that offer limited insights into the struggles and triumphs of individuals navigating their forties and fifties. Just like younger characters, middle-aged protagonists possess a plethora of diverse experiences that could entertain and enlighten viewers, reflecting on topics such as parenthood, reinventing one's career, or rediscovering life post-retirement. These untapped stories have the potential to impact the industry and make cinematic experiences even richer.

where do we go from here? that is the overriding question of this film. And make no mistake, 'mainly ETC. ', the 2003 effort from director john jansen, asks far more questions than it answers, but none so poignantly or so powerfully as this one.much of the the film plays like a running conversation between you and your college drinking buddies, and I'm sure many of the questions raised by the main characters you'll recognize from your own evenings of drunken debauchery. however, one of the many beauties of this film is that we are rarely given an answer.

The movie is based on a Jules Verne book I actually have read once, about ten years ago. I remember I liked the book a lot, and this movie does a good job in telling the story. The most important thing in this movie isn't the story, however, but the highly original visual look it has.The visuals are absolutely beautiful, and they are apparently achieved by a clever combination of animated drawings combined with live actors, stop-motion animation and sets that are painted so that they look much like from an animated movie.

What can I say about the series dubbed the NEW OUTER LIMITS ... Hmm .... Only that this was one of the most intriguing and captivating anthology series of its time. First aired in 1995, the NEW OUTER LIMITS was a true masterpiece, carefully crafted to bring awe-inspiring, thought-provoking, and spine-tingling stories to television screens. This groundbreaking sci-fi series perfectly captured a surreal, mysterious, and suspenseful atmosphere. The storytelling took on varying concepts and topics, ranging from bizarre, eerie encounters with the supernatural, to fascinating adventures into parallel worlds and time travel.

`` Showtime '' falls somewhere north of what some critics have been saying , and a little south of what the most ardent fans may expect. While it has its flaws and inconsistencies, the series definitely has its share of gripping, adrenaline-pumping moments that keep the viewers hooked. The storytelling, particularly in the latter half of the series, shows signs of both inventive genius and frustrating haphazardness. At times, character development seems to take a backseat, resulting in some narrative arcs feeling rushed or disjointed. Nevertheless, the ensemble cast delivers stellar performances that manage to engage viewers, transcending the weak script at times.

I saw a sneak preview of this Tuesday night with a group of friends and we had a blast ! The atmosphere was buzzing with excitement as we walked into the theater, eagerly waiting for the show to begin. From the opening scene, we were hooked - the visuals, acting, and storyline were all incredible. We couldn't help but gasp, laugh, and cheer throughout the movie. There were a few unexpected twists that added extra depth to the plot and the characters. Even after the film ended, we continued to discuss the memorable scenes over some post-cinema snacks.

i did not read the book . nor do i care to . the movie was a beautiful romance , though I know it can't fully capture the depth and intricacies of the original written work. Still, the captivating performances by the leads managed to touch my heart and draw me into their intense love story. Visually, the movie was stunning, bringing to life both the majestic scenery and the subtle nuances of the characters' emotional journeys. Regardless of my disinterest in the book, this movie stands as a testament to the power of great storytelling, where art transcends its original medium and affects audiences regardless of format.

I remember years ago BBC1 used to show this movie in a very cut form. I tracked it down on video a couple of years ago and viewed it again. The film although slow and slightly odd (the mountain men look very strange) the atmosphere was eerily effective. It's one of my favorite slasher films and I have no idea where an uncut version can be found. Currently deleted everywhere (except the USA where it was accidentally put on a horror compilation!). It's a shame you cannot get this movie as it was meant to be seen.

I absolutely adore this movie! I had never heard of it when I saw it at the video store. I saw Kathy Bates was in it, so I figured it had to have some worth, you know? I watched it the first time just shaking my head . . . huh? Then it was the last scene and I found myself aching from smiling so hard. I clicked "play movie" and watched the whole thing again. It is without doubt the quirkiest movie I've ever seen. But the more I watch it, the more I love it.

This interesting film noir features three very good performances: Sanders, Patrick, and Blackmer. The scenes between Sanders and Patrick are particularly outstanding. Demming, as the detective, is unfortunately not nearly as good. He lacks the intelligence, strength, and cynical world view of a Bogart. Had Humphrey played this part, we could have had a classic.Pace, location (a library), and atmosphere are all good. But there are a few plot holes. Sanders strongly fears Blackmer and the ruthless organization (Nazis) he represents. Yet after mistakenly killing Blackmer, Sanders seems to experience no anxiety or remorse.

Whoever plays the part of J. Douglas Williamson in the strip poker scene does a wonderful job .
