He apparently has a natural talent for comedy and keeps the audience engaged with his charismatic presence. The way he seamlessly balances both the confidence and awkwardness of J. Douglas Williamson, a young man finding himself in such a peculiar and unpredictable situation, is truly impressive. The actor's impeccable comic timing and amusing expressions have everyone in stitches throughout the scene. Moreover, his ability to keep the atmosphere light-hearted and enjoyable, even in a somewhat risqué situation like strip poker, is a testament to his versatility and flair for comedy.

"Showtime" is a funny film starring funnymen Robert DeNiro (Meet the Parents,A Bronx Tale) and Eddie Murphy (Shrek, Dr. Dolittle). The story is this: In the beginning of the movie detective Mitch (Robert DeNiro) and another detective go into a tv store trying to bust some criminals. When the cops arrive, Tray(Eddie Murphy)a cop, tries to arrest Mitch not knowing he's a cop. During this scene loads of funny things happen which catch the eye of tv producer Chase Ritz.

I gave it a seven only because the acting is good. And of course by that I mean Wilkinson. The other two principals were "decent". But the characters themselves...what on earth was so bad about the character Wilkinson played (James Manning)? I didn't see him behaving like the martinet Emily Watson accused him of being. Bill Bule, on the other hand, was an insufferable jerk who I was praying would meet an extremely brutal and prolonged demise. Who was I kidding? Tom Wilkinson isn't Paul Bettany after all.

Loved today 's show ! ! ! It was a variety and not solely cooking ( which would have been fine, too). But it was really great to see different segments – like fashion, wellness, and entertainment – all interwoven seamlessly throughout the program. It truly kept things fresh, engaging, and exciting for the viewers. It's wonderful how you all bring creative, informative, and trendy topics to life with such enthusiasm and genuine passion. Can't wait to watch more of these well-rounded episodes, as they genuinely offer something for everyone.

Like a few people I know, I came in late on 'Stingers'; not until 2000. Three years later there is no way I'd miss an episode. The show really is that good and has, for a better word, maintained its integrity, unlike 'Blue Heelers', for example. The crime is the thing; personal lives are there but only wheeled out when affecting an investigation! When Gary Sweet was brought in, some fans seemed worried, but he's really fitted in well, which didn't surprise me.

But a great cast! Jonathan Pryce, Kathy Bates, Rupert Everett, Lynne Redgrave, Julie Andrews and Dan Aykroyd! And that's just the beginning.I'm not totally sure that any description of the movie and plot are going to entice you to watch this one. Suffice it to say that it has something for practically everyone: death, singing, a sparkly suit, cell phones, a little person (nice looking woman, actually), a drawbridge (modern, not Medieval), a boombox, and a crossbow. Oh, and a psychotic.

After learning that her sister Susan is contemplating divorce , Kate decides to travel to the distraught woman 's remote cabin in the mountains, hoping to provide comfort and support. Upon arriving, she's startled to discover that Susan has invited their estranged brother, Michael, to join them for an unexpected family reunion. Over the course of the weekend, the siblings unearth deep-rooted grievances, face unresolved issues, and address long-forgotten family secrets. As they confront the tumultuous memories of their childhood, Kate tries to help Susan reconsider the path to divorce, and to find strength and resilience to navigate the challenges of her troubled marriage.

The Golden Door is the story of a Sicilian family's journey from the Old World (Italy) to the New World (America). Salvatore, a middle-aged man who hopes for a more fruitful life, persuades his family to leave their homeland behind in Sicily, take the arduous journey across the raging seas, and inhabit a land whose rivers supposedly flow with milk. In short, they believe that by risking everything for the New World their dreams of prosperity will be fulfilled. The imagery of the New World is optimistic, clever and highly imaginative.

I gave it a seven only because the acting is good . And of course by that I mean Wilkinson and Anderson's performances, which were both incredibly convincing and engaging. The plot, while not entirely original, had enough twists and unexpected turns to keep me hooked till the end. The cinematography and use of setting really complemented the story, creating an atmosphere of tension and unease throughout the movie. However, certain scenes felt drawn out, and some supporting characters were underdeveloped, which prevented the film from being an outstanding success.

I had heard of John Garfield , but , did n't know him . I loved this movie . I never knew John could leave such an impact on viewers like myself. In the movie, he brilliantly portrayed the character's emotions and conflicts, showcasing his impeccable acting skills. His screen presence was truly magnetic, and I found myself fully absorbed in his performance. I highly recommend others to watch it too, as it's an unforgettable masterpiece that highlights the artistry of John Garfield. From his impressive talent to the compelling plot, this film has turned me into a newfound fan and truly broadened my cinematic horizons.

Another enjoyable Warner flick . I really liked John Garfield in this , though I 'm wondering why Cagney was not cast in the lead role as he would have been a perfect fit. Nevertheless, Garfield's gritty performance was compelling and effectively carried the story. The supporting cast also delivered solid performances, making for an all-around entertaining and well-crafted film. The dialogue was sharp, and the pace moved at a good clip, keeping my attention throughout. Overall, the atmosphere captured that signature Warner Bros. style of the 1940s era that we've come to know and love.

I 've never seen the original `` House Of Wax '' so I really did n't know what to expect going into this film. But to my surprise, the remake starring Elisha Cuthbert and Chad Michael Murray turned out to be quite an enjoyable watch. The story follows a group of friends who find themselves trapped in a creepy wax museum where the sinister curator has created disturbingly lifelike sculptures using actual human bodies. Though not exactly groundbreaking, the film does offer a good dose of suspense, thrilling chase sequences, and a chilling atmosphere.

I never heard of architect , Louis Kahn , until this documentary . In this almost two hour documentary which features a combination of interviews, archival footage, and beautiful visuals of Kahn's masterpieces, one truly begins to understand and appreciate the genius and impact of this great architect. Louis Kahn's innovative designs, infused with profound humanism, inspired a whole new generation of architects. Through heartfelt anecdotes from family, friends, and clients, the documentary also explores his tumultuous personal life, illustrating a compelling and inspiring portrait of a visionary whose works continue to dazzle and amaze the world today.

Chucky (the murderous doll from "Child's Play" and 2 crappy sequels) is dead. But his ex-girlfriend Tiffany (Jennifer Tilly) gets his remains and (using "Voodoo for Dummies") revives him. Then, through circumstances too convoluted to get into, SHE is killed and has her soul put into another doll! Together they fall in love and kidnap a nice couple (Nick Stabile, Katherine Heigl) to take them to Chuck's coffin to get an amulet to make Chucky and Tiffany real people again...A lot better than it sounds.

This movie is a love story set in the backdrop of war . Everything about the movie was perfect . The captivating cinematography seamlessly captures the beauty and brutality of the times, effortlessly intertwining the complex emotions associated with both love and war. Each scene impeccably showcases the deeply raw chemistry shared by the passionate protagonists, which effectively enables viewers to experience their euphoric love affair through empathetic connections. However, the movie never fails to underline the tragic consequences and horrors that engulf the battlefield, subtly yet convincingly providing a poignant portrayal of star-crossed love amidst harrowing conflict.

When the new Outer Limits first started , the episodes were quite optimistic and challenging . As the series began to develop, the creators continued to explore thought-provoking and inventive themes, which led to increasingly captivating storylines. Delving deeper into issues like time-travel, extraterrestrial encounters, and experimental science, the show started gaining a large following among science fiction enthusiasts. This ambitious, complex approach helped cement its legacy within the sci-fi genre. While still retaining its characteristic eeriness, the Outer Limits found a balance that offered intellectual escapism and touched upon prevalent topics related to ethics, technological advances, and the human condition.

People comparing this movie to big blockbusters like Lord of the Rings or the Matrix will inevitably be disappointed with the way this movie turned out. Although it lacks in the big special effects department and there are no battles with hundreds of extras, there is still a masterful amalgamation of two old folk tales here. The acting talent, although not A-list, is still great and the interaction between the characters is perhaps more sincere than in a larger movie with an A-list cast. My particular favourite from this movie is Bridget Fonda, whose performance as the Snow Queen herself was quite moving, assisted enormously by a stupendous wardrobe and makeup.

Chaplin is a doughboy in his final film of 1918, a doughboy who can not seem to get the marching down straight. He spends time "over there" in World War One trenches. Several gags stand out: Limburger cheese as a makeshift grenade for one. The cramped quarters of the barracks in the trenches and when Chaplin and his mates are washed out of their bunks by flooding are highlights. Chaplin ends up capturing several German soldiers single-handed, and he spanks the German commander for refusing a cigarette. When asked how he did it, Chaplin replies that he surrounded them.

When I started watching 3 of the episodes of this series on the Action Channel,I have to say out of all the shows that I've seen that ADV released,this one is one of the best shows of all time. I had to see it again,and that's when I got my chance. I bought the entire box set of this series at Best Buy for my 20th Birthday. And I got to enjoy it,and see more of the episodes that I missed on Action Channel,and the same 3 episodes that I've seen.

SHOWTIME is a mess , but it 's an entertaining mess . The plot is forgettable , the satire is half-baked, and the characters are shallow, yet there's something inexplicably enjoyable about the chaos unfolding onscreen. Amid the whirlwind of flashy action sequences and chaotic comedy, it's impossible not to be amused. This may not be high cinema or intellectual satire, but it's perfect for an undemanding viewing experience that entertains without requiring too much from the audience. Essentially, SHOWTIME thrives in its ability to transform imperfections into an unapologetically enjoyable thrill ride.

This film is an impressionistic , poetic take on the immigrant experience , a reflective look at the turmoil and uncertainty faced by those who leave their homeland in search of a better life. As it beautifully explores the delicate balance between assimilation and preservation of cultural heritage, it delves deep into the emotions, challenges and personal sacrifices involved in the quest for belonging. Set against a haunting and mesmerizing backdrop, the narrative interweaves snippets of various stories and characters, creating a compelling tapestry of diverse voices and experiences that offers glimpses into the myriad facets of migration, loss and hope.

I'm not a huge fan of Lucio Fulci's films. Most of his 80s gore films had their moments, but often came across as second-rate Dario Argento imitations. With the exception of the entertaining "Zombi" (which was a George Romero imitation), I didn't really enjoy them. I know Italian horror often disregards the plot, but the storyline and characters in his films were just far too thread bare even by the standards. This is why "Don't Torture a Duckling" surprised me. Its actually a very well made film with an engrossing murder mystery.

the first time I saw this movie , I just thought `` what the hell ? '' a 10-year-old kid the first time I saw this movie, I just thought "what the hell?" A 10-year-old kid running around fighting bad guys, outsmarting everyone, and even driving a car? The whole concept seemed absurd and far-fetched. But as I watched the film unfold, I started to appreciate the charming wit, and adventurous spirit captured by this young protagonist. While it may have its quirks, it brilliantly reminded me of the unbounded imagination that runs wild within a child's mind.

The young John Garfield turned in a fine performance in the 1939 `` They Made Me a Criminal . '' The young John Garfield turned in a fine performance in the 1939 "They Made Me a Criminal." Playing the lead character, a wrongly accused boxer on the run from the police, he demonstrated the makings of an accomplished actor that would earn him numerous accolades throughout his career. In the film, Garfield masterfully displays a unique blend of intensity, vulnerability, and street-smart charisma which kept the audience engaged in his pursuit of justice.

I went to the pre-screening of "Rory O'Shea Was Here." I like this movie better than I expected, because the excellent casts and the powerful performance. It's a film about the friendship of two handicapped young man. Rory is free spirit young man who wants to be independent regardless his Duchenne muscular dystrophy. He can only move his two fingers but he can talk eloquently and help his new pal, Michael, who has cerebral palsy and is significantly speech impaired. I guess that's enough to start with a weeping drama. Well, it is.

Most critics seem to have dismissed this film, like so many other Charles Bronson vehicles, as just another patchwork of mindless violence. And while there is a fair amount of mayhem, DEATH WISH 3 is not that awful of an effort, particularly for fans of the series and its star.This time out, aging Charlie's Paul Kersey is let loose by a police chief desperate to clean up a rough part of New York City. The trigger-happy vigilante moves into the heart of gang territory, where he once again becomes a one-man army in an urban war of good versus evil.

I was n't expecting a great deal from this film , so I was pleasantly surprised when I watched it and found myself genuinely engaged and entertained. The plot was unexpectedly refreshing, boasting intriguing twists and interesting character development that piqued my curiosity throughout. The cinematography was visually striking, accompanied by an evocative soundtrack which contributed to the immersive experience. Stellar performances from the actors infused the film with emotional depth and conviction, making it easy to relate to the characters and their struggles. While it may not be groundbreaking, it's a well-rounded movie that deserves more credit than it initially led me to believe.

Some days ago, in Rome, a young Romanian man with criminal precedents assaulted and tortured to death a middle-age lady coming back home after an afternoon of shopping. A Romanian girl, who had seen everything, reported what happened.Therefore, it started a debate about the too much intense flow of immigrants from Romania, generalizing them as criminals, everyone, indiscriminately.I'm only 15, but I thought: what idea of affluence does Italy give to these poor people? How ever do they regard us as the Land of Plenty? Yesterday evening I finally saw NUOVOMONDO, and my question had an answer.

I don't see what the problem is with SOME people and their NEED for intellectual humor. You need to get your head out of your up-tight ass if you don't find this movie hilarious! If this isn't your "cup of tea", so to speak, then look at it for what it truly is- a damn funny movie. Maybe they DID set out to make yet another drugs/T&A movie, but in this case, they've truly hit the spot. It's especially funny for the Ali G fans, because he delivers everything we've come to love and expect from him.

When the trailer for Accepted first came up, many people began to get excited about seeing it... really excited. Who could blame them, it looked like fun. But that's exactly the thing. People went into Accepted looking for a good movie, but if you think about it, Accepted isn't the type of film destined to be a good movie. It's meant to be a film that pleases its crowd without too much effort being given. That being said, for those of you who expected a great film, you need to think about what could be made of a comedy like this one.

Damien O'Donnell has a good track record and in this film he handles a very delicate topic with sensitivity but manages not to let the film turn into schmalz.This is a fantastic film, its funny with sad bits and it makes you look at things differently. Tell everyone you know to go see it now- FANTASTIC!The acting is excellent, and Dublin plays a starring role. This film will change the way you view people with disabilities and also give you a very entertaining night out in the cinema. I can't wait til it comes out on DVD.

I saw this film at a small screening . Even though it had a low budget , the creative direction and storytelling were top-notch. The actors, although not very well-known, delivered compelling and believable performances that instantly drew the audience in. The story was simple, but emotionally resonant, dealing with themes of love, friendship, and loss in an unexpectedly relatable and captivating manner. Visually, the film was engaging and had a gritty, real-life feel to it. It proved that sometimes it doesn't take millions of dollars and A-list celebrities to create a memorable and touching movie experience.

Accepted is a 2006 teen flick that stars the guy from the mac and PC ads . The movie is centered around Bartleby Gaines, played by Justin Long (known from the Mac and PC ads), who, after being rejected by every college he applied to, creates his own fake institution named the South Harmon Institute of Technology (S.H.I.T.) to maintain his façade of success. To his surprise, several other rejected students also start attending the "university". Hilarity ensues as the group strives to legitimize their school, evade education authorities, and forge friendships through unconventional means.

This is my favourite Columbo. Martin Landau (excellent!) plays twins, one of whom may have committed a murder. This Columbo is unusual because the usual murder scene at the beginning doesn't give you any clue to which one did it! Peter Falk is on form as usual in this episode written by Steven Bochco (who also wrote 'Murder by the Book', my second favourite episode). The supporting cast are great especially Julie Newmar (very under-rated) and Jeanette Nolan as the house keeper that Columbo just keeps on upsetting.

I was pleasantly surprised by the depth of story and character development . Fulci was a master at creating horrific imagery and spine-chilling atmosphere, which this film definitely did not disappoint on. The chilling music and eerie settings really managed to captivate the audience and hold them captive throughout. In addition to the unsettling visuals, the thought-provoking storyline and carefully crafted personalities made the experience both thrilling and engaging. I genuinely cared for the characters and their journey as they navigated through their chilling surroundings. The themes tackled throughout were unsettling and brutal but handled in a way that wasn't gratuitous.

In this early Fulci work the director shows his most mainstream side as well as a talent for compelling storytelling . Despite being primarily known for his gory, horror masterpieces, Fulci surprises the audience in this piece, presenting a finely tuned, dramatic narrative. This engaging film unravels the complexities of the human experience while intertwining emotions such as love, deceit, and resilience. As the characters are brought to life through striking visual and psychological depth, it is evident that Fulci's remarkable attention to detail results in an astounding sense of reality.

My college theater just had a special screening last night of this film. I have got to say that I think everyone was impressed with how good this movie was. Though, my roommate didn't care for it but he's not into horror movies anyway and just went to see if Paris Hilton can act. By the way, if you're worried about that, don't be. I'm not exactly one of her fans, but I must be honest and say she was pretty good and she has the best death scene. Overall, all the actor's were very good.

Like some people here, I love/loved Stingers! In Norway it got aired a lot later. That also means that we are in the 176th episode. (yea, that's right) I have to say that I really love Stingers! It can make me cry, laugh, smile and so on. I think I'm going to die the day we reach episode number 192. Stingers might be the on series(except from Grey's Anatomy) that I really watch! The actors are amazing! Especially Jacinta Stapleton! Personallly I think she is one of the best access we have!

That 's right . Ohwon ( the painter and the main character ) is an exceptional person . What strikes me the most about him is his incredible artistic talent and insatiable passion for painting. Despite facing numerous hardships in his life, Ohwon's determination to create astounding masterpieces remains unshaken. Throughout the story, his unwavering commitment to art acts as his solace and savior in tough times, showcasing the immense power of creative expression. While his life's journey might be filled with pain, chaos, and upheaval, his remarkable resilience and unwavering devotion to art ultimately help Ohwon achieve unparalleled recognition and appreciation.

This early film from future goremeister Lucio Fulci is a very good addition to the giallo sub-genre. Set in rural Italy, there is a serial killer of children at large. Add to the mix an array of characters familiar to fans of giallo cinema  a madwoman, a newspaper reporter, ineffectual police, a sexy siren, a priest, a mute girl, a mentally-retarded loner etc. This is one of the best Italian thrillers of the early 70's.Unusually for a giallo, the victims in this case are young boys, which makes a change from the more typical women in peril angle.

Has the proliferation of relatively high quality shows on the proliferating TV networks made it possible for people to produce shows with limited resources and lower budgets? Absolutely, the golden age of television we're experiencing is changing the landscape, fostering creativity and diversity in content. Smaller production companies, niche networks, and streaming platforms provide an opportunity for fresh, experimental projects and storytelling formats. As a result, this generates room for ambitious newcomers to break into the industry and make innovative shows accessible to viewers who would not typically engage with such content.

Buddy Holly was a pioneer and victim of the early days of rock 'n ' roll . The young singer/songwriter from Lubbock, Texas, quickly rose to fame with his signature blend of country, rhythm, and blues that would influence generations of musicians to come. His distinctive look, characterized by thick black-rimmed glasses and a Fender Stratocaster guitar, became synonymous with his brand of cool yet innocent rebellion. Sadly, Holly's promising career was cut short when he died in a tragic plane crash at the age of 22, alongside fellow musicians Ritchie Valens and J.P. "The Big Bopper" Richardson.

it 's a good watch if u have time - deals with three friends who get into a needless bar fight that leaves them with legal and emotional consequences. As they navigate the aftermath, each friend deals with the guilt and embarrassment in their own unique way. Throughout the movie, viewers witness the strength of their bond and how this particular incident turns out to be a turning point in their friendship. The film takes a sincere look at the meaning of camaraderie and how trivial misunderstandings can snowball into major conflicts. Along with unexpected twists and dark humor, this well-crafted story keeps you hooked until the very end.

This series has a lot going for it with beautiful footage of the some of the most impressive underwater environments on this planet. Being a staggering five years in the making, one would be hard-pressed to expect any less. I did get the impression that some scenes from the first episode where repeated in the latter ones, which is naturally only a minor gripe.David Attenborough is great as a narrator and comments are informative, leaving enough room for one's imagination, and well spaced out, so that viewers get plenty of time to reflect upon the breathtaking imagery.

These critics need to find a new job!!! This movie is based on a TRUE STORY, which has made history. It illustrates beautifully how even in the mist of war and tragedy love can conquer all. The breathtaking Chephallonia of Greece has captured my heart and soul as if I too were there. The Blue eyed Cage & the delightful Cruz were amazing! Together they perfectly portrayed how a Mediterranean couple can only become closer in the time of war. This movie will touch your heart like it did mine you must go see it!!! !

I've commented once on this Chucky great, but I had to do it again to say some things about the film, when I first saw it in a great balcony in a great theater. The film was a lot of fun in the theater and my first Chucky film ever in a theater, and that was a special moment for me, because I cherish Chucky. The other horror villains are referenced with GREAT COOLNESS!!! And the gore was shockingly great! The scene where the gay kid gets nailed by the truck was amazingly cheerful!

Is this a good movie? It's hard to say -- but in 1953, for many people, it was a remarkably effective movie, suspenseful, scary and then, amazingly, actually touching when "the old gentleman" meets his unhappy death at the end of the movie.Yes, what lurks in the Maze turns out to be something of a surprise and, for a lot of people, a hilarious one. But the basic idea (ontogeny recapitulates phylogeny) was a very real one at the time the book was written, and does have some basis in fact.

Captain Corelli's Mandolin is one of Nicolas Cage's better films. He turns a fine performance as the title character. This is a romance set against the backdrop of a worn torn island. John Hurt's character gives his daughter, played beautifully by Penelope Cruz, some honest advice about love. This movie doesn't have the fault of being completely predictable. This movie also allows Cruz to turn in a performance as a strong woman who knows her own mind and heart. Once the film warms up beyond the opening sequence this film keep you focused on it.

I saw this film at the Seattle International Film Festival in a full house of avid movie buffs and Indian ex-pats. The film is amazingly beautiful and smooth flowing for a first film. The direction is self assured, especially with locals who were recruited on the fly for extras and bit parts. While the plot and story line is elementary to nonexistent, the pleasures of watching the performances and scenery offset the lack. The soundtrack to this film is a big attraction to world music lovers. If you want to see what can be done in 45 days, with a different location every day, check out Hari Om for inspiration.

SHOWTIME is a mess, but it's an entertaining mess. The plot is forgettable, the satire is lightweight and the action sequences, though well-staged, aren't that exciting. But I laughed. A lot. Credit goes to the inspired pairing of De Niro and Murphy. They have great chemistry. Murphy delivers the one-liners, De Niro cracks us up with a look or grimace. This movie will get a RUSH HOUR-like reception from the critics. Don't listen to them. If you're a fan of De Niro or Murphy, you're going to enjoy this movie.

When I saw this film at a festival years ago I was very impressed and I started to looking for it. Nothing to do, not in the cinemas, nor on DVD neither on Blue ray. Absolutely nothing!!! How it's possible this could really happen??? The direction is IMPECCABLE, the story is intriguing and has been filmed in a very original way the music it's perfect and James Franco is hot as hell!! !Please release this master piece and allow it to have it's proper life!!!!!!!!!!

Who could have thought a non-disabled actor could act so realistically and immensely powerfully as a disabled person in a film? This breakthrough performance not only showcases the immense talent and versatility of the actor but also highlights the transformative power of art in allowing audiences to empathize with diverse experiences. It also sparks a broader discussion around representation in the media, questioning if able-bodied actors should assume disabled roles. Nonetheless, this groundbreaking portrayal signifies a critical cultural moment, sensitively and masterfully shedding light on a perspective often underrepresented or misrepresented on screen, opening new avenues for inclusive storytelling in cinema.

It amazes me that production companies will sue because of reproductions they will not supply . I 've been looking for certain films or television shows that are not available for purchase or streaming, yet I've found fan-made copies or edits available online. While I understand that these companies are concerned with potential revenue losses, they fail to realize the market they are missing by not offering legal access to these productions. The demand clearly exists and instead of stifling fan enthusiasm with legal threats, production companies should find ways to tap into these audiences and monetize these older or rare pieces of content.

The very few reviews I could find online of Barnens ö really do not do it justice. I read them all before ordering the DVD, but for some reason I ordered it anyway. I regretted it almost immediately, but the order had already gone through so I couldn't cancel it. I'm very glad now that I couldn't. It's an extraordinary movie.I won't give a synopsis of the plot, because other reviewers have already done that. But I will say that I don't understand comments that it's bleak, shocking, weird, clinical, depressing or pornographic.

I 'm not a huge fan of Lucio Fulci 's films . Most of his 80s gore films had their moments of shocking visuals and creativity, but many also fell short in terms of storytelling and coherence. However, with that said, there are some hidden gems that showcase Fulci's true talent as a director. Among these standout works, you'll find more atmospheric and unsettling horror, such as "The Beyond" and "House by the Cemetery," which do not solely rely on gore to make an impact.

It's Showtime! Showtime is simply a bump in Eddie Murphy and Robert DeNiro's careers. It's an entertaining movie and a guilty pleasure but not quite up to the actors' standards, especially not Robert's. Showtime is directed by Tom Dey and features some small roles from guys like William Shatner and Mos Def.Showtime is about two very different cops, Mitch Preston (DeNiro) and Trey Sellars (Murphy). One takes work seriously in a low profile, quiet manner while the other is more easy-going and wants to have more fun than felons in his back seat.

it's a great movie for the whole family. i don't think many people have seen it cause i ask people and they say that they've never heard of it before. Sophie Heyman is my aunt's sister in law. my favorite scene is the whole movie i can't even pick a favorite scene. my favorite character is Hubert because he is a funny yet smart dog. if someone hasn't seen it they are missing out on a great adventure. i've only seen it cause my aunt is related to Sophie and she got a copy from her.

This is sweet . The actress who played the nurse with the gonzongas is the same actress who plays Elvira in the cult classic horror movie series. It is interesting to see how versatile she is in her roles, bringing something unique to each character she portrays. From flaunting her sultry charm as Elvira, the campy vampy mistress of the night, to being the charismatic, energetic nurse with gonzongas, the actress truly embodies the spirit of transformation in cinema. No wonder her acting prowess, magnetic appeal, and contribution to popular culture remain etched in our hearts and memories even to this day.

Great movie . Post-apocalyptic films kick ass . This one is no exception . Kept up the pace and interest throughout, with an engaging storyline and dynamic characters that truly bring the ravaged world to life. Intense action scenes seamlessly blend with emotional moments, providing an authentic sense of the desperation these survivors experience in a dystopian society. The cinematography brilliantly captures the stark landscapes, adding an eerie beauty to the desolate setting. Additionally, the director and screenwriters demonstrate their expertise in drawing the audience in and evoking deep emotion while propelling the narrative forward. A thrilling, immersive cinematic experience that shouldn't be missed!

I usually give horror films around 6/10 , but this one caught my eye . House of Wax was by far the most terrifying and intriguing horror movie I have seen in a while. With a gripping storyline and top-notch acting, it kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. The chilling atmosphere and the excellent use of visual effects truly elevated this film beyond my expectations. Instead of relying solely on gore and jump scares, it skillfully combined psychological tension with well-paced action to deliver a spine-chilling masterpiece. Consequently, I rate House of Wax a solid 9/10 – a must-watch for horror enthusiasts.

As I have said before , I am NOT a fan of Tweety . He 's just so aggravating I cannot help but cringe whenever I see him on the screen. It's a shame too because Looney Tunes has so many great characters like Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck who possess wit and charm, and Tweety just sticks out like a sore thumb among them. Perhaps it's because I find his voice grating, or because his perpetual victim status constantly demands attention, Tweety lacks any of the memorable or redeeming qualities of the others.

WTF ! ! Do any of his books/movies end in a happy ending ? ? The Notebook was good ... OMG, I know, right? It seems like Nicholas Sparks loves to give us major emotional rollercoasters with all those heartbreaking plots! While The Notebook does have a bittersweet, satisfying conclusion, I feel like most of his other works like A Walk to Remember and Dear John often end with such tragic twists! Honestly, his novels and the movies adapted from them should come with a tissue box because they never fail to make us shed tears!

Duchess and her three kittens are enjoying the high life with their devoted human mistress until the wicked butler Edgar, with his eyes on a big inheritance, decides to dope them and get them out of the picture. How can these fragile creatures cope in the unfamiliar countryside and the meaner streets of Paris? Only by meeting the irrepressible alley cat O'Malley, a rough diamond with romance in his heart. After they get a taste of the wide dangerous world, he guides them home, and Edgar gets his just desserts at the wrong end of a horse.

My Architect is a great film about Nathaniel Kahn's search for himself via the legacy of his famous Architect father, Louis Kahn, dead since 1974. The film builds slowly, but perfectly, and what starts out as a seemingly lost fortysomething's identity crisis unfolds into a beautiful tale with much deeper meaning with regard to the importance of love, loss, family and perhaps more importantly, our life's work.I had never heard of Louis Kahn prior to this film, although I was vaguely familiar with some of his work.

`` Showtime '' is a funny film starring funnymen Robert DeNiro ( Meet the Parents , A Bronx Tale ) and Eddie Murphy (Coming to America, Beverly Hills Cop). In this action-comedy, DeNiro plays a grizzled, no-nonsense detective forced to team up with Murphy, an ambitious but bumbling cop hungry for stardom. Together, they join a reality TV show documenting their crime-fighting adventures, often clashing with hilariously unpredictable results. Directed by Tom Dey, "Showtime" delivers a potent mix of fast-paced action, witty banter, and uproarious situational comedy.

I really enjoyed this film, it definitely keeps you on the edge of your seat. It was very well directed. I think it was important that they showed the other couple's life as well as Terry and Bobbys and show them as people with emotions. As this film needed to show Bobby as a cold and vindictive person.I agree with another review it was sick love, not true love. He didn't need to go to great lengths as murder to give his wife a baby. He should have been honest with her and told her that he was sterile and decide to adopt a baby together.

As many of today 's movies are guilty of , the plot is n't exactly stellar , the movie does have some redeeming qualities that manage to make it an entertaining experience for audiences. While relying heavily on CGI and special effects to capture viewer attention, the filmmakers managed to blend humor and witty dialogue amidst all the high-octane action sequences. Although the cast isn't filled with A-list talent, their chemistry is undeniable, giving a convincing portrayal of the character dynamics. The movie won't be remembered as a cinematic masterpiece, but it surely delivers enough thrills and laughs to keep moviegoers satisfied.

This is one of those movies where I just want to move my feet and dance around the house . This energetic and exuberant film truly captures the essence of foot-tapping music and unforgettable dance sequences. The entire production team has gone all out, giving the audience the delightful and uplifting feeling that music can invoke. This contagiously lively cinematic experience seamlessly encourages everyone to tap into their inner dancer, bop to the beats, and perform unapologetically wild dance moves. Each choreography piece displayed on the screen sets one's heart racing, and it becomes absolutely impossible to resist jumping around the room in jubilant celebration.

This is probably my favourite TV show ever . I love all the characters , especially Alex , who is such a dynamic and intriguing person. Every episode has an enthralling storyline that never fails to captivate my attention, leaving me eager to watch more. The mixture of drama, humor, and twists make it stand out from other shows, ensuring a fresh and enjoyable experience each time. Moreover, the character development throughout the series is incredibly well-written and I've grown attached to all of them. Even the side characters provide a depth and charm to the show, adding that extra layer of perfection.

When I was 10 ( currently 14 ) , I vowed to never see a movie that I knew would make me cry. This decision stemmed from a particularly traumatic experience where I ended up bawling in front of my friends at the movies. It was a painfully embarrassing incident that caused relentless teasing. But last week, as I reluctantly agreed to watch a heartfelt drama with my friends, I realized I was limiting my experiences by actively avoiding emotions. As the tears welled up and my friends gently nudged me with sympathetic smiles, I found a newfound appreciation for these kinds of films and ultimately, self-acceptance.

I 've read a lot of reviews about Showtime on IMDb and many seem to miss the mark . I 've noticed that people often compare it to more established streaming platforms, resulting in biased opinions. However, one needs to appreciate Showtime for its diverse content offering and excellent programming. Though it may not boast the most expansive library or widely-discussed originals, the quality of the available content more than compensates for this. Additionally, Showtime has consistently produced groundbreaking series like "Homeland" and "Dexter" which showcase unique storytelling and depth in their narrative arcs.

This movie is true action at its finest, It doesn't get any better then this. This is one of those movies that you can just kick back and watch some real good non stop shooting and killing plus there are some excellent lines to go along with all of this. My favorite is there is a one bad guy who is breaking into this old couples home and he is stealing a TV or something and he goes right up to them and yells "I will come in here anytime i like!!!" and right before he jumps out the window he yells "Anytime!!!"

This movie is an awesome remake of the original by the same title . The movie was cool , despite the initial skepticism surrounding it, as it successfully managed to preserve the charm and nostalgia of the original while adding new elements that catered to a contemporary audience. The storyline flowed seamlessly, incorporating both action-packed scenes and unexpected plot twists, which made it hard for viewers to take their eyes off the screen. Brilliant performances by the ensemble cast and exceptional direction combined to bring this movie to life, and it definitely deserves recognition for bringing new energy and dynamics to the story of the cult classic.

When his elderly mother Emily ( Jeanne Bates ) is attacked by her lodger Nestor Duvalier ( Brion James ) , a distraught Daniel (Johnathan Schaech) decides to take matters into his own hands. Against the advice of his girlfriend Sarah (Amanda Plummer), Daniel enlists the help of his childhood friend Leo (Donald Sutherland) to carry out a plot for revenge. As the plan starts to unravel, Daniel soon discovers Nestor's violent past and unspeakable secrets. But his quest for retribution turns into a dark spiral, leading to an explosive confrontation between Daniel, Nestor, and their respective demons.

When I first saw this movie,I also expected "our boys" to be cute,and more like an extended version of the TV show. I didn't "get it" back then. But,years later,at a party YEARS later,at a 70s' type PAR-TAY,where certain substances had been smoked,inhaled,and with plenty of tequila,"HEAD" was on late at night.We watched it,and finally realized what "HEAD" was all about. It spoofed their own show,as shown in one song that called themselves,"a manufactured image".

We saw La Spettatrice last night @ the Chicago International Film Festival & we were both immensely moved by it . The acting was phenomenal, especially by the lead actress whose emotional range truly captivated the audience. The storyline was intricate, delving into the depths of human relationships and the power dynamics at play in various settings. The cinematography was beautifully executed, taking us through the winding streets of Italy, effortlessly transporting us into the characters' world. The heartwarming ending resonated long after the credits rolled. Kudos to the talented director for creating such an exquisite film - it surely deserves more recognition on the global platform.

I was about 14 years old as I saw the musical version of Lost Horizon . I loved the film so much that it ignited my passion for musical theatre. The harmonious blending of enchanting music, spellbinding acting, and riveting storytelling left me completely mesmerized. The journey of the protagonist seeking purpose and identity amidst the mystical city of Shangri-La opened a new world of creativity and inspiration for me. As the melodic notes of the song 'The World is a Circle' echoed, I dreamt of someday being part of such a soul-stirring masterpiece on stage or in the making of the grandeur that a musical holds.

I caught this show a few times when I was young and it was playing tilt , My parents loved it and we would all gather around the TV to watch it together as a family. The combination of humor, action, and quirky characters really brought the show to life and captivated its audience. Each episode kept us laughing and eagerly anticipating what would come next. Now that I'm older, I appreciate even more the talented actors, creative storylines, and ingenious mix of different genres. Watching this show not only takes me on a trip down memory lane, but also highlights the unmatched charm of classic television.

William H. Macy always gives a good performance. He never looks lazy and never seems like he'd rather be somewhere else. In short, he's what more actors should be like. "A Slight Case of Murder" is directed by Steven Schachter, who went on to do two more great films with Macy (Door to Door, The Wool Cap).Television movies have long been a dump of overdone acting, poor cinematography, and sub-par scripting. That's why it's so refreshing to see a TV movie that does exactly what it's sort of film was created for.

This is a good film for die-hard Chucky fans . Okay I 'm sure it 's not as good as the original "Child's Play," but it definitely brings back the nostalgic terror that Chucky instills in everyone's hearts. The plot remains engaging throughout, combining slasher thrills with clever, dark humor. As always, the film is elevated by Brad Dourif's incredible voice work as the iconic Chucky. While newcomers to the franchise might find some aspects outdated or campy, die-hard fans will surely appreciate the homage to classic Chucky tropes, as well as a few new twists thrown in for good measure.

Forget Easy Rider - Head is THE film about the 1960s.Almost laugh : as the Monkees reduce their entire career to a psychedelic farce in this groundbreaking movie that will blow your mind. Directed by Bob Rafelson and co-written by a young Jack Nicholson, this anti-establishment gem unapologetically dismantles the manufactured pop image of the Monkees, showcasing their underrated talents while addressing the Vietnam War, materialism, and politics of the era. Both irreverent and clever, Head delves into the consciousness of the time through a wild, fragmented narrative interspersed with offbeat musical numbers, ultimately celebrating the bizarre humor and boundless creativity of the 60s.

At one time `Buddy Cop' movies ruled the box office. It seemed that every summer flocks of Beverly Hills Cop wannabes descended on our nation's theaters. Not any more. Lately the gusher has dried to barely a trickle. The drought has eased a bit recently with the release of Showtime, a movie that is a genuinely funny and consistently entertaining example of the genre.Mitch Preston is a dedicated cop. He's not a Dirty Harry type by any means. He's just incredibly focused professional who's completely intolerant of anything that gets in the way of the performance of his dutieslike, say, a T.V.

I really loved this movie and have spent several years trying to get it. It is just not available and it has not been on TV for many many years. I enjoyed it and the songs because it had something different to say and made you think how every person looks at something from different prespectives. Also we often don't appreciate something we have till it is no longer there.My 12 year old daughter just discoverd the music and is entranced with some of the songs. Someday I hope to get a copy of the film so she can have an opportunity to view it.

A well written screenplay. A moving story showing the middle class English at it's best. Some great acting by Tom Wilkinson and Emily Watson. Tom Wilkinson is one of Britain's best actors. He knows how to be subtle and honest. Emily Watson is an actress I was not familiar with, but to her credit she does a great job of playing the ****** wife. The director, Julian Fellowes did not succumb to the typical Hollywood gimmicks to give the film some meaty storyline. It has not over dramatized it's portrayal of the English middle class.

I saw this movie on it 's opening night , and enjoyed it . I probably would have enjoyed it even more if it weren't for the excessively hyped up trailers and spoilers that I couldn't avoid. Despite this, the movie exceeded my expectations, and I believe the story plot, characterization, and visual effects were stunning. The chemistry among the actors was incredible, bringing authenticity to their characters, while the soundtrack perfectly complemented every scene. The action-packed sequences and moments of comic relief contributed to an overall satisfying and thrilling movie experience.

An interesting look at the immigrant experience , told as a fable with some very weird imagery.I got drawn to this unique tale because it took me on a fascinating journey that unfolded the lives and perspectives of various immigrants, all interwoven within the framework of an enchanting fable. The unconventional mix of mystical elements and bizarre visuals provided a refreshing contrast against the realities faced by these diverse individuals in their pursuit of a better life. The author brilliantly used the allegorical nature of the story to shed light on some prevalent cultural issues that are experienced by immigrants worldwide.

probably the best horror movie in 5 years.. there's been lame remakes, attempts to make you scared (when all they make you do is walk out of the theater) and movies that just shouldn't have been made. but this one is worth it. the only reason i didn't give it a 10 is because Paris Hilton is in it (but her death scene makes up for it, believe me)....so here they are.. the SPOILERS of all the death scenes in the movie..1. my favorite death scene ever - Paris Hilton's!

They Made Me a Criminal is a remake of an earlier Warner Brothers film , The Life of Jimmy Dolan They Made Me a Criminal, released in 1939, is a drama and crime film that revolves around the protagonist, a falsely accused man on the run from the law, inspired by the storyline of the earlier Warner Brothers film The Life of Jimmy Dolan from 1933. Like Jimmy Dolan, the main character of the remake, Johnny Bradfield (played by John Garfield), finds himself falsely accused of a heinous crime after the sleazy lifestyle he'd fallen into led to unforeseen tragedies.

I saw this movie when it first came out in 1973 and loved it. Since then I've searched for a video but never found it until now, 33 years later, when I ordered it from Moviehunter. Sorry to say it doesn't hold up. This glamourized version just can't rise up to the 1937 production level. I love Burt Bacharach's musical score, that is if listend to by itself, and I even bought a CD of it, but for my taste it doesn't lend itself well to this mysterious and compelling story. Just doesn't fit.

This film , like much of their music , is either underrated or unnoticed by the casual observer . It delivers a unique and immersive experience that is both visually and audibly captivating. While it may not be tailored to please everyone, those who give it a chance will find themselves delving deeper into the story and becoming more appreciative of the intricate layers present in both its cinematography and its score. Although its subtle intricacies can make the overall impact harder to grasp for some, the movie remains an essential and unmissable piece for dedicated fans, art aficionados and discerning viewers seeking unconventional narratives and innovative visual interpretations.

I saw a sneak preview of this Tuesday night with a group of friends and we had a blast! After seeing sneak peaks for BOOGEYMAN (Horrible! 3/10) and Amityville Remake (so-so 6/10) I enjoyed this a lot more! As seen in the trailer, one knock I had was believing that a whole town could be "forgotten" but this is a cheesy popcorn horror movie so I accept it for what it is.My only major complaint is I assumed Paris Hilton would touch wax or get dipped etc. and moan "that's hot" but they didn't do that (how could they resist???

this is a teen movie and while u watch it expect some nonsensical stuff added here and there but overall it's a fun and entertaining experience that captures the essence of adolescent life. As with most teen flicks, you'll find a blend of clichéd high school stereotypes, cheesy yet lovable romances, and comical misunderstandings mixed into the plot. You'll definitely roll your eyes at the occasionally exaggerated humor and unbelievable antics, but at the end of the day, you can't help but enjoy this lighthearted, feel-good journey of growing up.

Death Wish 3 is exactly what a bad movie should be . Terrible acting ! Implausible scenerios ! Ridiculous death scenes! And yet, it has an irresistible charm that makes it an undeniable cult classic. In this outrageous installment of the Death Wish series, Charles Bronson returns as the vigilante, Paul Kersey, facing an array of dangerous gangs terrorizing his New York City neighborhood. Loaded with unintentional hilarity, over-the-top violence, and gloriously absurd dialogues, Death Wish 3 serves as a perfect reminder that cinema doesn't always need to take itself too seriously.

Has the proliferation of relatively high quality shows on the proliferating TV networks made it possible for people to produce, direct, finance and/or star in their own films who might otherwise not have been able to? Is that a good thing? This film does not answer the latter question either way, but it does appear that without Curb, Jeff Garlin would not have been able to make I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With. Like most new producers/directors, Jeff Garlin's independent piece heaves a heavily more sensitive sigh than the vehicle he is primarily known for (Curb).

A labor of love. Each frame is picture perfect and grabs you. Then the sheer emotion and story-telling take you through a dream that stays with you long after the movie. The director gets your heart and leads it through 100 minutes of visual poetry. You are a part of the emotional ride of the characters. I have seen this movie at 2 festivals and it got with standing ovations at every showing. The remarkable story-telling transcends nationality and language and I felt I was a part of the drama unfolding before me. The casting is as perfect as one can get.

This film was one of three that were later combined by Chapin into a compilation that was released to theaters in the late 1950s under the title "The Chaplin Review".This was an odd film in some ways because later in life, Chaplin was anti-war and his movies stressed peace and brotherhood. This film, in contrast, is a propaganda comedy meant to bolster the US efforts in WWI. It's truly odd to see Charlie as the "super soldier" who single-handedly captures 13 Germans, casually and coolly shoots several Germans in mere seconds as a marksman and then goes behind enemy lines to try to capture the Kaiser himself!

I believe that this is one of Elizabeth Montgomery 's best performances in a movie , and I have seen almost all of her works. In this particular film, Elizabeth Montgomery brilliantly portrays a character filled with complexity, effortlessly depicting various emotions with grace and authenticity. She carries the weight of the entire story on her shoulders and pulls off a genuinely compelling role, commanding the audience's attention from the very beginning. Her versatile acting and expressive subtlety elevate the quality of the film and help the other cast members rise to the challenge.

Let me clarify that. This is not a "good movie", but I am so glad it is out there, I am so glad I saw it, and for the role that it plays in my DVD collection, it is sublime. It is the ultimate PG-13 romp, it is college as we imagine it will be when we're freshmen in high school, it requires so much suspension of disbelief that it may as well be taking place on Mars. It is so wholesome that even when it tries to be dirty it wouldn't make your grandmother uncomfortable.

Enchanting . The best time to see this movie is sometime when unhappy or sad . It 's all just so whimsical and heartwarming that it effortlessly lifts your spirits and transports you to a world full of wonder and magic. The characters are so lovable and engaging that they feel like friends on this beautiful journey. The cinematography is captivating, leaving a vivid visual feast for the eyes. With its feel-good message and perfectly timed comic moments, the film acts as a comforting embrace, ensuring that your worries will melt away by the time the end credits roll.

As the mom of a 3 year old and a 2 year old, I adore AristoCats. It is a movie that contains no double-entendres, no almost-swear words like heck or darn, no parents who are functional idiots, and no crotch-smashing or flatulence jokes that are so prevalent in even the "best" kids movies these days. The story line is sweet and interesting. The music is great. The love story is quite romantic. The kittens are adorable, and the various other characters are unique and attention-capturing. The action is simple and not overwhelming or confusing.

Sacha Baron Cohen is a genius. And this movie is good! Although the film doesn't nearly reach the quality of the tv-show, it's still very funny and has some seriously wicked moments! I've liked Ali G since the first time I saw the material from the show. I think he's one of the best comedy characters of all time.. up there with say, Peter Dragon ("Action") and The Blues Brothers. Biggest surprise with this film was that they've actually got some serious actors to do it (Dance and Gambon).

Jenny Lewis plays an awkward girl called Jade . She smokes and drinks . She does n't have a lot of friends, as she keeps to herself and is more comfortable with solitude. Most people see her as a weird outsider, and gossip constantly follows her. One day, at her after-school job at the local bookstore, she stumbles upon a magical book that transports her to a parallel universe. This new world presents her with thrilling adventures and new friends that accept her quirks, celebrating her for being her unique self. This transformative journey empowers Jade, teaching her how to embrace her oddities and stand up against the bullies.

This is NOT the masterpiece that is Snow White , Cinderella , or Bambi , but it IS a very entertaining and charming addition to Disney's collection of animated classics. The movie stands strong with its endearing characters, a heartfelt story, and stunning animation that immerses the audience in its colorful world. With themes such as courage, friendship, and acceptance woven through its enchanting narrative, the film appeals to both children and adults alike, imparting valuable life lessons to cherish for years to come. The captivating soundtrack features memorable melodies and cleverly-crafted lyrics, truly a testament to the exceptional musical and creative talents involved.

I saw this movie on late night TV out of Buffalo about 30 years ago and I 'm dying to know its title. The plot revolves around a small group of people stranded in a haunted house, where a malevolent presence torments them. As they start delving into the house's tragic past, they discover its terrifying connection to the occult. This low-budget horror gem features convincing performances, along with masterfully constructed tension and atmosphere. It scared me out of my wits, and left an indelible mark on my young mind. Does anyone else remember watching this obscure horror classic on TV or recall its title?

Garlin outdoes himself as writer-director-actor in his indie production about a big guy ( Garlin ) wandering around Chicago with a camera, capturing life's absurd moments. He encounters various eccentric characters, highlighting the city's unique cultural mosaic. The protagonist struggles with personal issues, feeling lost in the urban jungle, finding solace in humor and wit. Garlin delivers a masterful, multidimensional performance that keeps the audience engaged, resonating with their own emotional vulnerabilities. Showcasing genuine comedic prowess and a deft ability to inject heartfelt insights into daily moments, Garlin has crafted an entertaining and introspective cinematic gem.

Before I forget, let me say the artwork in here is outstanding. From garbage cans to the huge cruise ship, the drawings are beautifully done. If this wasn't animated, critics would be lauding the "direction" in here, because it's really good.To the story: Sylvester is picking through the garbage at the shipyards but the pickins' are slim. While brooding at the dock next to a big ship, in a porthole he spots Tweety in his cage. Tweety spots him, too, and you know his first comment - the same one he always makes when he spots the cat.

This movie got better with time . I ca n't believe that it has been forty years since I saw it for the first time, but it truly seems to age like a fine wine. The plot, once considered cheesy and dated, now takes on a classic, timeless feel. The cinematography and special effects that were cutting-edge back in the day are still enjoyable and a testament to how groundbreaking they were at the time. As the years go on, I have developed an even deeper appreciation for the movie's skilled storytelling, character development, and raw emotions.

The Snowqueen is one of the best love stories I have ever seen : much better and deeper than Luhrman 's Romeo and Juliet, with all due respect. In The Snowqueen, the intertwining of elements such as vulnerability and devotion amplifies the very essence of love, unlike traditional portrayals which rely heavily on overly romanticized moments. What sets this movie apart is its exceptional ability to depict raw human emotions, interwoven with evocative themes of love, sacrifice, and tragedy. As you witness the depth of these emotions and experiences unfold on screen, the film will effortlessly leave an everlasting impact on the viewer's heart and soul.

If you are looking for a phony Hollywood action movie, this won't be one for you. If the Truth is what you seek, rent or buy this. From a true story, the movie attempts to capture the heart of what was/is happening in South Africa (and many other places).For historical knowledge, this rates up there with stories such as "The Pianist," "Schindler's List" or "Nuremberg." Millions of people today have no clue what apartheid is or that it even exists. This movie may help them learn, and may even help them dig deeper.

The movie is excellent. Acting, cinematography, direction and music are spellbinding. It seems to me that the reason so many give the movie a low score is because of the devotion they have to the original, 1937 version starring Ronald Coleman. That movie - for good reason! - engendered an unbelievable level of commitment. From talking with people who saw the original when it first came out, I believe the impact was something akin to the first "Starwars" movie in modern times. I have seen it. It was and is wonderful.

Who could have thought a non-disabled actor could act so realistically and immensely powerfully as a disabled person in a film? Probably someone. But no-one, truly no-one, could ever compare their expectations with the amazingly emotive and powerful performance given by the two actors in this film.Michael (Steven Robertson) lives in a home for disabled people. He has Cerebral Paulsy, and as shown to us right at the beginning, he has huge trouble communicating. So it truly is a lifeline when fellow disabled member Rory (James McAvoy) who can speak normally, understands him.

Buddy Holly was a pioneer and victim of the early days of rock 'n' roll. The young singer/songwriter from Lubbock, Texas left his mark on the template of modern music. Inspired by Elvis Presley, Holly would spend a lot of time fighting the system in order to get his rock-a-billy sound recorded. Before his untimely death, he was mixing lush strings with be-bop rhythms. Holly would take his place with Presley, Chuck Berry, Jerry Lee Lewis and Ricky Nelson as the voices of teenage angst.This easy to watch bio is not without flaws.

This was a riveting film , one that really drew me in . I 'm a big fan of William Dafoe and his exceptional talent, so his incredible performance in the lead role wasn't surprising, yet it completely blew me away. The film beautifully intertwined raw emotions and thought-provoking scenes, providing not just entertainment, but also depth that one rarely finds in movies these days. The director skillfully kept the momentum throughout, allowing each character's development to grow while unfolding the gripping storyline. The ending left me emotionally satiated, making this film an extraordinary cinematic experience I'll definitely watch again.

Another great Tom Wilkinson performance punctuates `` Separate Lies , '' a 2005 film also starring Emily Watson , Linda Bassett, and Rupert Everett. Directed by Julian Fellowes, this British drama is a powerful adaptation of Nigel Balchin's novel, "A Way Through the Wood." Wilkinson delivers a captivating portrayal of a reserved London lawyer, whose life gets turned upside down after discovering his wife's involvement in a mysterious hit-and-run accident. The complex, intertwined relationships that unfold paint a deep exploration of lies, loyalty, and guilt among the characters.

I've got to say it. Gary Busey saved this film. If it were not for his fine acting talents this film would have been sub par. I recommend the film but just barely.The biggest difficulty with the film is its broad disregard for historical, geographical and physical accuracy. For example, why is Lubbock green and hilly? How come Buddy's producer Petty ignored? Where are the daily trips to the Clovis, New Mexico studio? Why is Nashville treated as a racist hate camp out to destroy the Holly sound?

I watch the show every day and it is very entertaining . It provides updates of tech news , video game releases, gadget reviews, and industry events in a concise and engaging manner. The hosts are knowledgeable and have a great sense of humor, making the viewing experience enjoyable for both beginners and tech enthusiasts alike. The show covers a wide range of topics, ensuring there's something for everyone. It also regularly features interviews with experts, which adds credibility and depth to the discussions. All in all, this show is a valuable resource for anyone looking to stay informed and entertained in the constantly-evolving world of technology.

One of the most magnificent movies ever made. The acting of Charles Buchinski (later known as Bronson) is simply outstanding. This is the crown on the career of director Winner, who himself was often quoted saying this was his masterpiece. The plot has been copied many times, but it's never been topped. Wildey J. Moore, the gun manufacturer, many times claimed his brand's growth since the mid 80s can be fully credited to DW3, and rightly so. This is not just a movie, this is art that many generations will admire and appreciate.

Lucio Fulci 's `` Do n't Torture a Duckling '' paints an exceptionally unflattering portrait of small-town Sicily plagued by a series of brutal child murders. This gritty film delves into the superstitious underbelly of this seemingly tranquil locale, as residents desperately look for a culprit among witchcraft practitioners and mentally challenged individuals. Through a combination of atmospheric cinematography, gruesome violence, and social critique, Fulci's disquieting exploration of fanaticism and hysteria unmasks the depths of inhumanity capable of stemming from paranoia and scapegoating, demonstrating how hidden vices within even the most picturesque rural community can reveal chilling depravity when a series of horrifying events unravel.

He did one at Christmas to try and bring back a number one song, and now the terrific Justin Lee Collins wanted to reunite the cast members and maybe some crew of one of his favourite TV shows as a kid, The A-Team. The only member he wouldn't be able to get was the late great George Peppard who played main character Col. John "Hannibal" Smith, but he did get some kind of psychic to try and help. He did manage to reunite all members including Dirk Benedict (Lt. Templeton "Faceman" Peck #2) who went to Celebrity Big Brother in 2007, Dwight Schultz (Capt.

Considering it's basically low-budget cast, this is a surprisingly good flick about the life and death of rock pioneer Buddy Holly. Gary Busey stars as Holly, who was one of the first to use an electric guitar for pretty much all his music. Backed up by his Crickets, Holly had a string of hits and became a bona fide star before his death in a plane crash along with Richie Valens and The Big Bopper. The film follows his rise to stardom, marriage to his sweetheart and eventual death. I like this film and believe that you will too.

I don't see that much wrong with this movie. Granted, the principal singers might not be Luciano Pavarotti and Maria Callas, but they can certainly carry a tune. Burt Bacharach and Hal David are talented songwriters and I happen to love their songs, especially "The World Is A Circle", "The Things That I Will Not Miss", and "Question Me An Answer". Some people claim that Hermes Pan's choreography is ghastly and that the snowy mountain sets look as if they were made of plastic; I disagree on both counts.

If we could have `` Separate Tables , '' why not `` Separate Lies . `` This becomes somewhat involved as the intricate webs of lies in our daily lives often converge at specific instances, with emotions running high and the search for truth more crucial than ever. "Separate Lies" portrays the story of individuals carefully balancing the different aspects of their lives, often colliding with one another, unveiling unforeseen consequences. Through moments of intense revelation, the seemingly insurmountable barriers among the characters slowly crumble, with their meticulously crafted deceit no longer effective.

I think that this short TV series, was absolutely wonderful, and gave both a in-depth and clear explanation of everything that was on the screen at the given time. This was by far David Attenborough at his best. I personally thought this was one of the best documentaries in the past decade. This is definitely worth peoples money!I also found the bit about the abyss and deep water the most fascinating and interesting part. It was incredible to find out that the 'Blue planet' team discovered more than 10 new species of underwater life!

I've been looking forward to seeing this film ever since I first caught the trailer, and I'm so glad now that I have. It's truly a wonderful film. The actors are superb, the writing is fresh and real, the whole thing was just spot-on. I love James McAvoy in this, and I can't wait to see him in "The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe" movie this December. Romola Garai is wonderful too. Be sure to check her out in "I Capture the Castle" or "Nicholas Nickleby," two of my favorite films.

I always liked listening to Buddy Holly and felt a real loss when he was killed at a young age in the infamous plane crash back in 1959. As a pioneer of rock and roll music, his influence has never really faded. The unique blend of rhythm and blues, country and western that Holly infused into his tunes set a precedent for future generations. It's amazing to consider the impact he made during such a short period in the spotlight; one can only imagine what musical masterpieces he would have crafted had he lived a longer life.

The Aristocats is really quite charming, and is rated far too low on IMDb. The songs aren't as memorable as the ones in the Jungle Book, but they weren't bad at all. The animation is really lovely, the best sequence being the landscape of Paris in general. It looked beautiful. This is probably Disney's most relaxing animation I think, and as another reviewer quite rightly said, who doesn't love cats? Another great piece of animation was O' Malley looking into Duchess's eyes, as their romance was so believable while not obvious.

`` Back in the Day '' is an interesting , but flawed effort . Ja Rule stars as Reggie Cooper , a young man who gets caught in the midst of a dangerous world involving crime, drugs, and gang rivalry. In an attempt to escape the clutches of this dangerous lifestyle, Reggie tries to turn a new leaf by joining his high school sweetheart in pursuit of higher education. However, Reggie quickly realizes that completely severing his ties from his old world won't be easy. The tension mounts as old alliances and dangerous enemies threaten not only his dreams of a better future, but also his very existence.

Diora Baird is absolutely hot as hell in this movie. But really all the characters are amazingly fun to watch. (MINOR SPOILERS) As per usual, the main character, B, is the sane one of the bunch. B has this crazy idea to make up his own college when he's rejected from all colleges he applies to. He's known for making fake IDs. so an acceptance letter is no problem.Because B's dad is a hard @$$ and suspicious of this university he's never heard of, B gets his friend Sherman to design a website for the university.

An interesting look at the immigrant experience, told as a fable with some very weird imagery.I got drawn to this movie because it tells of immigrants from Sicily who traveled to America. I imagine much the same as my Grandfather did at that time. Travelling in steerage to provide ballast for the ships, I cannot imagine it was very comfortable, as shown in this film.Laws restricting immigrants existed. I would guess that these laws were more strict on those who came from the Mediterranean and Africa. Immigrants had to be free from contagious diseases or hereditary infirmities.

We loved this movie because it was so entertaining and off beat-- Not your usual Hollywood drivel.My husband had a Blockbuster coupon and passed on a string of new releases of violent Hollywood stuff. He was about to walk out when he saw this and decided to take a chance. There was only one copy -- and with some glitches in the DVD that we finally had to flip to wide screen version and then back to the full screen version to make it stop stalling. But it was worth it. Cathy Bates is so good and she was so perfect for the role.

You know, people who make comedies so often forget it's really ok to be outrageous. Well, not this time. Unconditional Love has it all. Barry Manilow and a dwarf in a movie with Cathy Bates as the romantic lead...and it works. Not only does it work, it works very very well. In fact, I think it's perfect. I laughed so hard I think I hurt myself yet the main characters were all so human, so honest, and so very real. But isn't that where great comedies come from?

I recently saw Blind Spot in Coyoacan , where it drew a huge crowd and some pretty intense discussion . Blind Spot in Coyoacan garnered attention not just because of the riveting plot, but also for the thought-provoking subject matter. It incited insightful debates among the audience as they shared their diverse perspectives on the issues highlighted in the movie. The range of emotions exhibited by the people was palpable; some showed discomfort and intrigue, while others appreciated the unflinching portrayal of social issues. This engaging film was not only a visual treat but also left a lasting impact on the moviegoers and sparked stimulating discourse long after the final credits.

I got some free tickets via the Times to see this little know Irish movie called 'Inside I 'm Dancing I got some free tickets via the Times to see this little known Irish movie called 'Inside I'm Dancing.' Intrigued by the title and excited for an authentic film experience, I invited a few friends and made a movie night out of it. It turned out to be a brilliant tale of two disabled men in Dublin who forge an unlikely friendship as they embark on a liberating journey to challenge the restrictions of their assisted living facility.

What a shame this movie was never released . ( It is now playing on cable . ) I tuned in expecting a captivating plot and riveting performances, but instead found myself utterly disappointed. The storyline was muddled and hard to follow, and the characters lacked depth and nuance. The actors tried their best with the subpar script but were unable to breathe any life into their roles. Perhaps the most redeeming quality of this movie is that its poor execution offers a lesson in how not to make a film. Save yourself the trouble and watch something else – there's no need to suffer through this misstep in filmmaking history.

I know this movie isn't for everyone, and I won't push my opinions on you, but what I have to say is the truth about how many people feel about this movie...It was the best I have ever seen!!! It was soooooooooooooooooo funny, and even though it wasn't the scariest movie I had ever seen, it kept me on the edge of my seat, because I didn't know what was gonna happen next. If you like funny scary movies, you have got to see this one!

What a surprise this film was . I 've seen a good few of Fulci 's horror and zombie flicks and honestly, I was a bit skeptical when I decided to give this one a try. I wasn't sure if Fulci could excel outside of his usual genre, but boy, was I proven wrong. The plot took unexpected turns that kept me engaged from start to finish. Not to mention, the masterful way he blended dark humor with dramatic elements - it genuinely showcased his incredible versatility as a director. The actors' performances were gripping and real, and the cinematography had a unique, eerie ambiance.

You know , people who make comedies so often forget it 's really ok to be outrageous . Well , let me tell you, being outrageous is not just okay, it's essential! Comedy thrives on pushing boundaries, taking risks, and bringing out the absurdity in life's most mundane situations. Laughter is derived from unexpected twists and witty observations that play with societal norms, making it incredibly necessary to go above and beyond the conventions. After all, the world would be such a boring place if everything were mundane and straightforward!

Duchess is a pretty white cat who lives with her three kittens in her wealthy owner's mansion in Paris. When the evil butler hears that the rich old lady is leaving everything in her will to the cats first, the butler is angered, because he wants to get everything first. So he puts them to sleep and abandons them off the side of the road. When the cats wake up, they start on a long trek home. A street wise cat named Thomas O'Malley meets up with them and offers to help them.

I loved this film!! I have been waiting for this film to come out so I could see it. I saw it opening night and loved it, Some people told me that this film wasn't any good and to stay away but I thought it was great. The actors did great and it was scary and made me jump. Paris Hilton did a great job for her first film, everybody is giving her a hard time when she did great and she didn't even have that big of a role. The set was great has it was made of all wax and how it was made.

If you get a chance to get a hold of this lost (for many years) gem, I doubt you will be disappointed.
