PS has an odd blend of social satire and ultra-cool blaxploitation-- even hints of slapstick, but it's so odd that it was not only ahead of it's time, nothing has been seen like it since.I strongly disagree with people who say that the film is dated, especially with Spike Lee's "Bamboozaled" (SP?) a few years back which was a misfire of trying to capture the same message. (Good filmmaking, disjointed script.

Great show! About time a reality TV show comes along that closes generation gaps. Contestants range in ages, some seem old enough to have watched the movie when it first came out. And others, looked so young that perhaps parents or teachers handed down the movie hoping it would touch their lives the way it once touch them. Grease has truly become an American icon. Grease is a fun and entertaining movie in which the young and old can relate to. "You're The One That We Want" is sure to gain even more Grease followers.

I can't say how many times that one line has made me laugh or how often I've described that scene to folks not familiar with this film. I saw it the year it was released, I was 19. I don't think there were a dozen people in that East Village theater that night. For years I thought we were the only ones who saw it. Nice to see here that others found it as hysterical as I had, and see it's lasting value despite the time gone by. Rent it, buy it or steal it.... a must see.

This is a remake of the anime classic from the 80 's , and this one is even better . Featuring stunning animation and compelling storylines, the remake remains true to the original while bringing fresh ideas to the table. New, fully developed characters and immersive world-building leave long-time fans satisfied, while also attracting a new generation of viewers. Engaging arcs capture the audience, whether it's your first time watching or a trip down memory lane. Beautifully crafted battle sequences, emotional growth of characters, and unforgettable friendships culminate in this revamped '80s anime, surpassing its predecessor to be considered a true masterpiece in the world of animation.

No. I'm not kidding with this one. He was a guest reviewer for Entertainment Weekly and gave this movie positive marks. And who can blame him? This is a charming, upbeat, and rather funny Disney movie. Who doesn't love kittens? The music in Ev'rybody Wants To Be A Cat is jamming. It makes me want to snap my fingers or something. Only years later when Cats Don't Dance came out have I seen a movie that was that musically fun. What Aristocats lacks in animation and story, it makes up for in charm.

I first saw The Victim (aka Out Of Contention) well over 25 years ago when I was very young. Being a passionate fan of Bewitched since I was a child, I loved to watch anything that starred Elizabeth Montgomery. This movie was (and still is) a real treat - whether you are a fan of Miss Montgomery's work or not. Elizabeth always shines in her roles, such as her portrayal as the rape victim in A Case Of Rape and as the suspected murderess in The Legend Of Lizzie Borden.

Fantastic Chaplin movie with many memorable moments as Charlie joins the army to fight in WW 1.At first he goes to boot camp, where he has to learn how to handle his rifle and how to walk in line. That's a really funny scene as the tramp is not used to keeping his feet straight!Next thing you know he's in France in a trench. Hilarious scenes here include a starving Charlie eating the cheese of a mousetrap and reading a letter from home over someone's shoulder.When Charlie goes to sleep he finds his bunker all flooded and his roommate snoring.

`` Head '' is a film that has held up well since its original release date in 1968 . The Monkees, a band initially formed for a television show, challenged conventions and successfully transitioned from TV sensations to silver screen stars through this cult classic. "Head" delivers an engaging and often absurd mixture of music, psychedelic visuals, and socio-political satire, reflecting the vibrant counterculture and attitudes of the late 1960s. Driven by catchy songs and an irreverent sense of humor, this experimental comedy encapsulates an era of free-thinking and rebellious expression.

Even after nearly 20 years apart , the original members of Black Sabbath have not lost a thing . In fact, they've only grown stronger as a cohesive unit. Their long-awaited reunion proved that they can still create electrifying music that captures the essence of their groundbreaking early work while demonstrating their matured artistry. Fans who witnessed this remarkable feat appreciated the harmonious combination of dark, aggressive riffs and powerfully melodic lyrics that characterized the band's unique sound. Critics, too, acknowledged the return of one of rock music's most legendary acts.

Despite all the hoopla about THE TROUBLE WITH TRIBBLES episode , THE BALANCE OF TERROR might just be the best episode of the original Star Trek series. The introduction of the mysterious and enigmatic Romulan species, as well as the battle of wits between Captain Kirk and his counterpart, lends to an intriguing and suspenseful plot. Enhanced by themes of war and political allegory, the episode showcases strong character development and thrilling action sequences. Along with THE CITY ON THE EDGE OF FOREVER, these episodes highlight the creative genius and depth that Star Trek, even in its earliest days, provided as it made waves in the sci-fi television genre.

The Buddy Holly Story opens on a shot of a yellow neon moon on the roof of a roller rink The Buddy Holly Story opens on a shot of a yellow neon moon on the roof of a roller rink, casting a warm glow over the bustling scene below. As the camera pans down, we see people of all ages whizzing around the rink, their laughter and excited chatter mingling with the lively tunes of rock and roll filling the air. Among the happy skaters is our protagonist, Buddy, gliding effortlessly with a contagious smile.

Between sweeping, extraordinary scenes within a plethora of Indian locations and a plot which is Bollywood inspired yet grounded in reality, this highly moving film is a must-see for those who love a good romance/adventure. And by this, I mean "good", not a Hollywood or Bollywood easy and contrived happy ending. East meets West in a different take on the buddy film. The performances are inspired and brilliant, the cinematography epic and the plot entertaining, engaging and poignant without a trace of schmaltz or cheap tugging at heartstrings. HARI OM is a sweet film that won't rot your teeth.

In this era when almost everything makes it on to DVD ( I 'm expecting to see the My Mother The Musical: Director's Cut hitting the shelves any day now), it seems as though the archival race is in full swing. This has led to a proliferation of digital treasures, spanning every niche imaginable, filling both online streaming platforms and dusty physical cases. However, amidst the hoard of resurfaced TV series, award-winning documentaries, and gripping original narratives, the question still remains – are these visual time capsules really worth digging into?

"Head" is a film that has held up well since its original release date in 1968. The movie is a complete contradiction of the Monkees image. It presents the Monkees in a way their fans never perceived them; men with real thoughts. Totally controlled by their producers, the Monkees were given the opportunity to tell their side of the story. The film pokes fun at their image, the entertainment industry, and corporate America. The soundtrack contains some of their best music. It's a movie well worth seeing over and over again.

Thanks to the helpfulness of a fellow IMDb member I 've just managed to watch this film for the second time after many years, and I must say it still captivates me as much as it did before. The incredible storytelling, masterful direction, and powerful performances make this a cinematic gem that stays with the viewer long after it's over. It's not very often that a film has such an impact on you, especially upon re-watching it after a lengthy period, but this one proves that great art remains timeless.

Motorama viewers should already by keen on other offbeat b-grade desert-based films such as Bagdad Cafe or Repo Man ( or even Tremors. If that's the case, then Motorama will undoubtedly pique their interest. Like its peers, Motorama offers an intriguing mix of eccentric characters, gritty aesthetics, and absurd situations that blur the lines between reality and delusion. This unique blend, coupled with tongue-in-cheek humor and an unabashed embrace of B-movie tropes, creates an irresistibly strange atmosphere. A road-trip-gone-wrong flick that exudes adventure and nonstop entertainment, Motorama's psychedelic undertones and curious character encounters make it a must-watch addition to any offbeat B-grade desert film lineup.

What can I say about the series dubbed the NEW OUTER LIMITS...Hmm.... Only that this was one of the best TV series ever assembled!! You have actors of all ages, The actors that are somewhat known and that time forgot. Everyone playing their part to exact perfection! These shows always have some type of moral story to them which most of the time (if not all the time) is very true! You can feel that the man whose voice is dubbed over the credits and in the beginning and ending believes what he is saying wholeheartedly!

Oh I remember watching this show at 4:00 p.m. during my junior high days . It was not a pleasant experience for me as I struggled to relate to the characters and the storyline. I would be home from school, too exhausted to concentrate on homework, and ended up sitting in front of the TV as it blared annoying laughter tracks and clichéd dialogues. With nothing much to do and a lack of good entertainment options, I tolerated the insipid show with reluctant boredom. I would have much preferred watching a nature documentary or even a corny but earnest afterschool special.

Can the intensity of a husband 's love for his wife lead him to cover up a crime , despite the moral and legal implications? Absolutely, and there are countless stories throughout history that show this is true. When a husband is wholly devoted to his wife, the instinct to protect and stand by her may trump ethical and legal obligations, thus allowing him to engage in unthinkable acts to cover up crimes committed by her. Such loyalty and sacrifice might stem from various reasons, including fear of losing a cherished partner, keeping their relationship intact, or even succumbing to manipulation.

I was pleasantly surprised by the depth of story and character development. Fulci was a master at creating horrific atmosphere using inventive camera work, vivid cinematography, and yes - wonderfully explicit gore.This film is no exception, however, compared to his later films (The Beyond, Zombie 2, City of the Living Dead, House by the Cemetery, etc.) the characters here are extremely well developed and the emphasis shies away from the supernatural and is more on the suspense created by a classic who-dunnit amongst the lush hills of Italy.

This is one of my favourite Disney films. It has everything you could hope for in a Disney animation: cute animals, great songs, a nasty villain and lots of adventure. The story begins in Paris, where aristocat Duchess and her three kittens live with their Mistress in a mansion. Life is perfect for them until the Mistress' fiendish butler Edgar discovers that she plans to leave her entire fortune to the cats. He realises that if he even stands a chance of claiming the fortune, the cats will be out of the way.

Accepted is one of the best teenage comedies I have seen in a long time . It has an original concept, hilarious characters, and a surprisingly heartfelt message. The story revolves around a group of high school seniors who, after facing rejection from their desired colleges, decide to create their own alternative institution, the fictional South Harmon Institute of Technology (S.H.I.T.). With offbeat humor, eccentric but lovable personalities, and a genuinely engaging narrative, this film expertly addresses the challenges faced by young adults as they navigate societal pressures to conform to traditional educational paths.

The story starts out with a soldier being transported to a desert town then goes back in time to tell the tale of how he came to this place. He started out as an officer in Napoleon's army fighting in Egypt but became separated from his unit. After nearly starving and/or dying of thirst he came upon a leopard which somehow became his bosom buddy. It brought him food and before long the soldier became almost totally wild so acute was his bonding with the animal. All things do end however and the man decided it was necessary for him to leave the critter.

This is probably the second best of the Death Wish movies. Death Wish 5 is the best one.Death Wish 3 reminds me of "West Side Story" with a new twist. Not even the recent flick "Gangs of New York" can measure up with one New York neighborhood in Death Wish 3 which is plagued not by two rival gangs---but one big gang. A gang that is willing to do things like cutting a person to death with an ax if he trespasses on its set.Deborah Raffin, who plays a public defender, plays gently in this action-packed movie that is filled with a lot of shoot-em-up violence.

So it 's not an award winner , so what ? Have you ever wanted to see a film that just takes you on a fun, entertaining ride without taking itself too seriously? This might be the perfect movie for you. Popcorn flicks have their place in the cinematic universe and they are certainly important, providing audiences with a respite from heavy and thought-provoking cinema experiences. While not everyone appreciates this particular subgenre of cinema, there is definitely an art to making light-hearted entertainment, and a unique satisfaction found in reveling in the occasional unpretentious film that just wants to entertain and engage its audience.

This is one of the best sequels around and a very good movie too even there were some mistakes but still I enjoyed it. This time, Charles is not just fighting one or two muggers but a whole army of them. Death Wish 3 has a lot great action scenes and I enjoyed it every single second of it. Director Michael Winner knows how to direct a good action movie like this and Jimmy Page providing the music, with producers Golan and Globus still doing there thing and Charles Bronson is still acting good for Paul Kersey.

Made at the height of the Black Power movement, this movie portrays African-American Putney Swope (Arnold Johnson) getting made CEO of a corporation after the white CEO dies (the white executives all hate each other and can't decide who should succeed the previous CEO). Once in power, he decides to turn it into a militant organization.I don't know how Robert Downey Sr did it, but he did it! "Putney Swope" is the ultimate jab at America's power structure. It's the sort of thing that seems like it would have come out of Richard Pryor's mind.

This is one of those movies where I just want to move my feet and dance around the house. It's a very positive and happy type of music. The movie has some sad parts but mostly the music is what makes me happy. Gary Busey did a great job as Buddy Holly. Buddy Holly kept on going even tho his pastor, his parents and the Nashville record producer told him no. Buddy Holly didn't give up on what he liked. I didn't know much about Buddy Holly until I watched this movie.

This is a brilliant film. The story starts off in Romania,where Billy Crystal stars as an agent who can talk anybody into doing anything. There is a really funny scene here, where Crystal is a child, and talks his father, who is a rabbi into eating pork (you filmophiles may know that this is a parody of Crystal's religion). He is mainly a talent scout, and he's trying to find a suitable villain for his latest movie. After finding out that the whole film has a terrible crew, he accidently falls into a small river.

Sacha Baron Cohen is a genius . And this movie is good ! Although the film does n't nearly reach the heights of his iconic roles such as Borat or Ali G, it still delivers ample laughs and moments of pure absurdity. His unmatched wit, unparalleled ability to inhabit different characters, and penchant for pushing the envelope make this another enjoyable installment in Cohen's repertoire. The supporting cast does a fine job in keeping up with his fast-paced, unscripted humor. Overall, the movie may not be a classic like his earlier works, but it certainly proves Sacha Baron Cohen's comedic talents have yet to falter.

I Loved this movie. Mark Blankfield was perfect for this role. More Classic sci/fie/Horror films should be remade to this comedy level, which is at the very top of the line in my opinion. A no drink movie, you laugh so hard you will spill it all over yourself. Can We expect more? Let's hope so. I would like to suggest many movies for this type of remake. Mel Brookes made some remakes of classic films.He made some very strong contributions. A Picture of Dorian Gray would be a good suggestion.

Another go round with the monkey king going west .... sort of.Beginning in the middle of some action the movie Another go round with the Monkey King going west unfolds in an adrenaline-filled adventure, bringing the legendary journey to life once again. The movie opens with a chaotic battle scene, showcasing the prowess and extraordinary abilities of the Monkey King as he faces numerous challenges on his quest. Together with his brave companions - the noble monk, Xuanzang, the devoted and powerful Pigsy, and the calm yet wise Sandy, they delve deeper into uncharted territories facing unparalleled dangers.

Let's be fair: there are no RULES for scriptwriting, so I won't say the movie SHOULD be something other than it is. I'll just state my opinion. OK, I really liked the script, the way things are told and characters are introduced. However, I think when a play is adapted to the silver screen, it could maybe try and fit this other media. Since this movie was directed by João Falcão, the same man who directed the play, it's not too much of a surprise that the film turned out a bit too theatrical.

Captain Corelli 's Mandolin is no Oscar contender but it was pretty good . I have to admit Ms Cruz 's performance was quite captivating and her chemistry with Mr. Cage was believable. The stunning visuals of Greece truly enriched the film's setting and the blend of romance, drama, and historical events managed to keep the story engaging. Despite a few clichéd tropes, the soundtrack added depth to the emotions portrayed on screen. All in all, while it may not be a cinematic masterpiece, Captain Corelli's Mandolin still makes for a heartfelt watch with some memorable moments worth experiencing.

This movie shows that the free enterprise system and the quest for the almighty buck transcends all racial and ethnic barriers. Ultimately the market place determines the message that is sent to the public. This movie dramatizes that point. A conservative white-collar advertising company is taken over by a group of street-wise African Americans chaired by a no-nonsense black man who wants to make a buck and believes he can sell products by telling the the truth. But the movie shows that no matter how hard he tries to do something different, the market place and the political system demands that he conform, rendering him no different than his predecessors.

When the new Outer Limits first started, the episodes were quite optimistic and challenging. As the series began to wind down, most of the episodes became just plain ugly and devoid of any entertainment value. The six episodes here reflect the very best, and worst, of the series.Since The Outer Limits always preaches a moral. I would like to offer my own. Starting with the most entertaining to the flops.1. Afterlife: As an institution, The U.S.A. military-industrial complex is both evil and paranoid, not to mention plain stupid.

If you like who-dun-its, you will like this film, considered the best Italian detective story (giallo), Fulci has done.It's not Mickey Spillane for sure. There are scenes designed to disturb anyone.Many would be offended by a local beauty trying to seduce a 12-year-old boy. She was joking, but she was naked nonetheless, and he would have jumped at the chance to jump her bones. She also tries to tempt the local priest.Young boys are turning up missing, and there are several interesting suspects. You have to watch carefully to discover the killer. Can you?

"A Slight Case of Murder" is an excellent TV movie, which is defiantly worth the price of a rental. William H. Macy is great as a movie critic who accidentally kills his mistress, and then has to try to conceal the crime. Although that may sound dark, the film is actually quite light hearted and funny, with many memorable lines ("Acting is harder than I thought- you ever see BODY HEAT? I think I owe Bill Hurt an apology" and my personal favourite "For next week answer these two questions about film noir, What do these people do during the day?

I first saw The Victim ( aka Out Of Contention ) well over 25 years ago when I was very young, and I remember being absolutely enthralled by the plot and the acting performances. This mystery thriller, released in 1972, follows the life of Kate (played by Elizabeth Montgomery), who is forced to investigate the disappearance of her brother's wife. As a fan of classic thrillers, I was completely hooked by the twists and turns that left me on the edge of my seat. The complex plot showcases the evolution of crime thrillers in that era and still leaves a lasting impact after all these years.

This is by far one of the best movies I have seen in a very long time . Top 20 for sure. The storyline was well crafted and brilliantly executed, keeping me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film. The characters were dynamic and developed, pulling me into their journey with realistic dialogue and gripping emotional moments. The cinematography was stunning and the visuals, absolutely breathtaking. The use of a powerful and impactful soundtrack just elevated this film to another level. I couldn't recommend this masterpiece more, as it genuinely transcends the definition of excellent filmmaking, providing a truly unforgettable cinematic experience.

The 1973 musical version of LOST HORIZON is the most wonderful endearing and campy musical films of ALL TIME. The 1973 musical remake of the James Hilton novel about mythical SHANGRI-LA! is a real special gem. Music by BURT BACHARACH and lyrics by HAL David. A strange mixture of straight drama, adventure and musical sequences. It has the distinction of being the ONLY anti war musical fantasy ever filmed. This film was a critical and financial disappointment in the United States, but made a lot of money overseas. Only in America did it fail.

A Formula For Murder isn't a well known Giallo, but that isn't to say it's not a very good one! The film is directed by Alberto De Martino, the man behind cult classics such as The Antichrist and Blazing Magnums. The film was released late on in the Giallo cycle, but more than stands up to many of the films released around the 'golden' period in the early seventies. Despite a lack of logic in some areas, the film works mainly due to the competent way it mixes Argento style death scenes with some genuinely surprising plot twists, and a host of well defined characters.

This little film is hysterical, full of stereotypes about gays, straights, dwarfs, British tea and pubs, American gun culture, divorce and marriage; yet, it manages to be sensitive to the issues surrounding each. Kathy Bates is "Amazing" Grace Beasley, and as a character actor of staggering range, she brings her considerable comedic talent to ground this somewhat unusual film as she did in Fried Green Tomatos. With the help of other comedic talents like Dan Akroid as Max, her ex-lawyer husband and the backdrop of downtown Chicago and rural England, the story is just intriguing enough to entertain.

The A-team is still repeating every day on Dutch television (RTL7, around 1800hrs) and I still watch it! I don't like the A-Team... I absolutely adore them!! It is just great to see Justin chasing the former members of A-Team. Brings back memories from the old days, when I was young an sweet. I would have given you a 10 for excellent, but Justin looks like he is chasing the former A-Team members all by himself. Of course, that is the only bad thing on this documentary.

Charles Chaplin's 'Shoulder Arms' of 1918 was his longest film to date, though, at just over 45 minutes in length, it was not quite a feature film. With World War One just drawing to a close, many popular entertainers of the time were doing their part to inspire their native troops, and Chaplin was no exception. And so the lovable Tramp went to war! The film begins with the Tramp in training, and the character is hilariously inept at even the simplest military drills, including marching and gun-slinging, much to the disgust of his drill sergeant.

This movie shows that the free enterprise system and the quest for the almighty buck transcends all racial and ethnic boundaries, breaking down barriers and unifying people from diverse backgrounds in their pursuit of success. It presents an honest depiction of capitalism's competitive nature, showcasing that with grit, perseverance, and cooperation, individuals can rise above any social and cultural limitations. As the characters navigate their complex entrepreneurial journeys, we are reminded that the lure of financial freedom is universally enticing, cutting through racial and ethnic lines, creating new allies, adversaries, and defining lifelong partnerships in the pursuit of a shared dream.

This is my favourite Columbo . Martin Landau ( excellent ! ) plays twins , one of whom may have committed a murder. The other twin seems completely unconnected and acts as an alibi for his sibling. As always, Peter Falk's performance as Columbo is superb - it's a joy to watch him slowly unravel the mystery surrounding the crime, which seems impossible to solve. His intuitive intelligence and determination bring to life one of television's most iconic detective characters. The supporting cast members also deliver commendable performances, and the gripping storyline is punctuated with clever twists and turns, keeping viewers engaged and guessing throughout.

Being American , I have not been exposed to this character before , which is good because some of you might not know him either, allowing us to learn together. As I researched this unfamiliar figure, I discovered a rich, fascinating cultural icon. The character, deeply rooted in the history and tradition of another nation, has captured the hearts and imagination of people across the world. Often portrayed in literature, movies, and television series, this character embodies strength, courage, and wisdom, which transcends regional boundaries.

Hey look, you don't watch this movie to change your life! But if you are female especially and have always had a little thing for Richard Gere; this movie is right up your street. Diane Lane and Richard Gere have on screen chemistry going way back. 'Nights in Rodanthe' is not a Oscar winner movie and it will probably be forgotten sooner rather than later but if you want an atmospheric, beautifully shot love story between MIDDLE AGED good looking people (they don't make your stomach turn and even when Gere is 'on top' he does not look too jowly) then this is the movie for you.

William Faulkner was one of the American writers to win the Nobel Prize in literature. Faulkner mostly wrote about life in the South particularly during the depression years. Many of his stories have been adapted to screen. Short stories like Two Soldiers is an endearing tale of two brothers in December 1941 after the attack on Pearl Harbor. The older brother, Pete Greer, goes to Memphis, Tennessee to enlist like hundreds of thousands of young men, some who would never come home. His younger brother doesn't take his departure well. He manages to get a bus ticket to Memphis without any money to find his brother.

I was so happy to learn that Hari Om will finally be theatrically released in 2007. I saw this film three years ago at the Vancouver International film Festival and have been waiting for it's release ever since so I could send everyone I know to see it. It's like taking a trip to India....colorful, magical, thought provoking. Aside from one rather strange Hollywood style auto rickshaw chase scene this movie is very realistic. This is not a Bollywood style song and dance movie but it does have drama and romance and humor.

Damien O'Donnell has a good track record and in this film he handles a very delicate topic with sensitivity but also unflinching honesty. "A Delicate Balance" takes an in-depth look at mental health issues, focusing on a single character, Rose, who battles with bipolar disorder. Throughout the film, the audience witnesses the highs and lows, alongside the misunderstandings and lack of compassion society often places upon mental illness. O'Donnell seamlessly navigates these challenges, showing the power of a supportive community while addressing the dire consequences that arise without that crucial network.

Mark Blankfield (from the old late night TV show "Fridays")plays Dr. Daniel Jekyll, a mild-mannered surgeon who invents a powder that turns him into a drug-crazed party animal. This was not, of course, his intent, he had higher aspirations, but he goes with the flow. This is actually a fairly stupid movie, but it's also pretty fun. Of course, once the good doctor realizes what he's done, he's ashamed, but he's also not above doing it all again & running through Hollywood as a crazed sex machine with frizzed out hair & gold chains.

What an incredible story and what a beautiful film! Hat's off to Ben Daniels, Lavinia Currier and the great Honore de Balzac. This captivating film conveys the passion experienced by the characters so effortlessly and yet so powerfully. I watched it mesmerized, almost holding my breath as the story developed towards its inexorable end. This film's execution was almost flawless: simple and pure, it plays with our hearts, guiding us in understanding the strange platonic, absolute thus possessive bond between two creatures not meant to be part of each other's world.

This is a good film , no doubt , but with some odd aspects . Without spoiling anything it takes place in an eerie setting that adds an element of suspense throughout the entire plot. The well-developed characters have intricate relationships with one another, further contributing to the intrigue. Moreover, the narrative explores thought-provoking themes of human emotions, mental health, and ethics. However, the peculiar plot twists and stylistic choices could potentially alienate some viewers. It's easy to get drawn into this peculiar world, but certain directorial decisions might leave one scratching their head.

(Synopsis) Graduating high school senior Bartleby "B" Gaines (Justin Long) finds himself without a college to attend. He has been able to talk and con his way out of every problem he encounters, but he hasn't been able to charm his way pass the college admissions board of eight colleges. His mom and dad are very disappointed that Bartleby hasn't been accepted into college. His parents think that if Bartleby doesn't go to college, he will have no future. Several of Bartleby's friends are in the same situation of being rejected by all the colleges they applied to.

OK, so I loved Rachael Ray before, but now, I ADORE her! How innovative. I love that she has a cooking section- I admit that occasionally I skip that part, only because it makes me WAAAY too hungry! But I also love that you can get the next day's grocery list on her website. I love that she has regular helpers and that she's made some of her viewers become her regulars. I love how personable she is and how creative she is. I also like how she does her Mystery Guests.

Before I forget , let me say the artwork in here is outstanding . From garbage cans to the huge mural that covers an entire wall, the attention to detail is exceptional. It seems that even the most ordinary objects have been transformed into pieces of art, creating a unique atmosphere within the space. It's fascinating how various materials like recycled metal and wood, have been crafted into sculptures and decorative items. Every nook and corner features delightful pieces that instantly capture your attention and admiration. As you move through the space, the color schemes and styles shift, showing a remarkable range of creativity and design skills.

Jeff Garlin 's film is filled with heart and laughter . As in Curb Your Enthusiasm , his screen persona is incredibly relatable, endearing, and hilarious. The storyline blends mundane aspects of daily life with perfectly timed humor, which adds depth and resonance to his character. Garlin's masterful ability to tell jokes, extract humor from everyday scenarios, and interact with an eclectic ensemble of quirky characters leaves audiences with a warm sense of satisfaction. His style effortlessly invites viewers into a lighthearted world, providing a sweet escape from reality.

Considering it 's basically low-budget cast , this is a surprisingly good flick about the life and death of rock 'n' roll legend Buddy Holly. Set in the late 1950s, it encapsulates the heady days of youth and the essence of early rock 'n' roll culture. While the acting can sometimes seem stilted, the genuine love for Holly's music shines through, with dynamic live performance sequences that capture his indomitable spirit. In a unique departure from biopic norms, we see deeper into the stories of fellow band members and his personal relationships that make it as much a tribute as it is an exploration of a fallen star.

Hey all you jive hustlers, you stone foxes, you mean dudes. Watch out cause Slaughter is back in town! If you are looking for a bad-ass, funky film to watch some night, this is just right. 'Slaughter' is back and trying to take it easy n' relax after his adventures down in Mexico. But if you are a narrow-minded gangster like 'Duncan', you are bound to seek revenge. Why, I don't know. Was 'Hoffo' in the first one his brother or what? Any who.

* Could contain spoilers , read only after seeing last episode season 2 * Think about it . The guys from Elden Academy had quite a journey throughout season 2. The epic twists, unexpected alliances, and revelations left us on the edge of our seats. In the finale, our favorite characters, Jason and Toby, manage to uncover a massive secret about the academy that could threaten everything they hold dear. The constant tension between friendships and romantic relationships – particularly the complicated dynamic between Amanda, Luke, and Mike – have set the stage for potential drama in season 3.

This has got to be one of the most magnificent things I 've ever seen on film . I do n't say this lightly, as I have been a passionate film aficionado for years, but this particular piece has left me in complete awe. From the enthralling plotline to the impeccable cinematography and captivating character development, every aspect of the film works in perfect harmony. The director has managed to tell a story that transcends beyond the confines of cinema and reaches deep into the human soul. The cast delivers emotionally powerful performances that bring the beautifully crafted script to life.

Barbora Bobulova's portrayal of Valeria in this story was entirely captivating and heart wrenching at the same time. It has been a long time since I have seen so much hidden passion and mystique presented by any actor simply by utilizing her facial features and the use of her eyes and mouth the way Barbora does with this character. She was entirely believable as Valeria and I was swept away with her characterisation of this role. All at once the film was real life and fantasy, the clever use of what was limited dialogue left me spellbound.

I do not think that this movie deserves the low rating that most will give it . It 's one of those rare films that may not impress all with its storyline or screenplay, but it definitely captivates with its charm and authenticity. I can understand how some viewers may not be completely engaged, given its unconventional narrative structure and pacing, but one must truly appreciate the efforts put forth by the cast and crew to create this unique cinematic experience. I urge you to look beyond the popular opinion and give this movie a chance – its creative storytelling and heart-warming performances just might change your mind.

In Nordestina , a village in the middle of nowhere in Pernambuco , Antônio ( Gustavo Falcão ) is the unofficial gatekeeper of the community. Antônio takes it upon himself to welcome outsiders, yet ensures they do not interfere with the traditional values and ways of the village. In his quest to balance his small community with the rapid onset of globalization, Antônio faces resistance and challenges. Just when he believes that things have taken a turn for the better, a new person enters the town who brings unforeseen changes that leave the villagers questioning their long-held beliefs and struggling to preserve their culture in a world constantly changing.

Just exactly HOW director John Madden come to settle with Nicolas Cage and Penelope Cruz playing the roles of an Italian army officer and a beautiful Greek island girl in the WWII epic love story "Captain Corelli's Mandolin" still puzzles many fans. Madden saw in these two talented actors a potential to beautifully portray the profound emotions of love, betrayal, and loss intertwined in this dramatic story. Madden's faith in Cage and Cruz's incredible acting abilities, coupled with their dedication to building the necessary chemistry, elevated their performances, making "Captain Corelli's Mandolin" a heartwarming tribute to the human spirit in times of adversity.

Being American, I have not been exposed to this character before, which is good because some of you have been disappointed. I have nothing to compare it to. I have found no enjoyment in the mindless idiot humor in the American teen movies, and although this is a slightly similar type of humor, I couldn't stop laughing. I hardly ever laugh out loud at a movie. And usually a movie has a few funny parts for me, but this movie was funny from start to finish. My only disappointment was when it was over.

The cinema of the 60s was as much as time of revolution as the politics and the music . Filmmakers from all around the world were challenging the conventions of storytelling and experimenting with radical new ways to convey their narratives. At the forefront were visionaries such as Jean-Luc Godard, Ingmar Bergman, and Federico Fellini, whose unconventional films dealt with complex themes such as alienation, existentialism, and the nature of dreams. Social realism and critical approaches to established structures flourished, whilst the emergence of international auteurs like Akira Kurosawa brought non-Western storytelling into the limelight.

I wonder why I have n't heard of this movie before . It 's truly a magnificent comedy ( I haven't laughed this hard in a long time). The stellar cast perfectly delivers witty lines and nails the impeccable comedic timing. I've never encountered such a seamless blend of relatable humor and unique plot twists. Upon further research, I found that it has been out for a while and was, surprisingly, a sleeper hit. Now I am on a mission to spread the word about this criminally underrated gem of a film, and can't wait to show it to friends during a much-needed movie night!

This is one of Chaplin's First National films from the period between his glorious Mutual shorts and the more mature United Artists features. More opulent than the Mutual films, it continues Chaplin's quest for perfecting his comic expression. Most people forget that the film is actually a dream that Charlie has while awaiting being sent off to the front.There is plenty of slapstick via the Limburger cheese being used to gas the enemy, and Chaplin's foray into enemy territory dressed as a tree.By this stage in this career, the great man had become so immersed in filmic expression that his films give the impression of making themselves.

Another great Tom Wilkinson performance punctuates "Separate Lies," a 2005 film also starring Emily Watson, Linda Bassett and Rupert Everett. Directed by Julian Fellowes, it's the story of a married couple, James and Ann Manning where the husband (Wilkinson) believes he and his wife (Watson) are happy together. An accident near their house on the night they have a party brings the police around. It is a hit and run that killed their maid Maggie's Bassett) husband. James becomes suspicious of a neighbor, Bill Bule (Everett) when he sees some damage on his car.

Wow, What a wonderful film-making! Mr. Im has done it, again!His last work, ChunHayang (2000) was a great film, but this one is even greater. Selected as an official feature film in the Canne Festival for the second time in a two-year row, this 66 years old director is getting better and better at what he is making of with a Korean culture.Simply, Chihwaseon is about a great Korean painter, '(Ohwon) JANG, Seung-Up' who was considered as a prodigy in the late Nineteenth century.

This is possibly one of my favorite films. It tells the tale of a girl named Gerda (Chelsea Hobbs) who lost her mother at a very young age, so has been bought up by her father. She falls in love with the bell boy named Kai. However, on her birthday the snow queen (Bridget Fonda) comes the the hotel which her father owns and kidnaps Kai. Gurda then goes after Kai, and follows him through the four seasons in an attempt to rescue him.I thought that this was an excellent adaption of the story with great performances from all the cast.

Oh my word ! ! I have never seen a film so lacking in any kind of moral judgement or responsibility. It's as if the creators threw caution to the wind, prioritized cheap thrills, and threw a blind eye to any potential ethical concerns. To say I'm shocked would be an understatement. However, it's also a reflection of our society's increasing desensitization and eagerness to consume this type of content. Though disturbing, perhaps this should serve as a wakeup call for filmmakers and viewers alike to critically evaluate the media we create and consume, while striving for a balance between art and morality.

`` Blind Spot '' one of my festival favorites . I was totally intrigued by the idea of three strangers coming together in one place, all connected by a mysterious event that left a lasting impact on each of their lives. The blind spot, which is seemingly invisible to others, bonds them and encourages them to find a shared resolution. As the film unfolded, I was drawn into the intricately woven narrative and mesmerizing performances of the ensemble cast. Their chemistry was evident and it enhanced the sense of unity in the face of an intangible challenge.

The writers of lost have outdone themselves. Season two's finale is even more heartbreaking and intense than the finale for season one. Locke's lack of faith has not only resulted in spiritual consequences for himself, but in tragic physical consequences for the lives of the other castaways. Michael's betrayal resulted in a success for him but can he possibly escape the island? He will have to if he wants to stay alive. I don't doubt that one or more of his former friends would be willing to kill him in revenge.

The last film by underrated director Alberto De Martino ("The Antichrist", "The Killer is on the Phone") is a truly suspenseful but incomprehensibly neglected giallo, containing pretty much all the trademarks that makes this Italian horror sub genre so magnificent and addictive to the fans. There are some very disturbing themes (child abuse, phony priests), loads of creepy moments, plot twists left & right, outstanding music and  last but not least  a handful of really sadistic murder scenes! Especially the opening sequence, which is some kind of prologue, is a powerful piece of horror!

Was very fortunate to see the movie Hari Om at The Bermuda International Film Festival. It was the opening night and was such a delightful movie. It was shot beautifully around India and I want to go there now. The main actor..Vijay was absolutely incredible. He was the highlight of the movie. Apparently he was also in the movie..Monsoon Wedding. He was the total star of the show. Benoit's character cracked me up...was very funny. And the girl (forget the name) was great too. They were all great!

Chaplin enters the trenches of WWI in this spirited comedy that never belittles the horrors of war . The rain pours incessantly as soldiers trudge through mud and dodge falling bombs. Amidst this turmoil, our fearless and ever-optimistic protagonist, Chaplin, refuses to let the war dampen his spirits. With expert slapstick timing and mischievous wit, he inspires laughter and morale amongst his comrades. Be it transforming daily routine tasks into outrageous antics or using his quick wit and unique pantomime skills to escape deadly enemy traps, Chaplin never strays from the challenge. His resolute positivity reminds us of the indomitable human spirit even in the darkest moments of history.

Blind Spot's images are great. The action draws you in completely, even though the movie is a bit long. By the end credits all that you can think about are the film's positive high-points. The lead actors have the most incredible screen presence. The story is heart-wrenching. The film score is nicely understated . Completely moving in its own powerful way. Not your standard melodramatic cuing. Trance-like moments add poetic resonance to the engrossing narration and terrific visual compositions. Hope you get a chance to see this film. It delves into some dark territory but you come out of the tunnel seeing nothing but white light.

I did not know what to expect when I decided to watch this documentary . I knew it was about climate change and its impacts, but I never anticipated how powerful and moving it would be. Through striking visuals and compelling narratives, the filmmakers provide an honest, human look at the urgent challenges we face due to our rapidly changing planet. This documentary highlights not only the scientific data and alarming statistics, but also the tangible, real-life consequences of global warming affecting people across diverse landscapes and communities. After watching it, I felt more informed, empathetic, and inspired to make a difference in whatever way I can.

I watch tons of movies and had no idea this would be as good as it was . I was completely blown away by the captivating storyline, the unexpected twists, and the brilliant performances delivered by the cast. Not only did the movie boast impeccable cinematography, but it also showcased a skillful use of its visual effects, striking the perfect balance of awe and realism. Additionally, the music score seamlessly evoked the required emotions, drawing me deeper into the experience. Overall, this underrated gem of a movie is a masterful production and a must-watch for all cinema enthusiasts seeking high-quality, engrossing entertainment.

Belonging to the subgenre of post-apocalyptic future films, it is a stylistic and very very intimate installment. The most noticed element of the film is its silence; no one speaks. I don't think Besson, despite what is evident in most of his later work, meant it as any kind of cool gimmick. I think what makes it so clever and so effective is the fact that with no other way of communicating, everyone has to read each other based on intuition and conveying of emotion, no matter how slight.

I love this movie , though I do n't like how they picture Egyptians , being an Egyptian citizen myself I love this movie, though I don't like how they picture Egyptians, being an Egyptian citizen myself. It seems like filmmakers have fallen into the trap of using cultural stereotypes to portray us. Egyptians are shown either as rigid historical figures or as the exotic "other." What we see on screen rarely encompasses the beautiful and diverse experiences that make up Egyptian culture. That being said, I do appreciate the compelling storyline, excellent acting, and the beautiful cinematography showcased throughout the movie.

"Pearl Harbor, buddy." This movie is brilliant! Sure it doesn't exactly flow like an multi-million dollar comedy does, but the jokes that are constantly thrown in are unbelievable. I'm one that goes for silliness, much like "Dumb and Dumber", "Airplane" and "Wet Hot American Summer" and I have to say this easily ranks up there. Movies just aren't written with this kind of sporadic comedy anymore. Too many jokes in this are such a surprise to the viewer that it's honestly amazing that more don't know about and praise this slapstick masterpiece!

TV churns out dozens of true-crime movies every year . You can see 3 or 4 every Saturday on Lifetime alone. This growing popularity of true-crime movies can be attributed to our fascination with understanding the darker aspects of human nature and the motives behind criminal behavior. Documentaries like Making a Murderer or scripted adaptations such as Mindhunter are not only riveting and educational but also push for the exploration of the criminal justice system, uncovering its flaws and inciting debate on serious societal issues. As long as audiences crave mystery and moral complexity, true-crime films will continue to hold an influential spot in our collective entertainment.

This film, winning Im Kwon-Taek the Best Director at Cannes in 2002 (tied with P.T. Anderson for Punch-Drunk Love), is about a 19th century Korean painter with a commoner's roots and significant impact on Korean painting. One of the strengths?of the film is that Im tries to help us see with the eye of a painter, so we see multiple scenes and objects which help our drunken painter friend, Jang Seung-up (Choi Min-shik),?receive inspiration.The costumes and the art direction are all impressive and the acting is even along being good.

Hey look , you do n't watch this movie to change your life ! But if you are female especially , it's a fun, lighthearted, and enjoyable way to spend an evening with friends or alone for some much-needed "me time." The film provides laughs, romance, and moments of genuine camaraderie among its strong and relatable female characters. Sure, it won't make you ponder existential questions, but it doesn't have to! Instead, embrace its wit and humor and appreciate the refreshing dose of girl power on the screen.

A great movie . The movie was even better then the commercials put on . And believe it or not , the entire cast gave some of their best performances to date. The plot was filled with surprising twists and turns, making it unpredictable and keeping the audience hooked throughout. The cinematography and visual effects were spectacular, giving the movie an additional layer of richness and depth. The director really showcased their exceptional vision and understanding of storytelling, ultimately making the movie a memorable and exhilarating experience. A must-watch for cinema enthusiasts, this movie deserves all the praise and acclaim it's been receiving.

I do n't see what the problem is with SOME people and their NEED for intellectual humor . You need to understand that not everyone shares the same taste in humor, and it's important to appreciate diverse forms of comedy. Laughter is subjective, and it should cater to a wide variety of audiences. If we limit ourselves to intellectual humor, we might lose the opportunity to bring laughter and joy to others who appreciate slapstick, physical, or other forms of lighthearted entertainment. Embracing diversity in humor enhances social interactions, builds connections, and reflects our unique individual preferences.

To say the truth , I went to see this movie only because Nicolas Cage is my favorite actor . , and I always make sure to watch every film he stars in. However, I did not have high expectations going in, given that many of Cage's recent movies haven't exactly been well-received by critics. To my surprise, this particular movie had a very interesting storyline that kept me engaged from the beginning. The supporting cast complemented Cage's performance brilliantly, showcasing their talent through meaningful interactions with his character.

Coming from the "druggie" generation, I thought this movie was hilarious. It definitely brought Jekyll & Hyde up-to-date, so to speak. My husband and I laughed all the way through it. Would love to have the movie in my collection. I told my two teenagers about the movie and they would love to see it. They aren't into drugs but they know enough about them to understand the comedy in the movie. It's been so long since I've seen it I can't remember but a few things.

Too bad somebody did not have the smarts to release this movie to theaters . I had never heard of it before, and I stumbled upon it quite by accident. This gem of a film truly deserved the spotlight of the big screen for all to see and appreciate. Its compelling story, combined with brilliant performances and breathtaking visuals, made it a remarkable cinematic experience. With limited marketing, it ended up flying under the radar and slipped into streaming platforms without fanfare. It's a real pity as a theatrical release would have potentially resulted in higher viewership, rave reviews, and possible award nominations.

I tend to get furious when hearing about Lucio Fulci 's reputation as a director . Too often he 's dismissed as merely a "gorehound" or "shock specialist" without enough attention being paid to the innovation and artistry in his work. This reductionist approach overlooks Fulci's influence in shaping Italian horror and thriller genres, particularly his experimentation with plotlines and striking visuals. Though Fulci's films have attained cult status, I believe there's a lot more to explore beneath the gore; whether it's symbolism, themes, or meticulous narrative construction.

This was the greatest movie I have ever seen in my life , the action was great , and i absolutely loved the storyline. The character development was phenomenal, and it kept me engaged from start to finish. The visual effects were breathtaking, showcasing incredible talent behind the scenes. Every scene had me on the edge of my seat, the suspense building and captivating me throughout. The humor was perfectly balanced with the emotional aspects of the story, providing an overall amazing experience. The chemistry among the actors was impressive, creating a truly immersive experience that exceeded my expectations.

Chucky is back but this time he is not scary ( a lot ) - but he is funny ! Chucky, the infamous killer doll, has returned with a twist - this time, he's swapping his frightening antics for some laughter! This reincarnation of the once-spine-chilling character now delights and amuses fans old and new alike with witty humor and quirky personality. The iconic doll we all used to dread has now transformed into a lovable, eccentric jester bringing forth plenty of unexpected laughs, ensuring audiences never look at Chucky the same way again. Who knew laughter would disarm our deadliest doll and capture our hearts?

Being a middle aged mom myself, I very much appreciated seeing a romance between grown-up people that weaves in the many issues that effect us. Diane Lane beautifully portrays Adrienne and the sacrifice and conflict that a mother goes through, wanting to do what is right for her children, but still have a happy life herself. I am not a big Richard Gere fan, but he always does a good job with the guy who is sort of jerk, but learns something about himself.Criticism of their romance as unrealistic is hardly justified when compared to most other romantic movies.

This searing drama based on a true incident concerns several ambitious African nationals who decide to temporarily leave their families and embark on a perilous journey to Europe in search of a better life. The film deftly captures the heart-wrenching emotional turmoil these individuals endure, torn between the need to support their loved ones financially and their unwillingness to abandon their dreams for a brighter future. As they navigate dangerous terrains and treacherous conditions, battling discrimination and despair, their tale serves as a poignant and powerful reminder of the enormous personal sacrifices migrants make for the possibility of a life worth living.

This film was made right in the area where I grew up and now live. I know personally most of the property owners of the various locations used in the film. As a teenager, I worked in the fields surrounding the isolated road shown late in the film with Ron Perlman, Jonathon Furr, and the car. I am told that Jonathon Furr and Ben Allison are are natives of NC. I was fortunate to see it at a local showing. At that showing was one of the people who helped select locations and secure props, such as the bus (1938 Greyhound) used in the movie.

All the characters in this cartoon were hilarious . Norman the Viking guardian had some memorable phrases and the skull character, Skullie, always brought a spooky charm to each episode. Not to mention Matilda, the witty and intelligent seafaring lass, whose comebacks had everyone laughing. Together with a plethora of unique sidekicks like Olaf the not-so-smart but ever-loyal servant, Bjorn the cowardly warrior, and Ylva, the singing enchantress, these vibrant characters constantly got themselves entangled in ridiculous situations that left viewers in stitches. Each character had their own comedic quirks, making for unpredictable and lively antics throughout the series, delighting the young and the young-at-heart alike.

This is one of the finest TV movies you could ever see. The acting, writing and production values are top-notch. The performances are passionate with Beverly D'Angelo superb as the older woman with a teenage daughter and Rob Estes simply perfect as the young stud boyfriend. However, the best part of this film was how it showed the consequences of sexual abuse instead of going for the usual happy ending. It showed that abuse can happen in good families; involve good people; and wreck lives. It is thought provoking and entertaining. Congratulations to all concerned with this exceptional movie.

This is possibly one of my favorite films . It tells the tale of a girl named Gerda ( Chelsea Hobbs) who embarks on a thrilling journey to save her beloved brother, Kai (Daniel Peacock), from the clutches of the evil Snow Queen (Elizabeth Munro). As Gerda journeys through enchanting landscapes, she encounters whimsical characters, treacherous obstacles, and magical events that push her resilience and determination to their limits. This captivating story not only entertains but teaches valuable life lessons on courage, friendship, and the unwavering power of love.

Little Dieter Needs To Fly is another in the remarkable body of Werner Herzog's filmic work that is without peer. Having recently rewatched it on DVD, nearly a decade after its initial US release in 1997, it has lost none of its power, and one can see its influence on documentaries as diverse as Herzog's own recent Grizzly Man and Errol Morris's Academy Award winning The Fog Of War. Like the former, it details, in its far too brief 74 minutes, the life of an interesting American. Like the latter it gives a peek at a side of war that few see.

A very suspenseful giallo from the director of "L'Anticristo"(1974),this one begins with a brilliantly-handled sequence involving a priest,a little girl,and a broken doll.However the main story is about maniac(David Warbeck)marrying a traumatized cripple to kill her for her money.The plot,whilst not original,is really suspenseful,the acting is good and there are several skillful and gory murders.The score by Francesco de Massi is quite effective,some of which can also be heard in Lucio Fulci's "The New York Ripper"(1982).Highly recommended for fans of Italian cinema!

I am a guy, so i was very hesitant to watch the movie because i know that Richard Gear likes to be in tear jerker movies. I would rather watch action/adventure/sci fi. I was right, the movie is definitely a tear jerker. Diane tended to over act a few times, as did richard, but they brought it around and made it work. The daughter was a suppressed teen with huge attitude, so you started out hating her. The movie is way too predictable, but for entertainment purposes, it was a masterpiece.

I can't get this flick off my brain. It's definitely totally different than anything that's out there. I've seen a ton of movies over the holidays and while some are okay nothing really rocked my world the way BlindSpot did. There is just something way cool about the actors and the way that they put the film together. It's like there is really scary stuff mixed with with some pretty f****ing hilarious black humour. Franco is great but the older rough dude steals the show in a few scenes, like when he punches the kid out in the dirt grave.

Oh my gosh!! I love this movie sooooooooooooooooooooo much!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! It is so incredible......I loved it as a wee babe and still love it as an adult. It is my favorite Disney movie of allllllllllllllllllllllllllllll time! You should watch it, watch it and love it. My friends and I watch it a ton.....It is soooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo good. I recommend it to anyone who is a child or a child at heart.

We saw La Spettatrice at the Syracuse International Film & Video Festival & liked it.This film delved into the fear we all have. Fear of rejection, fear of intimacy and most importantly fear of our own inadequacies.The three lead actors, Barbora Bobulova as Valeria, Brigitte Catillon as Flavia, Andrea Renzi as Massimo are match well to their roles and are excellent. It was a joy to witness the dynamic between the three of them as it seemed real.I believe Barbora Bobulova is a stand out. I hope we see much more of her in the coming years.This film doesn't take the easy way out.

Containing Billy's famous humor, this more modest comedy with heavy bittersweet overtones is a big departure, pleasantly unexpectedly so for Billy Crystal. This movie has different tear-jerker, dramatic, serious underlying themes (particularly with a scene with Steven Seagal). This movie was both entertaining and serious, a movie about lost love, about relationships with father-son, husband-wife, about friendship and values with a good dose of humor thrown in, especially at the beginning. The balance between drama and comedy isn't always maintained as with the new classical genre of this type, but the real message and motivation for this movie remains solid.

Telling the story would n't be the point at all , would it ? Barnens ö , spelled almost like "children's island" in Swedish, was a place where my soul found solace, surrounded by pristine nature and embraced by endless skies. As a young adventurer, I would get lost in the lush forest, entangled in the harmony of wind whispering through the trees, accompanied by my unwavering thirst for exploring hidden realms. There I would find peculiar secrets, learn invaluable life lessons, and share laughs and tears with the wisest teachers.

After learning that her sister Susan is contemplating divorce, Kate decides to travel to the distraught woman's remote country home and spend some time with her. When Kate arrives, however, Susan is nowhere in sight. That's because someone has murdered her and stuffed the body in a trunk in the basement. As a storm rages outside, Kate tries to figure out where her sister could have gone and places her own life in great danger...the killer is still on the premises! In her first post-BEWITCHED vehicle, Elizabeth Montgomery gives a solid dramatic performance.

I saw the trailer and read some reviews , and I had low expectations for this movie . I was pleasantly surprised when it turned out to be much better than I expected. The plot was engaging, with some twists I didn't see coming, and the performances from the actors were on point. The cinematography was also impressive, giving the film a unique atmosphere that kept me immersed. Even though it wasn't perfect, with some cliché elements and occasional slow pacing, it was an entertaining watch that kept me hooked.

I thought this was movie was great , Richard Greico and Yasmine Bleeth have great chemistry in this movie . I absolutely loved their performances, as they managed to portray their characters flawlessly and in a way that truly resonated with the audience. The captivating storyline was well-constructed, and the character development allowed the viewers to become invested in their on-screen relationships. Not to mention the film's cinematography and visuals were fantastic, further adding to its allure. In my opinion, this movie deserves praise for the talented acting, memorable plot, and engaging overall presentation, making it a must-watch for fans of Richard Greico and Yasmine Bleeth alike.

The Child's Play series isn't a favourite of mine, but Bride Of Chucky is actually an okay movie. This time we have two dolls Chucky and his former girlfriend (when he was human) Tiffany. Together they go on a journey to find an object. There are a few interesting scenes through the movie like the guy getting hit by the truck and literally exploding, the sex scene between Chucky and Tiffany and the ending which allows for another sequel to take place. Wasn't really a straight forward horror, it mixed a lot of comedy and was a sort of spoof of the horror genre.

I can not say this movie was a hilarious , but I must have had a grin on my face most of the time. The humor was subtle yet clever, incorporating well-timed dialogue and just the right amount of physical comedy. The acting, particularly from the lead actors, brought out each character's quirks and nuances perfectly, allowing the viewer to appreciate every laugh the film offered. Although it wasn't a side-splitting experience, it certainly was an entertaining watch and one that leaves you feeling happy and uplifted. This is a solid, light-hearted flick for when you need that easy-going charm and laughter.

The retelling of a classic story is set to the music of Burt Bacharach and lyrics of Hal David. The actors seem like real people in this fairytale of the outside world meeting with mystical Shangra-la. It is a joy to watch Bobby Van, whose acting puts me in mind of Red Buttons, and, as always, George Kennedy (Cool-Hand Luke) who always manages to carry gravitas in his roles. The surprise here is Charles Boyer as the elder High Lama. Who would have known? All-star cast including Michael York and Olivia Hussey makes this work a keeper for those of us who cherish people.

It was Libby talking to Desmond in the flashback , and if anyone is confused about her past ( like why she was in the mental hospital), it has not been revealed yet. Desmond still recognized her face but couldn't pinpoint where he knew her from. Meanwhile, Libby was also piecing together her mysterious connection to Desmond, haunted by hazy memories of the encounters they had before. In time, their shared past would intertwine with present predicaments as more light is shed on their fateful intertwining stories. This path will uncover dark secrets, astounding truths, and a link they never would have expected.

`` Nuovomondo '' was a great experience . Many filmmakers tell their stories to a big extent via dialogue . Nuovomondo offered a refreshing take on storytelling, where the visual aspect played a more significant role than the spoken word. It demonstrated how potent visuals and powerful imagery can lead to the creation of vivid stories without relying heavily on dialogue. Filmmakers who chose this approach engaged the audience in a different way, challenging them to interpret and understand the characters' actions and emotions purely through visual cues. Nuovomondo left an indelible impact, inspiring more filmmakers to tap into the innate power of visual storytelling.

That's right. Ohwon (the painter and the main character) is an exceptional person. What strikes me most is the message this film might address to all of you people there. And the message is sad. It says that, it's very difficult to do anything that's amazing or maybe even genius without having to obey the governments, establishment and other VIPs of this world. And even if you try, you might not be able to bear it. It is about the battle of a single person with a system. With many systems.A great film of this wonderful Korean director.

Gary Busey did a splendid job playing the rock-n-roll legend Buddy Holly(1936-59). He does have a spitting image to the man. Being a garage band in the 50's is sure different from today's. Having a group of three is usually simple back in those days. I bet that Buddy Holly(Busey) was a much better musician than most of what I heard. Since he lived in Lubbock, Texas, it was only a quiet country town back then. His parents were Christians, though his mother was a strong supporter of her son's work.

Containing Billy 's famous humor , this more modest comedy with heavy bittersweet overtones is a big departure , pleasantly surprising viewers. Exploring themes of love, loss, and human connection, it showcases Billy's range as both an actor and comedian. The audience can still expect his quirky jokes, expertly intertwined with moments that pull on the heartstrings, creating an unforgettable and truly multidimensional experience. Supported by an equally talented ensemble cast, the film masterfully captures the delicate balance between laughter and tears, proving that even amidst sorrow, there's still a place for Billy's unshakable, irresistible humor.

i did not read the book. nor do i care to. the movie was a beautiful romance, and i think women will enjoy it. no, it was not a "10" film, but it was enjoyable. women, if your man is bored as mine was, then watch it yourself. hurt is wonderful as the philosophic doctor who delivers a thoughtful monologue on "in love" and "loving. "also, if you like nick cage, he was terrific and funny. i enjoyed watching the developing romance. also, if you like Christian bale -- do see him in equilibrium.

As far as I know I 've seen most of Lucio Fulci 's films , with the exception of some of his early comedies and a few obscure titles. His body of work ranges from giallo mysteries to visceral horror classics like "Zombie" and "The Beyond." Fulci's unique blend of atmospheric storytelling, gruesome special effects, and iconic visuals made him a pioneer in the genre. However, it's essential to approach his films with an open mind, as they're known for their disturbing and often bizarre content.

It took me a while to find this movie since they don't have it yet on DVD (and my VCR is not worth hooking up again). I guess all the referencing to drug use is too much for some folks. But I found a decent bootleg on Ebay and I must say that anyone who takes this movie too seriously is just retarded. It is a slap stick spoof in the vein of "Airplane." I must say that when I watched it on Showtime or Spotlight growing up in the 80s, I enjoyed the humor a whole lot more then, than I do now.

This film was made right in the area where I grew up and now live . I know personally most of the locations showcased in the film, making it all the more special to me. The movie itself beautifully captures the essence and unique atmosphere of my hometown, and portrays the relationships among the residents in an authentic manner. As a result, it's a deeply nostalgic experience watching it – as if the film took a snapshot of my own memories and personal connections. The way in which the filmmakers successfully manage to preserve these elements and breathe life into the familiar landscapes gives it a truly heartfelt charm.

Little Dieter Needs To Fly is another in the remarkable body of Werner Herzog 's filmic work that is without comparison. The film showcases a blend of documentary and surrealism, immersing the viewer into the extraordinary journey of Dieter Dengler. A German-born American who fulfilled his dream of becoming a pilot only to find himself navigating through the dark world of war, imprisonment and, ultimately, freedom in the Vietnamese War. The atmospheric visuals and remarkable storytelling captivate the audience's imagination, urging us to examine themes such as determination, adversity, and resilience.

I always liked listening to Buddy Holly and felt a real loss when he was killed at a young age in an airplane crash. He wasn't in the old rock 'n roll class of , let's say, Chuck Berry or Jerry Lee Lewis, but he wasn't far behind. Who knows how big his legacy would have been had he sang for decades. Almost every single he put out was a hit.So, I was very pleasantly surprised how good a job Gary Busey did at playing him and at imitating his singing voice.

inspite of many movies dealing with great artists or a genius, chihaweseon pointed out the real dilemma in which an artist is capted...the decision whether to ease the demands of the popularity or to create something new and to define ones' own style.Chiahweson's desperate seek for inspiration and broadening his conscious led him to live the way he did, restless, outrageous, and yes very drunk! But still he defended and retained the most important ethical rules for an artist: respect to his Master, respect to the nature and the gradual seek for improvement and to perfection.

Mark Blankfield played Jekyll and Hyde.Michael McGuire was the dad.Tim Thomerson was the plastic surgeon.Did you even see this movie? I doubt it!Blankfield was fairly popular at this time for playing the pill-popping doctor on Fridays. Thomerson has been funny in anything he does, from movies to series to stand-up comedy. If I ever find this movie on DVD I will definitely buy it. I recorded this movie off of HBO back in '82 and have pretty much worn out the tape. One of the funniest takes on the Jekyll & Hyde theme ever.Of course.

I was watching an NFL game and started surfing during a break and found this on one of the HBO type channels. I missed the beginning but when I started watching Deadly Voyage the clicker was put down and not even thought of until the credits rolled. You will find yourself rooting against the villans and on the edge of your La-Z-Boy throughout this one. If you get the chance take the time to watch it. Every once in a while I think about having the cable company take off my Movie channels but when you stumble across great ones like this you know why it is worth paying extra for them.

I do n't usually like this sort of movie but was working at home and wanted something to halfway watch while completing some tasks. I decided to give it a shot, considering the reviews were mostly positive. Surprisingly, I found myself enjoying the film more than I anticipated. The engaging plot, compelling characters, and brilliant visuals truly drew me in and held my attention. Even though it didn't fit into my typical movie preferences, the overall experience had me immersed, proving that sometimes stepping outside of my comfort zone can lead to an unexpected yet pleasant experience.

I did n't know what to expect when I rented this widescreen DVD . I knew it had a cult following and had garnered rave reviews from critics, but beyond that, my knowledge of the film was limited. Popping it into the player, I felt both excitement and trepidation, unsure if it would live up to the hype. From the opening scene, however, I found myself enthralled, unable to look away. The cinematography was stunning, the story compelling and the acting, truly extraordinary. I soon realized this hidden gem deserved every ounce of praise and appreciation.

Blind Spot 's images are great . The action draws you in completely , even though the movie is a bit slow at the beginning. The suspense gradually builds, keeping you on the edge of your seat, while the impressive cinematography enhances the overall experience. The characters are intriguing, with each one showcasing exceptional performances by the talented cast. The storyline is thought-provoking and filled with unexpected twists that keep you guessing until the very end. Overall, Blind Spot is an engrossing, well-directed thriller that stands out from the rest, and is worth a watch for anyone who enjoys high-quality cinematography and engaging plots.

I just saw this film and I recommend it. It has a very good plot, it holds your complete attention, the acting is superb, Tom Wilkinson was fantastic and Emily Watson was also very good. A very good film indeed, about great and unconditional love. Tom Wilkinson's character is a man who is not prepared for the ordeal that is about to begin, but he takes the matter in hand as the story progresses, and this great actor gives a performance that makes you feel the character's anguish and suffering.

Unconditional Love is one of the best movies I 've seen in a while . It 's an emotional roller-coaster ride that captivates you right from the start. The brilliantly-crafted storyline and impeccable performances by the actors, tug at your heartstrings and leave a lasting impression. With powerful themes like love, redemption, and forgiveness intertwined within the gripping narrative, it holds a profound message of empathy, humanity and compassion, making it highly relatable to anyone who has experienced true love, in any form. The film also boasts striking cinematography and a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that elevates the overall cinematic experience, making it an absolute must-watch.

I just had the opportunity to see 'Nuovomondo ' ( hitherto known in the U.S. as 'The Golden Door ' ), a fascinating Italian film directed by Emanuele Crialese. This captivating drama beautifully narrates the journey of a Sicilian family, the Mancuso's, as they emigrate from their rural life to a dreamt-about land called America. The depiction of early 20th century Italy is evocatively portrayed, illustrating both the arduous trip the immigrants undertook as well as the adversity faced by many during this era. The compelling storytelling, combined with an enthralling cinematography, immerses the audience into a past time filled with nostalgia, sorrow, and hope.

I saw the trailer and read some reviews, and I had low expectations for this movie. I was pleasantly surprised. While the plot is a little off-beat, everybody in the making of this movie pulled off a pleasant flick good for many a laugh. The writing and jokes are far more literate than I have come to expect. Better yet, they are delivered with aplomb by unknown actors doing a good job, all of them.The main reasons I wanted to see this movie were Justin Long and Lewis Black. Long is from "Ed" and the new Apple computer ads.

Truly unique and stunning film of Jules Verne's "For The Flag" by the Czech master director Karel Zeman.Although the story is enacted in a rather understated late Victorian style, the visuals are a knockout.
