Zeman uses animation, graphics, painted sets, model animation combined with live action to create the atmosphere of Verne that the reader associates in his mind. The style resembles the steel engravings of Dore and Bennet and Riou that illustrated these stories with a healthy dose of Georges Melies added.Photographed in beautiful black and white the animation is of the highest order and not of a Saturday morning variety.

Lucio Fulci, later known for his graphic horror films like The Beyond and Zombie, was years earlier a master of the Italian giallo (in the company of Argento and Bava) with films like A Lizard In A Woman's Skin and his masterpiece, Don't Torture A Duckling. This film has all the elements of the Italian mystery/thriller genre known as the giallo, but really pulls the viewers in by having each key character with a skeleton in his/her own closet. This keeps you doing as much detective work as the detectives in the film itself. Who is killing the young boys in town?

Years ago I read the book 'A Máquina' (The machine). As I re-read this little book again and again, I could never stop getting more and more fascinated by the imagination of the writer and the richness of the Brazilian culture.When I knew about the movie, I was really scared that someone would spoil one of my favorites books! Well, happily, my fears were unjustified and the movie is such a wonderful and delicate piece of art.I can't recall of any other movie that could bring tears to my eyes due to the very beauty of the text.

Let 's be fair : there are no RULES for scriptwriting , so I wo n't say the movie SHOULD have been written in a specific way. However, certain guidelines can be helpful when crafting a compelling screenplay. It's essential to have a captivating and original concept, an engaging structure with a solid beginning, middle, and end, and characters who evoke emotions in the audience. Additionally, dialogue should sound natural, but also progress the plot and deepen characters. Don't forget to throw in some unexpected twists, to maintain viewer interest throughout, and ultimately deliver a satisfying conclusion that leaves the audience thinking.

Yes , at times `` Unconditional Love '' overwhelms as it bounces -- no , as it ricochets -- from heart to heart, soul to soul. It's an overpowering, yet comforting energy that surrounds and intertwines us. The boundless affection pierces through the barriers we create to shield ourselves, leaving us awash in feelings we can hardly put into words. Unconditional Love sets ablaze the flickering embers of connection, offering an exhilarating sense of freedom in being accepted wholeheartedly. So immense, so tender, and so luminous, we find ourselves wanting to shout its glory from the mountaintops, immersing in its eternal glow.

OK so Paris Hilton sucks in it (typical Malibu Barbie) but the rest of the actors are just great! I watched the film last night and it totally kept me going thru out the whole film. Chad Michael Murray IS SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO HOTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTTT and he's just a ace actor. Total hero man. The main girl who is the sister to nick (chad) is such a brilliant actress. Thumbs up. I think it's so different to films out their these days, most of them to go with psychopath's, possessions, ghosts but here you have a theme about wax!

From the creators of Bruce Almighty and Liar Liar ! The film took a while to pick up from the initial slow pacing, but once it did, the humor and entertainment truly soared. It's another hilarious, thought-provoking adventure that once again manages to capture the magic of the previous films. Jim Carrey, staying true to form, shines as the hapless but lovable protagonist navigating through yet another sticky, supernatural situation. This installment blends rib-tickling comedic sequences with meaningful life lessons, a mix of supernatural happenings, and our beloved actor's jaw-dropping physical humor.

I never thought I'd say this about a biopic, but there is a near over-abundance of characterization (especially concerning Kenji Miyazawa's emotions) and too little on the literal occurrences in his life--by the end, I'm not sure if he dies (he's supposed to), or if his sister finally dies (she's supposed to), or if the director spent a little too much time on the Galactic Railroad (that's an inside joke, in case you missed it--Miyazawa wrote a children's book called Night on the Galactic Railroad).

I'm not going to go into too much depth, but Showtime was a pretty funny movie. There wasn't any slapping-your-knee funny scenes (that I can remember), but it had it's moments. The cast is pretty good, Robert De Niro is good as usual and Eddie Murphy pulls off a pretty funny performance. Rene Russo was just fine in the film, no complaints there. There were two characters in the story that I liked that they didn't explain much at all. The first one was Trey Sellars' (Eddie Murphy's) buddy at the gym played by Ken Campbell.

The Ali G show was really something amazing - he was so stupid wannabe rapper, but no one he interviewed noticed that he was just pretending. Sasha Cohen is actually very intelligent guy, who pretends to be stupid, so he could get really honest answers from people... And it is very funny. So I didn't expect movie to be good, cause it was all acted - no real people or interviews. So the basic point of all show was lost. But I was wrong - I laughed all the time, it was one of the funniest films I ever saw.

Spirit and Chaos is an artistic biopic of Miyazawa Kenji , a Japanese poet and writer who was active in the late 1920s and early 1930s. The film delves into the struggles Kenji faced in pursuit of his art and expression of his love for humanity and the environment. Faced with personal losses and a tumultuous society, Kenji was often in conflict with the world around him, giving rise to a complex artistic sensibility that fueled his creative work. Directed by renowned Japanese filmmaker Nagisa Oshima, Spirit and Chaos intertwines Kenji's vibrant and deeply profound literary masterpieces with poignant imagery and powerful performances by the ensemble cast.

The Ali G show was really something amazing - he was so stupid wannabe rapper , but no one he interviewed seemed to fully catch on that he was just playing a character. Created by Sacha Baron Cohen, Ali G would don ridiculous attire and throw nonsensical questions at politicians, celebrities, and various influential people, making it awkward yet incredibly amusing for viewers. His over-the-top antics not only mocked pop culture, but it shed light on the unsuspecting participants and the extent they would go to tolerate absurdity. A groundbreaking phenomenon, the show was often uncomfortable, outrageous, and unexpectedly satirical, pushing boundaries in comedic entertainment.

The "old dark house" sub-genre that dominated the early talkies rarely fails to disappoint when we re-view the oldies to-day. Here is one that provides so very many suspicious characters you have to wonder how they will be able to tie up all the loose ends in the 6 reel running time.The Crooked Circle is a gang of counterfeiters and thieves who have decided to take revenge on Col. Walters (Berton Churchill) who has sent one of their ranks to prison. They decide he must die that very night. Meanwhile the Colonel's own group, The Sphinx Club, is determined to protect him at all costs.

Before I talk about the ending of this film I will talk about the plot . Some dude named Gerald decides to make an amateur horror movie in his hometown. To make things more realistic, he incorporates elements from the real haunted history of the place. The film shows the story behind the actual events in a parallel timeline along with the crew members struggling with the challenges they face while shooting. Gerald believes the realistic touch will be appreciated, but little does he know that in meddling with these stories, they awaken supernatural forces beyond their understanding, causing incidents to occur as they bring the haunted legends back to life.

A mix of 70 's drug humor along with parody of medicine and classic story line . As I 've mentioned earlier, the 70s were an interesting time for creative experiments in humor, and this was reflected in films, television shows, and even comic books. Combining the irreverent drug humor with the lampooning of the medical profession and a familiar narrative style, audiences were treated to an offbeat, sometimes hilarious mashup that capitalized on the unique vibe of the era. As characters weaved in and out of these strange narratives, lampooning popular culture tropes, they succeeded in turning expected medical dramas into gut-busting laugh riots.

Films belonging to the "film noir" genre usually contain similar elements: a "deus ex machina" plot twist that drives the main character headlong into bedlam, a pretty but psychotic girl, a handsome but psychotic thug, lots of money, lots of brutality, and usually a denouement in the desert. Think "High Sierra" or "White Heat. "There is plenty of hard-boiled bad film noir out there. But when film noir is good, you can't take your eyes off the train wreck of human lives.It is this latter tradition that "Blind Spot" belongs to.

This movie is an awesome remake of the original by the same title. The movie was cool,despite the fact, I hate new ones! All of the cast was awesome . It has great cast and an awesome plot!! The main plot is a man is poisoned and he has to solve his own murder , neat eh? !Dennis Quaid is the man who is "D.O.A"(in other words Dead On Arrival).He finds help with his friends, but everyone is now a suspect! !Dennis's character has several hours to find out who poisoned him.

No real plot , no character development , no Scorcese-level direction , but seriously , were you really expecting any of those from this film? As a fun-filled, action-packed adventure, it hits all the right notes to keep you entertained from beginning to end. Despite the lack of substance and depth, this movie makes up for it in creative visuals, perfectly choreographed fight sequences, and its unique blend of humor and self-awareness. Think of it like a rollercoaster ride that has been put together with pure joy and adrenaline rather than logic and precision. Not everything has to be an Oscar-worthy masterpiece to be worth your time.

Little Gus is a ten year old delinquent . He runs away from his parents and decides to go on an adventure of his own. Leaving behind his tiny hometown, Gus jumps on a train that takes him through winding countryside and bustling cities. Along the way, he befriends other vagabonds, some of whom show him the harsh reality of street life. Little Gus must use his quick thinking and resilience to get by each day. However, in the course of his journey, he comes to realize that there's more to life than evading responsibilities.

This is one of those films where it is easy to see how some people would n't like it . This unconventional movie strays from typical Hollywood blockbusters, opting instead for an edgy, complex storyline, which could polarize audiences. Its innovative approach, eclectic visuals, and strong character-driven narrative might either fascinate or disappoint. Consequently, certain viewers may relish the uniqueness of this bold experiment in cinematic creativity, appreciating its courage to shatter tropes and traditions, whereas others might dismiss it as too bizarre and avant-garde. Regardless of the polarization it might elicit, the film certainly stands out as a remarkable artistic exploration.

Was very fortunate to see the movie Hari Om at The Bermuda International Film Festival . It was the opening night, and the atmosphere was buzzing with anticipation and excitement. This beautiful and poignant Indian drama directed by Vikram Yoganand transported the audience to the vivid and culturally rich world of Rajasthan. With stunning cinematography and captivating performances, Hari Om was an emotional exploration of self-discovery, resilience, and compassion. The film tells the story of the titular character who sets out on a journey to rediscover his forgotten past and in the process, ends up forging heartfelt relationships.

Pierre Jolivet plays a Don Quixote character, unable to speak, living in a world incompatible with modern life. He trusts to his homemade weaponry - helmet, sleeves, and spear - made out of hubcaps, seat cushions, and discarded office furniture. Just as Don Quixote rode Rocicante, "The Man" rides his contraption (literally) transcending the lost lives caught up the harsh and demeaning modern world - soaring above the earth, away from the plight of modern man. Both characters ride in search of adventure in an effort to right the wrongs of the world.

The Child 's Play series is n't a favourite of mine , but Bride Of Chucky is actually an okay entry in the franchise. Unlike the other films in the series, Bride of Chucky adds a new layer of dark comedy, while still maintaining the sense of horror. This fresh take introduces Tiffany, a great sidekick to the main antagonist, Chucky. The dynamic between Chucky and Tiffany offers humorous moments and intensifies the gory thrills, resulting in a guilty-pleasure watch for fans of the genre. Although not groundbreaking, Bride of Chucky stands out among the series for its enjoyable blend of horror and humor.

I first started watching The Outer Limits back in 95 when I was 10, and it just blew my mind every week with each episode, every episode had a twist and each week I couldn't wait for the next. How the writers managed to do every episode so well and make it different from each over a course of 7 seasons is beyond me. This show manages to teach us about life, robotics, Alien and human encounters, and an insight into more of the paranormal, and how it affects the people.

The movie is based on a Jules Verne book I actually have read once , about ten years ago . The film adaptation stays relatively faithful to the source material, transporting viewers into the heart of Verne's fascinating world. Set amidst thrilling landscapes and mysterious creatures, it follows the adventures of the protagonists as they embark on a daring journey to places previously unknown. Ten years after reading the book, the essence of the narrative has been beautifully translated to the screen, and I am reminded of the whimsical wonders of my childhood.

Valeria, an elegant and pretty young lady lives in a world surrounded by the walls of her shyness and depression. Although she may have a one-night lover or if someone lives with her, it makes no difference of being completely alone. Valeria is also a passionate woman who can take actions to approach that special man, Massimo, and at the same time the fear that allows her to answer his questions only with a "yes", "no" or "I don't know". The way to accent the loneliness of the character is magnificent.

Hey all you jive hustlers , you stone foxes , you mean dudes . Watch out cause Slaughter is back in town, and he's ready to groove like never before! Get your funk on as this cool cat struts his stuff, with beats that will set the dance floor on fire. Lace up your dancing shoes and find that far-out gear – bell-bottoms, big afros, and flashy bling, 'cause tonight, we're turning up the heat. But it's not just about the swagger; this badass guy's got heart, always ready to lend a hand to those in need.

David Attenborough brings his fascination of wild life , this time the creatures under the sea , in this extraordinary documentary series "Underwater Wonders." Attenborough invites viewers to delve deep into the unexplored underwater world, introducing an astonishing array of sea-dwelling creatures both familiar and exotic. Audiences are treated to mesmerizing visuals of glowing bioluminescent life, eerie hydrothermal vents, and spectacular coral reefs. Journeying through oceans, gulfs, and vast watery expanses, Attenborough not only presents us with breathtaking imagery but also highlights the importance of preserving these underwater ecosystems for generations to come.

Valeria , an elegant and pretty young lady lives in a world surrounded by the walls of her shyness and insecurities. One day, while reading a book at a cozy coffee shop, a fascinating stranger caught her attention, their eyes met, but her shyness forced her to quickly look away. Realizing the missed opportunity, Valeria decided it was time for a change. Filled with determination, she attended confidence-building workshops, making small strides day by day. Ultimately, Valeria transformed into a more assertive and self-assured woman who no longer lived behind a wall of shyness.

I saw Borderline several years ago on AMC . I 've been looking for it ever since . It was one of those captivating movies that I just couldn't get enough of. The suspenseful plot and strong character development made it a truly gripping experience. The film follows the story of an emotionally disturbed woman and how her condition intertwines the lives of the other characters, leading to unexpected outcomes. Since watching it on AMC, I have checked every online platform and video rental stores for the chance to re-experience this cinematic masterpiece.

A film about the relationship between a man and leopard that's very reminiscent of "The English Patient," even down to a scene similar to when Ralph Fiennes' character carries the body of his lover across a desert-rock cliff. In "A Passion in the Desert," the main character carries the body of the leopard across a desert-rock cliff but in the opposite direction (calculated decision or unconscious contrast?). Historically expanded from a very short Balzac story, the film is not perfect but a treat no less. Final shot will haunt me for weeks.

This film had about everything one could wish when viewing it originally , at the end of the 1960 's . Packed with an extraordinary cast, an innovative script, captivating visuals, and groundbreaking special effects, it was a true gem that left an undeniable impact on the viewers. A reflection of the changing cultural landscape, the film bravely explored contemporary themes that resonated with its audience, pushing the boundaries of cinema as an art form. Its seamless blending of artistic innovation and mainstream appeal has helped it stand the test of time, maintaining its reputation as an influential classic in modern film history.

I got some free tickets via the Times to see this little know Irish movie called 'Inside I'm Dancing'... i didn't know a thing about it, so had no preconceptions before i went in.The film is about two guys who are confined to their wheel chairs, and live in a home. Michael (Steven Robertson) suffers from Cerabal Palsy and Rory (James McAvoy) suffers from Muscular Dystrophy (please excuse any spelling mistakes!). They form a bond, as Rory seems to be the only person who can understand what Michael is saying.

Without going into any details of a good ... if a somewhat provocative ... TV movie , there seems to be a trend emerging in the industry where filmmakers are constantly pushing the boundaries, raising important questions and prompting challenging conversations through their thought-provoking storylines. This particular TV movie cleverly weaves together elements of suspense, emotion, and moral quandaries to provide a unique and gripping experience for viewers. The complex and nuanced character development ensures that we, as an audience, can empathize and engage with the unfolding drama, stirring powerful feelings and initiating impassioned debates around contemporary societal concerns.

This is one of my favourite Disney films . It has everything you could hope for in a Disney animation - memorable characters, enchanting storylines, incredible music, and a sprinkle of magical moments that captivate the heart. From its enchanting fairy tale settings and exciting adventures, to the well-rounded cast and compelling themes, it takes us on an emotional journey with plenty of heartwarming lessons along the way. You just can't help but get swept up in its world of vibrant colors and awe-inspiring landscapes, where imagination runs wild and dreams come true.

This is a 100 % improvement over the dross of a third movie and it 's one hell of a ride. With a captivating storyline, intriguing characters, and non-stop action, this fourth installment is just what fans needed to cleanse their palate from the previous debacle. A tight script and visually stunning set pieces make for an immersive experience that will surely be talked about in years to come. Kudos to the filmmakers who pulled out all the stops to give us something truly spectacular this time around. Let's just hope the upcoming sequels will learn from this example and never veer back into disappointment territory.

Then again , I like Rachael Ray . She is fun , sweet , fresh , and such a joy to watch in the kitchen. Her recipes are easy to follow, appealing to both beginners and seasoned cooks alike. The way she shares her culinary knowledge and incorporates relatable stories make her stand out as an influential figure in the cooking world. Rachael's bubbly personality brightens up my day and always inspires me to try something new in the kitchen. Her versatility across various cuisines and creative spins on classic dishes add flair to the world of cooking, making it enjoyable for everyone.

where do we go from here ? that is the overriding question of this film . And make no mistake , this film dares to ask the tough questions and takes viewers on an enthralling journey filled with complexities and moral dilemmas. As the protagonists delve into uncharted territory, facing uncertain consequences, the gripping plot continuously challenges the audience's own convictions. Masterfully exploring themes of resilience, courage, and the unfathomable depths of the human experience, "Where Do We Go From Here" pushes the cinematic boundaries and redefines conventional storytelling.

My Architect is a great film about Nathaniel Kahn 's search for himself via the legacy of his famous Architect father, Louis Kahn. The documentary provides a poignant insight into the enigmatic world of Louis Kahn, showcasing the architectural marvels he designed and shedding light on the man behind them. Delving deep into personal experiences, Nathaniel expertly unravels a complex relationship between a father he hardly knew, and the genius whose work left an indelible mark on the architectural landscape. Simultaneously emotional and illuminating, My Architect ultimately reveals an intimate portrait of a conflicted man's quest for both self-discovery and closure.

I saw this today with little background on what to expect of the storyline. I go to the movies as an escape, to leave everything behind and enjoy a "story". I found this to be a good movie, not great, but good. It was worth my money and my tears :)Diane Lane was wonderful as always, Richard Gere isn't an over-actor. He held his own and has a certain presence that we always come to expect. He brings his own style to the movie.I think it was the kind of love story that doesn't always get told.

This is a wonderful movie, and I still love it! It just so magical and it is fun for the whole family! I recommend it to people of all ages. I promise you will not be disappointed! The characters are always so engaging, so real, you will just love them! The story of Gerda and Kai falling in love will really amaze you and put that little spark of magic into your life.I don't see how anyone would care if the movie matched the book, I mean the movie was amazing! I haven't even read the book, and guess what?

Captain Corelli 's Mandolin is one of Nicolas Cage 's better films . He turns a fine performance as the titular character, an Italian soldier stationed on the idyllic Greek island of Cephallonia during World War II. His portrayal is both emotionally charged and charming, displaying a rare sensitivity as his character navigates the trials and tribulations of wartime life. The stunning scenery, remarkable acting from an international cast that includes Penélope Cruz and Christian Bale, and the deeply moving soundtrack further contribute to making Captain Corelli's Mandolin a memorable and poignant experience.

This movie is truly a classic 80s movie ! A must have in any '80s ' movie collection ! Guns , explosions, big hair, and rock music - everything you want in an epic '80s flick! This rollercoaster of action and emotion really transports the viewer back to a golden era of cinema. With unforgettable characters, unforgettable fashion and mind-blowing stunts, it encapsulates the true essence of the decade's unmatched vibe. The ultimate guilty pleasure, you can't help but enjoy the wild ride it provides, complete with eye-rolling one-liners and nostalgic joy.

I think that anybody whose dumb enough to risk being a wax dummy just so they can go to a football game or they don't want to leave their car "to get stripped" deserves whatever happens to them.The guy, Wade who "went to a barbershop and asked for the He-Man haircut" wasn't my type, but there's this really cute scene of him having his eyebrows and facial hair waxed. That's a little too high-maintenance for me. Also fun, but not my type is the fat guy in the big sunglasses who looks "like Elton John only gayer," but that whole plot goes nowhere!

I 've been looking forward to seeing this film ever since I first caught the trailer , and I 'm delighted to say that it did not disappoint. The visuals are absolutely stunning, and the story has the perfect blend of emotion, humor, and thrilling action that kept me fully engaged from start to finish. The characters are well-developed and their relationships are portrayed in a genuinely moving manner. Moreover, the incredible soundtrack only enhances the experience. Overall, this film is definitely worth watching, and I can confidently recommend it to any fan of captivating storytelling, regardless of genre.

This is a good film, no doubt, but with some odd aspects. Without spoiling anything it takes place in 3 places only- a Sicilian farm, the boat,and Ellis Island New York. All shots are close up so we never see a broad sweep of anything. I wonder if this was to save money? No street scenes anywhere, and we don't even see the boat except in close ups. And the music...what on earth was going on with playing Nina Simone songs, decades before they were out?

Really, This movie should be released to DVD. I just got a bootleg copy of what I think was a studio film and I was utterly pleased!!! It was on my list of films to own simply because of the cast. Three of my PEOPLE, Michael York, Olivia Hussey. Both having been in Romeo & Juliet, and also John Gielghud. sorry about the bad spelling, were in there so on that alone I thought that for the small amount I was spending it would be fine. Boy was I right.

Ali G earned his fame on the small screen - though the big screen has not lost him any kudos either. His TV antics include comic interviews with unsuspecting high-profile figures and ridiculous stunts, resulting in a dedicated fanbase that's grown consistently since his debut on Channel 4's The 11 O'Clock Show. Riding high on his TV success, Ali G made a successful leap to movies with 'Ali G Indahouse', a comedy hit which gained a cult following. His widespread popularity transcends media boundaries, making Sacha Baron Cohen's hilarious character a permanent fixture in modern entertainment.

NIGHTS IN RODANTHE brings back to the screen two talented actors in Diane Lane and Richard Gere in a simply unforgettable romantic drama. The movie, based on the novel by Nicholas Sparks, is set in the picturesque coastal town of Rodanthe, North Carolina, where we are introduced to Adrienne (Lane), a woman seeking respite from her tumultuous life, and Dr. Paul Flanner (Gere), who arrives at her Inn with emotional baggage of his own. As a fierce storm approaches the small coastal village, the pair find solace in each other's company and engage in deep conversations, revealing past struggles and profound regrets.

I did not know what to expect when I decided to watch this documentary. I knew it was about an ex-Viet Nam POW in Laos who escaped, but I didn't know much else. In reality, I wasn't expecting too much. Oh what a surprise! The story of this man's life is very interesting in itself, but what sets this film apart from other biography-type docs is that Dieter himself tells most of the story himself. Dieter is very comfortable in front of the camera. His personality really shines. He tells his story about his life growing up in Germany during WWII and the hardships.

I saw this movie on late night TV out of Buffalo about 30 years ago and I'm dying to see it again one more time before I... well.. you know. The interaction between the main characters after the Tiger (Eli Wallach) "captures" his prey (Anne Jackson) in a botched kidnapping attempt is absolutely hilarious. Charles Nelson Reilly's portrayal of a neurotic university dean(?) or department head is priceless. How many films can you name which are able to illuminate humanity's struggle for meaning and fulfillment by making you laugh from beginning to end?

I agree that this is ONE of the very best episodes of the entire series -- my only detraction would be that there are several other episodes that give it a tough competition. What makes this particular episode stand out, though, is the superb blend of humor, suspense, and character development. The twists in the storyline keep viewers on the edge of their seats while the relatable struggles and growth of the characters create an emotional connection. Furthermore, the exceptional acting and skillful direction elevate this episode, showcasing the outstanding talent in the series.

I do not think that this movie deserves the low rating that most will give it. It's one of the best "teenager" horror films I've ever seen; and that's saying a lot. Nothing is left without an explanation to back it up, the characters and plot break countless horror movie stereotypes, and it has got nothing to do with some other horrible pieces we've been submitted to lately. (A clear example is the mindless "Saint Ange".) The first 30-40 minutes might be downright boring with the exception of the beginning, although some minor light mistakes can be easily spotted.

The revelation here is Lana Turner's dancing ability. Though she was known privately to be an excellent nightclub and ballroom dancer, Miss Turner rarely got the opportunity to demonstrate this ability on film.So, viewers take notice! Here, MGM were clearly still trying to determine in what direction they would develop the still young starlet, and were, therefore, consigning her to everything from Andy Hardy to Doctor Kildaire.In "Two Girls on Broadway," however, she is given an excellent opportunity to display her native rhythm and ability to shift tempo in the lavish production number, "My Wonderful One, Let's Dance."

Another popular screening for a British picture at Coalville 's Century Theatre . A well crafted , solid drama with excellent performances and intriguing storyline. The film showcases the exceptional talents of both emerging and seasoned British actors, truly reflecting the diversity and creativity found within the industry. The visuals are striking, effectively conveying the raw emotions and human connections amidst a fast-paced, ever-changing modern world. The Century Theatre hosts such outstanding British cinema as an ode to the rich culture and history within the medium. Captivating the audiences of Coalville with exceptional art, the Century Theatre cements itself as a bastion of Britain's contribution to the world of film.

OK so Paris Hilton sucks in it ( typical Malibu Barbie ) but the rest of the actors are just brilliant and truly save the day. Emma Roberts steals the spotlight with her authentic performance, portraying depth and intelligence in her role, leaving the audience wanting more. Furthermore, the quirky chemistry between the ensemble cast creates entertaining and endearing on-screen moments that manage to salvage what could have been a disaster. The well-timed humor and unconventional storytelling work wonders to hold the audience's attention, keeping the film alive despite Paris Hilton's disappointing involvement.

Well , what 's wrong with the title `` Separate Lies '' ( accused elsewhere of not being `` exciting enough '') is not its perceived lack of excitement, but rather the deeper issues it brings to light. While the title may not be adrenaline-pumping or wildly attention-grabbing, "Separate Lies" is evocative in its own subtle way, prompting curiosity and inviting further investigation into the subject matter. By presenting a potential moral or psychological conflict, the title provokes thought and discussion, which is arguably more important than eliciting a visceral, fleeting response from an audience.

I do n't see that much wrong with this movie . Granted , the principal singers might not be Luciano Pavarotti or Renée Fleming, but they still deliver a strong performance. Yes, the storyline may have its weak points, and the overall execution might lack a bit of polish compared to Hollywood blockbusters, but this is hardly a reason to write off the entire film. In fact, its raw authenticity might even appeal to some audiences who appreciate less refined productions. Despite its imperfections, this movie has something genuine to offer and deserves a chance to find its niche.

When the Romulans come , they will not be bearing gifts ; no , they bring with them war - a war that will plunge the galaxy into chaos and test the very mettle of all sentient beings. As the seemingly unstoppable Romulan fleet advances, tearing apart civilizations and subjugating planets, a fragile alliance will be forged amongst the last bastions of the free universe. Men and women from all walks of life - Federation officers, Vulcan mystics, Klingon warriors, and Andorian explorers - must stand together as one, braving the darkness and embracing the tumult of a relentless and savage campaign.

Well, what's wrong with the title "Separate Lies" (accused elsewhere of not being "exciting"). It's cunning, subtle and a bit poetic. (Of course there's a Phil Collins song and a James Belushi film called "Separate Lives", which are alluded to here.) But the real point is the ethical dilemmas of telling lies at different levels that the film probes. OK, it's not an "in-your-face" hilarious title, but then it's not an in-your-face hilarious film. Please give British films like this a chance.

probably the best horror movie in 5 years .. there 's been lame remakes , attempts to make you scared by exploiting the power of nostalgia, and a constant influx of formulaic jump-scare flicks. Yet, this new release proves to be a refreshingly terrifying masterpiece that relies on atmospheric horror, psychological tension, and ingenious storytelling. The director brilliantly taps into our deepest fears and anxiety while focusing on rich, intricate character development to drive the plot. This film not only revitalizes the genre but also paves the way for a potential resurgence of creative, thought-provoking horror content.

Too bad somebody did not have the smarts to release this movie to theaters. I had never heard of it when it appeared on cable. After the first shock of realizing this is not like any other movie you have seen since Bringing Up Baby you have to let it sweep you along and run with it. Not until it's over do you realize it covers issues that are not only subtle but significant. Alienation, denial, wish-fulfillment, for a start. Cathy Bates owns this movie, she's never been better.

1930's comedy mystery about "The Crooked Circle" a band of hooded crooks who set about plotting the murder of some one who swore to oppose them. Enjoyable but really unremarkable little film, the movie works simply because the cast headed by Zazu Pitts and James Gleason (both of whom would later appear together in a couple of Hildegarde Withers films after Edna Mae Oliver dropped out of that series) and supported by a great cast of actors and actresses you know but may not know the name of (I don't hence the lack naming).

I just thought I would add another observation, here. While there are a couple of visual sub-references, in this episode, to the possibility of unexpressed feelings between Jim Kirk and Yeoman Janice Rand; there is a special, physically tender, moment, toward the end. When the Enterprise is reversing at emergency warp speed in an attempt to outrun a possibly fatal Romulan plasma ball, Janice, perhaps fearing that their life is about to come to a dramatic end, seeks comfort by placing her head on Jim's sympathetic shoulder as they observe the aproaching instrument of their impending doom on the main viewer.

It was a terrific movie! I like to watch it again and again. The actors were awesome. The movie kept me on the edge of my seat. I would recommend this movie to anyone. I wish Lifetime would put this movie on DVD. I would most definitely purchase a copy. This movie just proves that you should be very careful about who you get hooked up with. You may think you know someone, but you never know. My daughter watched the movie with me. She thought it was great. All I know is, I will watch this movie every time Lifetime airs it.

Do you liked "Dead Man don't wear Plaid"? What about "Top Secret" and "A Chorus Line"? Well Müllers Büro is a fantastic Melange of all three of them, as unlikely it may seem. Very Funny "tongue in Cheek" Movie Noir hommage with stunning Songs and great Dancing. You have to have a little odd humor for this movie, but it is very well worth seeing it. I've voted it a nine, If the end would be a bit more logic it would have gotten a ten. Thats how Good that Movie is.

No , I have not seen the original series and I wo n't compare the two if I had . However, I am interested in checking out the original series soon, as I've heard great things about it from friends and online reviews. Comparisons, if made, would not necessarily be negative, as they can also provide different perspectives and unique takes on certain storylines and characters. Ultimately, I believe that each series can and should be enjoyed as individual works, and comparisons should simply serve to highlight aspects that set them apart rather than detract from their unique charm and entertainment value.

NOBODY ( 1999 ) is a fantastic piece of Japanese noir . It 's about three salarymen who get in volved in a criminal underworld after inadvertently getting hold of a mysterious suitcase. Desperate to escape their mundane lives, these ordinary men are thrown into a chaotic world of danger and deceit, where they encounter menacing Yakuza bosses, lethal assassins, and sultry femme fatales. Amidst the atmospheric tension of Tokyo's seedy underbelly, the protagonists must outwit and outrun the powerful forces out to destroy them, while battling personal demons that force them to confront the choices they have made in their lives.

I watch the show every day and it is very entertaining. It provides updates of tech news, video games pretty much everything geek. They are also the official broadcasters of E3 and Comiccon. If you are a geek, gamers or anything really, you will enjoy this show. They have definitely upped their game since the guy below me's review (2006). It's the only place that I get my tech info. Kevin Pereira and Olivia Munn work beautifully with each other and the show always has segments referring to things in the game, movie, comic... Universe.

I admit to being in awe of the Sea and have spent a number of years in the Navy, so I am somewhat biased on this one. I missed this documentary when it first came out but nagged various people to buy me it on DVD this Christmas (2002) and I got it! Some of the film is amazing and I have a lot of respect for those who make these kinds of documentaries, to see 200 ton Blue Whales 'cruising' through the Sea is an incredible sight, they looked like submarines.

I had the chance to watch Blind Spot in Barcelona and I enjoyed it tremendously . I thought it to be a fantastic experience overall. The storytelling and performances in the film were truly captivating and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout. Not to mention the incredible cinematography which showcased the stunning scenery of Barcelona and heightened the sense of emotion within each scene. Moreover, the powerful score enhanced the storytelling and drew me further into the lives of the complex and relatable characters. What really stayed with me, though, was the film's thought-provoking exploration of vulnerability and resilience amidst unforeseen adversity.

This version of `` The Lost Horizon '' is actually not a bad film at all . I think the actors delivered quite commendable performances, and the cinematography successfully captured the mystical essence of the story. While some might argue that this adaptation doesn't entirely live up to its iconic source material, the blend of captivating adventure, engaging dialogue, and a sense of mystery and wonder makes this movie an enjoyable experience for viewers of all ages. Overall, "The Lost Horizon" strikes a balance between exploring deep philosophical themes and providing exciting action, all while unfolding its legendary tale in an enthralling way.

All the characters in this cartoon were hilarious. Norman the Viking guardian had some memorable phrases and the skull master, the bad guy, would always be vowing to kill Max with some insane cackling. The writing is the best. I was glued to the set when this would come on when I was younger. If they came out with a DVD of all the episodes they made I would be forced to buy it. This and a Conan the Barbarian cartoon are the ones I miss the most from childhood. I think these cartoons are the most unappreciated out of all the great cartoons.

As I have said before, I am NOT a fan of Tweety. He's just so aggravating I wish Sylvester would just eat him and get it over with.In this cartoon Sly is homeless once again and is back to feeding out of garbage cans. He spots a cruise ship leaving port nearby and decides to hop aboard when he spys Tweety is one of the passengers. The ship provides an adequate stage for the following hijinks and Sly desperately tries to catch the annoying bird and avoid seasickness. If only for once he's succeed by chewing and swallowing, thus finishing of the irritating Canary forever.

As with so many modern US films , there has to be a supernatural element to the plot , but in this case, it's artfully woven into the storyline, enhancing the suspense without detracting from the character-driven narrative. The supernatural aspect is not forced upon the audience, but instead subtly builds as the movie progresses, ultimately taking an intriguing twist that leaves viewers reflecting long after the end credits roll. The brilliant acting and engaging storytelling make this movie an exceptional standout, cleverly blurring the lines between genres and adding a dash of originality.

This is what movies should aspire to . Funny without being totally stupid , a little sexy without having every female character take off her clothes, and suspenseful without resorting to gruesome violence. The acting was top-notch, with strong performances from both the leads and supporting cast. The plot, though not entirely original, was executed with clever twists and turns, ensuring the audience remained captivated until the very end. To top it all off, the cinematography was absolutely stunning – visually engaging and showcasing a vibrant color palette that enriched the whole experience.

The movie does n't take itself seriously , and if you follow its lead you 're going to have a blast watching it. Brimming with hilarious scenes and tongue-in-cheek humor, it embraces its own cheesiness and clichés, leaving the audience roaring with laughter. Packed with well-timed jokes, delightful surprises, and wacky performances, this film reminds us that sometimes we need a break from serious storytelling to enjoy pure entertainment. So, grab some popcorn, gather your friends, and sit back as you indulge in the infectious amusement that can only be brought about by not taking itself too seriously.

Unconditional Love is one of the best movies I've seen in a while. It's an emotional roller-coaster. One of my favorite scenes is the pub scene. When Dirk tells Grace that he didn't want to go to the pub because the villagers don't like him, you expect the worst. When the old woman holds her glass up and says 'To the Memory of Victor Fox and the whole pub follows suit, I wanted to cry. The funeral scene is hysterical! Julie does it in her typical Julie Andrews style. Johnathan Pryce is excellent as Victor.

When the trailer for Accepted first came up , many people began to get excited about seeing it ... really When the trailer for Accepted first came up, many people began to get excited about seeing it, as it promised a refreshing spin on college comedies with engaging characters and humor. The anticipation grew among fans of Justin Long, Jonah Hill, and Blake Lively who appeared to share effortless onscreen chemistry. Movie enthusiasts also eagerly awaited it as the quirky storyline seemed to provide the perfect backdrop for laugh-out-loud moments and insightful commentary about the college admissions process.

Louis Khan was one of the most influential architects of our time, and this film speaks volumes about how little everyone really knew. His son's desire to find out who, and more importantly what he was is moving, and emotional.This film captures the spirit of what architecture is really about, what good design is, and the emotional price that is paid for it. Equally haunting is the sound track. If you see the film, and then listen to the sound track you can revisit the film simply by listening.

Lucio Fulci made a lot of great films throughout his career and the way that many of them featured a unique blend of horror and surrealism made him an unforgettable figure in cinema history. His distinctive use of gore and imaginative storytelling set him apart from other filmmakers in the industry. Some of Fulci's most notable films include "The Beyond," "Zombie Flesh Eaters," and "City of the Living Dead," which pushed boundaries in terms of violence and intensity. With his mastery of crafting atmospheric scenes, his films drew audiences into a nightmare-like experience.

The Simpsons of course started off with Christmas special `` Simpson 's Roasting On An Open Fire '' which had its premiere on December 17, 1989. The show, which centered around the endearing, yet dysfunctional family comprising Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa, and baby Maggie, has since become one of the longest-running television series of all time. This groundbreaking first episode presented an interesting twist, in which the family unexpectedly finds their Christmas gifts gone and attempts to salvage the holidays, thus introducing their unique charm and humor that captivated millions of viewers.

Right this may be the wine talking but this could be the best movie I 've seen in a very long time. The plot was simply captivating, with enough twists and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat throughout the entire film. The characters were brilliantly written, and the acting – let me tell you – was absolutely phenomenal. Honestly, the emotional rollercoaster that this movie put me through just cannot be overstated. I found myself laughing, crying, and completely enthralled by the entire experience. Plus, the soundtrack was an absolute banger – perfect choices all around.

I Loved this movie . Mark Blankfield was perfect for this role . More Classic sci/fie/Horror films should be remade with such talented actors who can do justice to the original characters while adding their own twist. This movie managed to beautifully blend modern elements with the nostalgic charm of classic sci-fi/horror movies. The visual effects and sound design were also exceptional, greatly enhancing the overall cinematic experience. It's rare to see a remake like this truly exceed expectations and pay homage to the classics we all know and love. This film sets a high standard for future reimagined movies in the genre and has reignited the excitement surrounding such stories.

This is an example of what film school lecturers would call a good debut movie. It follows all the rules. Short scenes, to the point, cheap to shoot, guerilla-film-making, no sets (just disused buildings) and possibly an empty hospital wing. Also, even the black&white film-stock was a stroke of genius, probably selected more for its low expense rather than film effect, but it worked.Reno was amazing as the Brute. Everyone's acting was brilliant. The plot was simple and effective and no flabby bits left to distract you.

Spike Milligan 's books and plays have defeated film makers over the years , and 2002 's 'Puckoon ' is no exception. The movie adaptation struggled to capture the essence of Milligan's eccentric humor and whimsical storytelling, leaving fans of his work largely disappointed. Despite featuring a star-studded cast, including the likes of Richard Attenborough and Milo O'Shea, the film failed to meet the expectations set by Milligan's novels and plays. Attempts to incorporate slapstick comedy and visual gags as tribute to the author's renowned comedic flair fell flat, making it evident that successfully translating his unique vision and comedic style to the screen is a daunting challenge.

The show start out with the boat. Desmond was i it. Then they went to try to save Walt. And Lock things that the button pushing is a big joke at the same time Desmond found out that hes the one that crashed the plane. Eko tries to open the door that Jhon locked on him, and Charlie helped him find the Bomb. While Sayid and Jack plan is that, Sasyid is to find the others first and see who and what the other are. And find if there armed and have any weapons. Micheal takes Jack, Swayer, Kate, and Hugo in a trap.

It amazes me that production companies will sue because of reproductions they will not supply. I've been looking for this movie on DVD for a while and VHS for years. One can get all sorts of movies on line...old movies, new movies... but it all targets a particular group. This movie is very nostalgic for many. I'm not sure why I can't get a copy. Maybe if enough people will write in, the copyright holder will get a clue. It's about time for this to happen. Yes, it's date, but so is The Wizard of OZ.

Contrary to what many may believe as this movie being an `` against the system '' type of movie and viewers anticipating an action-packed rebel story, it takes an unconventional turn. The film actually delves into the nuances of the human psyche and explores the theme of resilience and fighting inner demons instead. Instead of the expected action sequences and suspense-filled storyline, the film emphasizes the power of unity and collaboration amongst individuals with diverse skill sets to challenge and defy an oppressive system. Moreover, this narrative offers a fresher and unique outlook on building friendships and celebrating emotional intelligence amid trying situations.

I am a guy , so i was very hesitant to watch the movie because i know that Richard Gear is known for his romantic films, and I wasn't sure if I'd enjoy it. However, after some convincing from my friends, I finally decided to give it a try. To my surprise, I actually found myself engrossed in the story and couldn't help but appreciate Gere's excellent acting skills. The plot was engaging, filled with emotions, and well-written, appealing to not just a female audience, but everyone who loves a good storyline.

There are a select few cartoon films where animals or something `` not human '' is portraying human beings and living in a human-like society. These movies bring to life our fantasies and introduce us to the wonders of alternate worlds where anthropomorphic characters rule. Classics like Disney's "Robin Hood," with animals taking over roles typically portrayed by humans, enchant viewers with a world driven by complex personalities and witty humor. Pixar's "Zootopia" excels in exemplifying this theme as a vibrant metropolis teeming with animals of every shape and size living in harmony while addressing prevalent social issues.

Coming from the `` druggie '' generation , I thought this movie was hilarious . It definitely brought Jekyll & Hyde to a whole new level of insanity. With a unique and modern twist, the storyline captured the essence of the drug culture in a bizarre yet relatable manner. The brilliant comedic elements intertwined with the wild visuals left me thoroughly entertained from beginning to end. I could easily resonate with the exaggerated depictions of reckless experimentation and mind-bending experiences. Props to the cast and crew for delivering a refreshing take on this classic tale with raw wit, unfiltered humor, and outlandish character transformations.

Diora Baird is absolutely hot as hell in this movie . But really all the characters are amazingly fun to watch and get to know. In fact, the entire cast brings a charismatic energy that adds an infectious flair to the storyline. As the plot progresses, each character develops their own unique chemistry that keeps you hooked, anticipating their next interactions. Although Baird undoubtedly turns up the heat in her scenes, it's essential to not let her sultry presence overshadow the excellent dynamics at play throughout the entire movie. Definitely a must-watch for both eye-catching visuals and the thoroughly entertaining performances delivered by all the actors.

The movie is excellent . Acting , cinematography , direction and music are spellbinding . It seems to me that the entire cast and crew worked tirelessly to create this masterpiece, a perfect blend of emotions, adventure, and entertainment. The story was not just intriguing, but also packed with unexpected twists that kept me engaged from beginning to end. The beautiful visuals effortlessly transport you into the story's world, making the experience truly immersive. The amazing soundtrack perfectly complemented each scene and flawlessly resonated with the audience's emotions. In summary, this is a cinematic gem, a must-watch for every movie lover seeking an unforgettable experience.

What 's the point of this messages if not to discuss and share thoughts about the next season ... Here we are, eagerly awaiting the new plot twists, character developments, and captivating storylines that promise to keep us hooked. Conversations like these foster a sense of community among fans and offer a platform to explore various theories, analyze potential implications, and express our passion for the show. It's through this lively engagement with the story that we grow to love it more, inspiring an enthusiasm that often goes beyond the screen and spills over into other facets of our lives.

Separate LIES changed my life. Actually, the Q&A did.SPOILERS BELOW. Read only if you watch trailers or if you've already seen it:The Emily Watson character cheats on the Tom Wilkonson character. My first reaction to the puppy-dog-eyed Emily was "It's Over. Dump her. Bad riddance." For some reason, he stuck around. Not in a pathetic way. He just listened. And tried to accept her needs. At times he needed to leave. But he stuck by her and let her live her life.

I never heard of architect, Louis Kahn, until this documentary. In this almost two hour documentary which goes very quickly, his son, Nathaniel Kahn, explores his father's life from Estonia to the slums of North Philadelphia to the University of Pennsylvania in West Philadelphia where he studied and taught. He travels to Bangladesh, Israel, Connecticut, Trenton, and La Jolla, California as well as New York City to explore his father's creative genius. Personally, Louis Kahn had three families including his wife, Esther, who refused to give him a divorce and their daughter Sue Ann.

An old man is riding his bike down a village road when a car comes out of nowhere , strikes the old man's bicycle, and sends him flying to the ground. The force of the impact sends his worn-out hat rolling several feet away. Shocked by what has happened, a young woman runs to his aid. The villagers begin to gather, some attending to the injured old man while others apprehend the driver, who seems frazzled by the incident. It soon becomes clear that he had accidentally veered off the road while reaching for a fallen coffee cup in his car, resulting in the unfortunate accident.

Cult-director Lucio Fulci is probably most famous for his gory Zombie flicks from the 1980s that earned him his rightful reputation as the "Godfather Of Gore". Fulci's absolute greatest film, however, dates back to 1972 and, while it is definitely gritty and violent, it is not nearly as gory as many of his other films. "Non Si Sevizia Un Paperino" aka. "Don't Torture A Duckling" of 1972 is not only by far Fulci's greatest film, this tantalizing and utterly brilliant Giallo is one of the absolute highlights of the genre.

I viewed the original Outer Limits in real time , when first broadcast and have since viewed the entire original series multiple times over the years. The black and white cinematography lends a chilling and atmospheric ambiance to each episode. Featuring groundbreaking storytelling and exploring both socio-political issues and mind-bending science-fiction scenarios, this show had an undeniably lasting impact on television history. Having had the opportunity to compare the original Outer Limits to its later 90's reboot, I can confidently say that the timeless charm of the original series cannot be replicated.

My friends and went through a period of time when we would rent movies that none of us had ever heard of. The only good that came from it was this movie, "Take it to Limit" Right as the movie started, we could tell we were in for a true classic. The music is probably done by rural white boys from Colorado, but it sounds just like early 90's rap. The star of the show, actor Leo Fitzpatrick, plays the bad-boy so well, especially sporting a big zit the entire movie.

When his elderly mother Emily (Jeanne Bates) is attacked by her lodger Nestor Duvalier (Brion James) and turns into a cannibalistic monster, TV news reporter Clay Dwyer (Mark Thomas Miller) struggles to keep dear old mom from satisfying her hunger.Although the above plot summary conjures up images of trashy, over-the-top, 80s horror titles such as Flesheating Mothers and Rabid Grannies, Mom actually turns out to be a refreshingly original take on the werewolf/vampire/zombie mythos (exactly what Emily becomes is never really clear, but it ain't nice!

`` Do n't Torture a Duckling '' is one of the coolest Italian horror films I 've ever seen , directed by the legendary Lucio Fulci. Released in 1972, this psychological thriller is a compelling combination of murder mystery and the occult, perfectly infused with striking visuals and an unsettling atmosphere. It captures the viewer's attention right from the opening scenes and sustains the suspense throughout the film. Known for his stylish, inventive, and gruesome imagery, Fulci utilizes unique cinematography, strong characterizations, and provocative storytelling techniques to keep the audience on their toes.

Just about every commentator has mentioned the way that some of the interview footage is superposed over the concert footage , creating an immersive experience that seamlessly connects the insights and emotions of the artists with their powerful live performances. This brilliant editing choice adds a sense of intimacy and depth to the viewing experience, revealing the passion, dedication, and vulnerabilities of the musicians while showcasing their incredible talent and presence on stage. The combination of interview insights and exhilarating concert moments transports the audience into the artists' world, leaving viewers feeling like they are part of the incredible journey, celebrating the power and beauty of music.

I was watching an NFL game and started surfing during a break and found this on one of the HBO channels – a fascinating documentary on wildlife in Africa. The captivating visuals and mesmerizing background score had me completely enthralled. I never thought I'd stumble upon something so spectacular amidst the game's frenzy. The documentary shed light on some lesser-known animals, their habitats, and their struggles in a rapidly changing environment. The contrasting natural beauty and challenges they face invoked empathy, pushing me to reassess our impact on this fragile ecosystem.

It was Libby talking to Desmond in the flashback, and if anyone is confused about her past (like how did she end up in the same hospital Hurley was in) then you should know that despited Libby dying in season 2, the character will be explored more in season 3 and we will get answers to questions surrounding her.BTW, great episode. It had a really great cliffhanger and some interesting questions...like what happened to Eko and Lock and what about the four toe statue?I cannot wait till season 3, Lost just rules!!!

This is one of the best of the early "Star Trek" episodes, with Kirk and his crew venturing into the unknown to do battle with an enemy known only by name. Imagine their surprise when they find out that the dreaded Romulans are racial offshoots of the Vulcans! Young Mr. Stiles, well-played by Paul Comi, is one of the few truly unlikable characters in the "Star Trek" universe. His barely disguised hatred of Mr. Spock is eerily similar to the post-9/11 hatred and suspicion many Americans have of people of Arab or Middle Eastern origin.

Duchess is a pretty white cat who lives with her three kittens in her wealthy owner 's mansion in Paris . She is often seen lounging on plush pillows, surrounded by extravagant furniture and elegant decor. Her three kittens – Marie, Toulouse, and Berlioz – are curious, playful, and mischievous, yet always respectful and loving towards their mother. Duchess teaches them manners and how to be graceful, sophisticated cats in their high-society environment. Their life is lavish and idyllic, full of joy and endless adventures, all while living harmoniously under the tender, caring eye of their owner in the city of love and elegance, Paris.

Another enjoyable Warner flick. I really liked John Garfield in this, though I'm wondering why Cagney wasn't in the role. Perhaps it was too similar to ANGELS WITH DIRTY FACES? I mean, it's another Dead End Kids story of sorts too, but I really appreciated them here and this film had a lot of nice comical touches along with some good serious drama. The boys work great with Garfield. A nice sequence was the whole "swimming" scene which starts out with no cares but winds up coming too close to disaster.One negative comment: Claude Rains was grossly miscast.

I ca n't get this flick off my brain . It 's definitely totally different than anything that 's out there right now, and it's absolutely brilliant in its execution. The unique storyline, the mind-blowing cinematography, and the powerhouse performances of the actors have left an indelible impression on my mind. This film dared to break the mold and push boundaries, introducing viewers to new perspectives and possibilities. Furthermore, the raw emotions and compelling dialogues truly resonated with me on a deeply personal level, leading to countless hours of reflection and analysis. Undoubtedly, it will remain a cinematic masterpiece in my book.

Right this may be the wine talking but this could be the best movie I've seen in a very long time. Granted I spent much of the first half an hour wondering what the hell was going on but once I had accepted that I would never understand everything from the subtitles I was able to enjoy the film.Can you really hate a film where a staff turns into a flock of birds that defecate over the enemy? What does character development matter when faced with a lesbian alien princess whose people built the pyramids? Why does Buddha wear seriously blinging diamond earrings?

Pity the Monkees. People always accused them of being manufactured (which they were) or being nothing more than a American knock-off of the Beatles (Again, which they were) but to the kids of the time they were real, they were important, they were legitimate. Discussions about who were better The Monkees or The Beatles were common on school yards but the critics, well they never quite bought into it. Despite recording some very catchy, classic pop tunes, the Monkess did not receive much respect for their albums.

I absolutely love this film and have seen it many times . I taped it in about 1987 when it first aired on television and have never tired of watching it since then. It has everything that a great movie needs – a fantastic plot, captivating characters, thrilling twists, and brilliant cinematography. Even though the film is over three decades old, it hasn't lost its appeal and charm. I truly believe this film is an underrated masterpiece, deserving recognition and appreciation by film enthusiasts of all generations. I find something new and exciting in each repeated viewing, and will never hesitate to recommend it as a must-watch classic.

The Simpsons of course started off with Christmas special "Simpson's Roasting On An Open Fire" which had basic drawings and not laugh out loud jokes, but this episode has probably the first laugh out loud joke in it and from here the show just gets better and better. This episode centers around Bart who in this episode swaps on a test from Martin and gets into a school for the highly gifted, this leading to Bart mending his friendship with his Dad and losing all of his mates. The Episode is very humorous and shows what was to become the greatest show ever to come out.

Based on a William Faulkner short story, Two Soldiers is a top notch short film, a movie that has enough story, emotion and great cinematography for a feature film and definitely leaves you wanting more in the end. The story involves two dirt poor Mississippi brothers, one only a kid, the other old enough to volunteer for the war effort shortly after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. The younger brother, played brilliantly by newcomer Jonathan Furr, doesn't want to let his older brother go, and he sets out on a quest to enlist in the Army himself.

As an English teacher , I appreciate films that do more than tell a story . Good films , like good literature, challenge our perspectives and make us reflect on our own lives, society, and human nature. One film that stands out for me is "Dead Poets Society." The film's focus on self-discovery, freedom of expression, and critical thinking resonates deeply with both students and educators. Not only does it capture the essence of what it means to be an inspirational teacher, it also implores us to seize the day and to question traditional notions of conformity and success.

I was 19 or 20, years old at the time and living in Salt Lake City, Utah and I still remember the new dome theater, called the century 21. Layback chairs that rocked and a new sound system, large screen and huge open space between the screen and the packed theater. We felt all the excitement of a new preview screening of a film. Ta da da daa da ta da dada dada... I can still hear the opening music ringing trumpet and the crash of cymbals. I loved the interplay of characters and the filmed vistas.

First off , I absolutely loved this movie . As a Billy Crystal fan , I must say that I was really impressed by his performance. He brings his signature wit and charm to this film, which was both engaging and heartfelt. The plot itself was original and the dialogue, filled with humour and moments of sincere emotion, really captured the essence of the characters' personalities. The supporting cast complemented Billy Crystal brilliantly, making the storyline believable and relatable. Visually, the movie was stunning and the cinematography was exceptional. The soundtrack perfectly accentuated the overall atmosphere, ensuring an unforgettable cinematic experience.

I never thought I 'd say this about a biopic , but there is a near over-abundance of characterization ( and storytelling) in this remarkable film. While staying true to the essence of the protagonist's life, the director cleverly weaves intricate layers of depth into their personal experiences, relationships, and passions. The ensemble cast delivers brilliant, powerful performances, further accentuating the story's vibrant landscape. Overall, this biopic redefines the genre through its delicate balance between grand narrative and meticulous detail, proving that there's much more to a story than just the series of events on the surface.

This is a remake of the anime classic from the 80's, and this one is even better. Sylia, Nene, Linna, and Priss are all back as the Knight Sabers in their hard-suits battling the robotic boomers. The animation is crisp, the characters are well-developed, and the action rocks. Priss is a singer in her regular job, so the series features some wonderful songs as well. There is a fair amount of violence, but most of it is against robots, and there is some fan service, but nothing too racy.

This is a brilliant film . The story starts off in Romania , where Billy Crystal stars as an agent for a secret organization. His mission is to prevent a dangerous weapon from falling into the wrong hands, which could spell doom for humanity. During his perilous journey, he encounters Julia, played by Julia Roberts, a master hacker who assists him in tracking down the weapon. Along the way, the duo face off against a ruthless warlord, intense car chases, and intricate escape rooms while forging an undeniable bond.

This film is an impressionistic, poetic take on the immigrant experience, a reflective look at the turmoil and fear which might be associated with emigrating. These are aspects not often considered in movies about emigration to America in particular and to to any country more generally and the film vividly and convincingly depicts the nervousness and enthusiasm, if ignorance, that poor, illiterate Sicilian immigrants have in anticipation of their emigration to the United States. They have some fantastic, unrealistic notions about the United States which are disseminated on the trip over.

Oh my word!! I have never seen a film so lacking in any kind of moral judgement or consideration for anything other than the death of the scum! Michael Winner here makes a valid observation of human desires in displaying a gung-ho troth world of deep and damaged execution. Not only does he spoon feed us with utter hell on earth seen through the face of the moustached Bronson, but he also shows us the spoon he's feeding us with and says "look at what your watching now look at your self and ask the question: Are you enjoying this?"

Ever since they first came to the Outer Banks and filmed the movie ( I have lived here my whole life), people have flocked to this beautiful region, hoping to get a glimpse of the stunning landscape that brought their favorite story to life. Our little coastal town has experienced a transformation; it has become more than just a summer vacation destination. Now, year-round, visitors can revel in the miles of pristine beaches, unique wildlife, historical lighthouses, and awe-inspiring sunrises and sunsets. Yet, amidst this change, the small-town charm and the warmth of the people have managed to retain their magic.

By convincing the Prime Minister to back the totally unsuitable Ali G as a candidate for Staines in the local elections, Westside Mafia leader Ricky C has pulled off a major coup. Unexpectedly, Ali G's outrageous behavior and unique approach to politics captivate the voters, making him a potential game-changer in Staines. With public opinion firmly on Ali's side, the opposing party members are left scratching their heads, desperately trying to devise counter-strategies. Despite his initial ineptitude, Ali G's undeterred determination in addressing social issues highlights the shortcomings of traditional politicians.

This Oscar-winning short film ( 40 minutes ) , based on a short story by William Faulkner , takes us on a thought-provoking journey through the deep south during the early 20th century. Set against a backdrop of racial tension, it narrates a dramatic tale that explores the life of an impoverished white family struggling to find their place in a harsh society. Skillfully directed, it uses raw emotion and masterful cinematography to draw us into this complex world where unexpected relationships emerge between the main characters as they face discrimination, personal turmoil, and ultimately hope.

The Paul Kersey of DEATH WISH 3 is very far removed from the Paul Kersey of the original film . The Paul Kersey we see in DEATH WISH 3 has undergone a significant transformation when compared to his earlier persona from the original film. In the first installment, Paul was portrayed as a more subdued, gentle and morally conflicted individual - reluctantly compelled to take matters into his own hands due to the rampant crime and brutality he witnesses. Fast forward to the third movie, Paul has fully embraced his role as a relentless vigilante, single-mindedly driven by the goal of eradicating criminals and crime syndicates without hesitation.

I think that this short TV series , was absolutely wonderful , and gave both a in-depth and clear explanation of the storyline, as well as insightful character development throughout its episodes. The cinematography was visually stunning and the soundtrack complemented the show's unique atmosphere, providing an immersive experience. Each actor delivered outstanding performances that left the audience emotionally invested in their story arcs, truly showcasing their talent. Additionally, the script and dialogue were skillfully written and thought-provoking. Overall, this TV series exceeded my expectations and made a lasting impression. I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys a compelling narrative and brilliant production values.

"I am ... proud of 'Head'," Mike Nesmith has said. He should be, because this film, which either has been derided by many of us or studied and scrutinized by film professors, works on many levels.Yes, it's unconventional. To many, frustrating. It's almost as if the producers hand you the film and tempt: "You figure it out. "You probably already know that The Monkees TV show was a runaway marketing success that depended upon business acumen and no small serving of public deception. TV shows are about selling soap and toothpaste first, than to entertain.

A great movie. The movie was even better then the commercials put on. And believe it or not it was very very inspirational. I really think anyone who walks out of the movie at the end will be inspired one way or another.It was kinda corny at the very beginning, but quickly picks up. I laughed. I laughed very hard on some parts. The acting is basically above average, nothing special, but better then average. I can safely say it was the second funniest movie to come out this summer (1st funniest being CLERKS II).

When I was 10 (currently 14), I vowed to never see a movie that I knew would not have a happy ending. And until a few weeks ago I had done pretty well, except for Shakespere for English class...etc...I was still only watching things that ended happy. But then I saw Ramola Garai in Havanah Nights, which was cute, not good but entertaining enough to watch. After seeing this a few times over the two or so years since I first saw it, I grew to like it, especially the music.

James Franco is totally cool in this movie . Not just handsome and charismatic but genuinely open and vulnerable in his portrayal of the lead character. His raw emotion and sensitivity truly draw the audience into the story, allowing them to connect on a deeper level with the struggles his character faces. Franco's performance demonstrates immense versatility, taking the audience on an emotional roller coaster as he tackles scenes of joy, sorrow, anger, and redemption. Supported by a strong and engaging cast, this film truly showcases the brilliance of James Franco and the magic he brings to the screen.

Indeed, Cynthia Watros is in this movie as Elizabeth talking to Desmond. Though I'm just wondering how she ended up as a 'rehab patient'(?) where Hurley is also in there trying to reduce his weight (as seen from the previous episodes).Anyway, this last episode is really suspended. The ending is not so understandable. I think the writer did expect the audience that there is a season 3 coming.I just hope the next season will give light to more unclear/hanging events that were happened.Just can't wait further for season 3.

At first I didn't think I would like this movie, but as it progressed it became better and better. I love music and I was impressed with how well Cage could fake the movements of playing a mandolin. My son was with me and he also like the movie a lot for its music and the story and the way the story unfolded--- slowly showing how Corelli won the girls heart. The acting and the story were both well done and well directed. At first Corelli's bravado was irritating, but soon he grew on you.

Being a middle aged mom myself , I very much appreciated seeing a romance between grown-up people that weaves in the complexities of navigating adult relationships while maintaining individuality and family obligations. In this heartwarming and emotional journey, we witness how true love can spark and rekindle through shared vulnerabilities and the profound bond forged by parenting, redefining the modern fairytale ending. Both relatable and inspirational, it conveys the message that love and happiness are never too far away and that our age does not restrict our capability to form deep connections, nurture dreams, and overcome hurdles for the people that matter most.

This is one of the best of the early `` Star Trek '' episodes , with Kirk and his crew encountering the enigmatic and seemingly godlike entity known as Trelane. Trelane appears to possess powers beyond the crew's understanding and continually toys with the Enterprise, placing them in several challenging situations. These scenarios test their wits, morality, and patience, ultimately providing ample character development for Kirk and his crew. In the end, it's their strength as a team and commitment to their Starfleet principles that help them overcome the trials set by Trelane.

Easily Lucio Fulci's most respected film, "Don't Torture a Duckling" is highly renowned for it's edgy subject matter, gruesome imagery, and strong storyline. Terror befalls a small Italian village as young boys begin turning up murdered, engulfing the confused and determined authorities plus a dedicated detective in mystery. Was it the creepy hermit? The spastic voodoo witch? One of the hookers? The rich girl? Someone else? Contrary to most fan's frequent representation on the film's violent content - I consider it much more plot driven; featuring only one real moment of memorable bloodshed (involving chains and boards).

I can not say this movie was a hilarious, but I must have had a grin on my face the entire time.
