I like this darker kind of comedy; "very bad things", "8 heads in a duffel bag" or "coldblooded"The way the main character tries to get away with murder is a lot of fun to watch. To me it was not much of a surprise what the ending would be, but the way that ending came about was. Another thing that sticks out, is the way they have managed to involve the audience.

If you expect that this movie is full of action and grabbing you from the start then do n't watch it, as you might be disappointed. This film is more of a slow-burn drama that gradually unravels a complex and emotional storyline, taking the audience on a journey of character development and discovery. The strong performances and poignant visuals make it worth the watch for those seeking a more introspective experience. Appreciate it for its intricate plot, immersive atmosphere, and masterful acting, as this film offers a refreshing alternative to fast-paced action flicks, allowing you to immerse yourself in the powerful narrative that unfolds before you.

The `` all I have is 5 dollars and my wedding ring ... '' scene was a riot . I couldn't stop laughing as the desperation in the character's voice became increasingly hilarious. Their failed attempts to barter their limited belongings with a street vendor led to even more hilarity. It was an unexpected comedy moment that added lightheartedness to an otherwise tense film. Despite their seemingly low odds, the character eventually finds a sympathetic individual, highlighting that there's always a silver lining even when times get rough. This unforgettable scene masterfully blended humor with relatable emotions, leaving the audience smiling and heartened.

A very weird , psychedelic , esoteric , ( and did I say weird ? : ) experience.But on at a deeper level, this extraordinary journey left an indelible mark on my consciousness. Entering this bizarre realm, it felt like reality was melting away, taking me through twists and turns filled with intense colors and patterns, causing my mind to stretch and contort. Despite being unusual, there was something captivating and spiritual about this world. Alongside waves of emotions and profound insights, this voyage invoked a new sense of interconnectedness and helped me break free from mundane constraints.

This searing drama based on a true incident concerns several ambitious African nationals who decide to temporarily leave their families by stowing away on an outbound ship. They think that if they successfully make the voyage they can better their lives by making enough money in New York to send for their families. Unfortunately for them, the ship that they select is a rundown Russian freighter which has already been heavily fined at a previous port for harboring stowaways. The captain and the first mate are determined not to let this happen again as their jobs are on the line.

Accepted is a 2006 teen flick that stars the guy from the mac and PC ads. The movie is about Bartelby .B. Gaines a guy who has rejected from all the colleges he has applied for so decides to make his own college and invites all the other people who did not make it, problem is hundreds of people sign up to his school. The movie is hilarious and I was lucky enough to buy it for $5.00 at a sale and I have always watched it since. Overall this movie is a must watch for fans of all comedy as it is funny, witty and just a good movie all up.

No . I 'm not kidding with this one . He was a guest reviewer for Entertainment Weekly and gave the latest Marvel film a surprisingly in-depth and thoughtful critique. Not only did he delve into the complexities of the plot and character development, but he also touched on the stunning visuals and choreography that we've come to expect from a Marvel production. Moreover, he commented on the importance of diversity in the casting and acknowledged the movie's strong emotional core. Who knew he would have such an intricate understanding of film analysis? This just goes to prove that sometimes even the most unlikely critics can provide invaluable insight.

While I agree that this movie lacks any real substance and should not be taken seriously , its primarily directed towards a specific audience who craves mindless entertainment. Movies like these offer an escape from reality and, for some, are an enjoyable distraction after a long, hard day. Yes, it may be shallow and full of cliche moments, but it does fulfill its purpose in providing some humor, thrills, or emotional tugs. Some might find pleasure in its simple storylines and appealing visuals. However, I acknowledge the importance of investing time in films with depth and thought-provoking content.

I never realized what a fabulous dancer Lana Turner was until I saw this movie. She was only 19 years old and gorgeous. What a pleasure to watch her dance with George Murphy. The story line was typical for its day but the dancing was really special. I never tire of watching Fred and Ginger but Lana Turner in this movie was just as terrific. I always thought of Lana as a so-so actress who tended to over act. She should have done more dancing and less of the Maddam X and Peyton Place roles. I had a new appreciation for her after seeing this movie and her wonderful dancing.

Head should have been a proud moment not just for its stars (The Monkees and Victor Mature), or its director/co-writer (Bob Rafelson), but also its other co-writer (and brief cameo) Jack Nicholson. As it stands, most of them seem to shun it, and to outsiders the movie is regarded, at best, as a curio.While the T.V. series was famously based on the antics of the Beatles' 'Help! ', this film is also judged by the same accord. Yet far from the trite and painfully overrated Beatles films, and even the dated Monkees T.V.

There are a select few cartoon films where animals or something "not human" is portraying human beings and I think that this film is one of them. Apart from a few points of the plot and the characters - this film could be changed with all people rather than mainly animals. Although - it's good someone did not - I feel the cats are jolly good in this film portraying humans! :-)This film also focuses on quite a lot of adult issues - which is rather odd for a Disney film.

I think it definitely is. The writing is of such a quality that beginner students of the English language should model their conversations after its dialogue. For example, the exchange between Paul Kersey(Bronson) and Ms. Kathryn Davis(Deborah Raffin) (more about this character later) is extremely clear and to the point: Ms. Davis says, "I hope you like chicken. It's the only thing I know how to make," to which Kersey deftly responds, "Chicken's good. I like chicken."

Ross Hunter's musical remake of the 1937 fantasy, based on James Hilton's enduring bestseller, was written off by critics and audiences almost immediately in 1973, sounding off a backlash against musicals in general that gave the genre a bad reputation in Hollywood for years. Group of disparate British and American individuals end up on an emergency flight out of a war-torn Asian country, but their plane is hijacked and crashes in a snowy mountain terrain; a rescue party arrives and leads the group to an isolated community called Shangri-La, where the sun is always shining and most of the residents are youthful and blissfully content.

The movie starts with a board meeting at a major advertising agency . Putney Swope is on the board for token representation, but suddenly finds himself elected chairman after a chaotic vote. As the newly appointed leader, Swope radically transforms the previously traditional agency, aiming for genuine representation and innovation. He renames it "Truth and Soul Advertising," swiftly implementing dramatic changes: including replacing the majority of white staff with a more diverse team, refusing to work with alcohol, cigarettes, or political campaigns, and shaking up the entire industry.

If we could have "Separate Tables," why not "Separate Lies. "This becomes somewhat involved. A housekeeper's husband is killed when he is hit by a car while on a bicycle. The culprit turns out to be the woman she cleans for. The latter was having an affair with a friend and was driving the car with the lover in it when the accident occurred. To complicate matters further, the housekeeper once worked for the guy's parents and he had her jailed for stealing. Therefore, people will hesitate to believe that it was his car that caused the accident.

I thought that the storyline came into place very well. I liked this movie a lot. If you're going to rag on a Bridget Fonda movie, you can just rot. I thought that ragging on movie stars was a bad idea. Apparently somebody doesn't think so. I rather enjoyed the movie. I'm even thinking of buying it. I want it to be my very first DVD for my room. That's how much I like it. I rather would not start an online argument with someone I don't know & have it be over a movie.

These critics need to find a new job ! ! ! This movie is based on a TRUE STORY , and the incredible acting, captivating plot, and phenomenal cinematography genuinely moved me. There are few films that make a deep, emotional impact, but this is definitely one of them. Of course, it may not have the same resonance for everyone, and that's absolutely okay. Everyone's taste in cinema is different. However, critics should look beyond personal preferences and be unbiased when reviewing a movie, taking into account its creative vision, storytelling prowess, and the real events behind it.

When I started watching 3 of the episodes of this series on the Action Channel , I have to say that I was immediately hooked. The high-octane adventures, well-developed characters, and brilliant storylines made for an incredibly engaging experience. From breathtaking stunts and fight sequences to compelling plot twists, the show consistently delivered moments that left me eagerly waiting for the next episode. The incredible production values, along with the dedicated performances by the cast members, breathed life into this thrilling series. By the end of those three episodes, it was crystal clear to me why it had garnered such a devoted fanbase and rave reviews.

**1/2 Elisha Cuthbert, Chad Michael Murray, Brian Van Holt, Paris Hilton and Jon Abrahams. Directed by Jaume Collet-Serra.Yet another classic horror film remade with dunder-headed teenage acting despite grizzly and creative deaths. Based on the 1953 Vincent Price film House of Wax where a maniac kills unsuspecting teenage hooligans and turns them into priceless wax figures. Still with the fantastic set design to make the whole house into wax the movie is a typical classic horror remake like Tobe Hooper's 1974 classic Texas Chainsaw Massacre later remade, despite creativity and so-so acting the movie was still just a gore picture.

Well, I guess I was in the mood for a movie that really grabbed me from the beginning. This movie wasn't it. It plodded along at a pretty slow, deliberate pace for the first 40 minutes, but there wasn't really anything in it that I was terribly interested in--there's an intriguing and mysterious feud between Jean Reno's character and an old man, but more of the first 40 minutes is dominated by the wanderings of the main character, whom I didn't know much about and couldn't really relate to at the time.

Loved today's show!!! It was a variety and not solely cooking (which would have been great too). Very stimulating and captivating, always keeping the viewer peeking around the corner to see what was coming up next. She is as down to earth and as personable as you get, like one of us which made the show all the more enjoyable. Special guests, who are friends as well made for a nice surprise too. Loved the 'first' theme and that the audience was invited to play along too.

This film biography of early rock and roll star Buddy Holly (1936-1959) is a tour de force for Gary Busey. The movie's highlights are Busey's stage performances where he plays guitar and sings Holly songs. He brings such energy to the performances that Holly's own filmed performances almost pale in comparison. Busey's infectious toothy grin lights up the screen, he creates a totally believable and winning personality and his Oscar nomination for best actor was well deserved.The film follows Holly's career from growing up in Lubbock, Texas, to stardom and New York and his untimely death in a plane crash.

This is a good film for die-hard Chucky fans. Okay I'm sure it's not as good as what the Child's Play movie were like, but this can get really funny and enjoyable, Chucky's laughs are hilarious. (SPOILERS)Now not one doll, but two, meaning double the impact, Jennifer Tilly played the part really well and definitely pulled off the best kill of the movie.If you have seen the Child's Play movies this would be a worthy film on your Chucky collection, but if you've never seen the Child's play movies before, this'll will be a new start.

It reaches the minds and feelings of everyone driving them deep in the black desert . A brutal but beautiful journey that evokes a sense of desolation and solitude. The wind howls fiercely as one delves further into the abyss of darkness, filling them with an irresistible yet haunting pull. Vast landscapes stretched endlessly, filled with only sand, sorrow and silence. Emotions swirling like the relentless storms surrounding them. Every step in the inky blackness brings revelations and discoveries within the explorer's soul. Touched by this ruthless force, the weary traveler unveils depths of vulnerability and resilience, shaping them with newfound resolve.

Oh I remember watching this show at 4:00 p.m. during my junior high days. It was not a pleasant experience because I remember watching it when I made my homework.Still, the show caught my attention when Alex displayed her special powers and dealt with the typical junior high problems.But the show wasn't all about adventures and special powers; it was more of an educational effort for a younger audience in order to get more interested in school and biology overall.The lead actress (can't remember her name and I'm too lazy to copy and paste from the main details) delivered a fantastic performance.

I know this movie is n't for everyone , and I wo n't push my opinions on you , but I just wanted to share my perspective. As someone who appreciates intricate storylines and unconventional cinematography, I found it to be an exceptional work of art. The acting was superb, and I was completely immersed in the unique world created by the director. However, if you're more into traditional Hollywood blockbusters or prefer lighter and more action-packed content, this may not be the right film for you. Ultimately, whether or not you enjoy this movie might depend on your taste and interest in exploring different types of cinema.

I've been a fan of Rachael's since the beginning of 30MM on the Food Network, so I have seen her grow over the years. The minute I saw her interact with Oprah, I predicted that this show would happen, because I saw how taken Oprah is with her, and with good reason: she comes across as very natural, and willing to laugh at herself, which is very engaging. The set is appealing, and there are some fresh ideas (I love the lazy Susan that the audience sits on).

This interesting film noir features three very good performances : Sanders , Patrick , and Blackmer . The scenes between Sanders and Patrick are filled with intense chemistry, making for captivating onscreen interactions, while Blackmer delivers a more enigmatic portrayal. The gripping plot pulls viewers in as it weaves its tale of deception, passion, and ultimately, betrayal. Set in a dark and brooding world where every character has a hidden agenda, the atmospheric visuals enhance the feeling of mystery and danger that permeates the film. A sultry and captivating soundtrack complements the vivid cinematography, creating an overall tone of classic noir at its finest.

OK, so this film may not have won any Oscars, but it is not a bad film. The original "D.O.A." is undoubtedly a better film, but that does not mean this film is bad.The film stars Dennis Quaid in one of his early roles, when he was first becoming really famous, after "The Right Stuff" made him a star, and a very lovely looking Meg Ryan, when she was still now quite famous.This is more of an "update" of the 1950 film, rather than a remake, since the setting is different and the characters too, are different.

Jeff Garlin's film is filled with heart and laughter. As in Curb Your Enthusiasm, his screen persona is hilarious; but in addition we get to see both warmth and a sense of emotional vulnerability that makes the story universal. While the film chronicles his character's dreams of love, performing success, and weight loss, it will appeal to anyone who dreams of a better life. The supporting cast brings the frustrations and joys of his life to the screen in funny and heartbreaking ways. The simple joys of food, friendship, and trying once again once life has disappointed us are all themes.

I tend to get furious when hearing about Lucio Fulci's reputation as a director. Too often he's categorized as a no-talented filmmaker, only out to shock and disgust entire audiences with images of pure gore. True, his films contain more explicit filth and sickness as your average mainstream American production, but his films always are of wide range and the plots are gruesomely morbid. Don't Torture a Duckling is yet another story! This film is a pure gem of the Italian shock cinema! I easily dare to call this film a masterpieceit's an old-fashioned giallo that includes all brilliant aspects of genuine horror.

1969 was the year . New York City was the place . Putney Swoope was the second Robert Downey film . This dark comedy featured a distinctive sense of satire and wit, much like his father, Robert Downey Sr.'s earlier films. Set in the chaotic world of advertising, the movie chronicled the rise of an unscrupulous character named Putney Swoope. He effortlessly shatters the status quo, revolting against traditional practices in advertising, turning heads in New York City with a peculiar, honest, and controversial ad campaign. The film earned both praises and criticisms, resonating a counterculture spirit and raising debates on consumer culture of that era.

I still ca n't describe what to feel when I received this by the fnac site . Such a rare gem, truly a collector's dream come true! When I first held it in my hands, a wave of excitement and nostalgia washed over me, reminding me of the countless hours spent browsing through the site for unique items like this one. It's simply amazing to have the chance to own such a rare and cherished piece, and knowing that I can now share my joy and passion for this collection with like-minded enthusiasts just brings it full circle.

I have to admit that I approached this movie with a sense of expectation and dread . Louis de Berniere 's novel was a captivating read that tugged at the heartstrings with its memorable characters, idyllic love stories and tales of heroism. The fear came from past cinematic endeavors to adapt books, often butchering the soul that made them special. However, with stunning cinematography, a strong and emotionally engaging screenplay, and heart-wrenching performances, this film exceeded my expectations, preserving the novel's essence, while daringly incorporating artistic elements of its own.

The best thing from the American Pie "bakery." I found the humor and the plot to be far more engaging audience than any of the American Pie movies to date. .Also concerning the appropriateness of the content I found this to be acceptable to a much larger audience than any of the previous American Pie movies. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie experience. When the movie first came out I read a number of negative reviews and ended up not going to see it while it was still in the theater...I now regret that decision.

I 'm not a massive Disney fan , but my 7 year old son is starting to get into them , so I'm slowly warming up to the magic of their movies. He just can't seem to get enough of the charming characters, mesmerizing animation, and heartwarming stories that take him on magical journeys. Consequently, we're bonding over a Disney movie marathon and discovering the unique universe they have to offer together. Who knows, my taste might change by immersing myself into their captivating stories alongside my little Disney aficionado. After all, reliving our childhood wonder can add some extra sparkle to our everyday lives.

Remember that this came out before Gulf War I , which gave us Werner Herzog 's `` Lessons of Darkness "and CNN's live news reporting from the warzone. These impactful moments in media history revolutionized how the public perceives and consumes information related to war and conflict. The documentary-like, almost apocalyptic scenes in Herzog's 'Lessons of Darkness,' along with the fast-paced coverage of events by CNN during the first Gulf War, showcased the magnitude of modern warfare, particularly through striking visual narratives. Both aspects shaped the opinions and outlook on conflict, ushering a new era of understanding regarding war's devastating impacts and consequences."

I recently saw Blind Spot in Coyoacan, where it drew a huge crowd and some pretty intense discussion. I really admired the story and visual approach. The action is frightening and the mood of loneliness that the film projects is amazing. There is much beauty in the melancholy that surrounds these three misfit heroes. Not just in the desert but in the city too. My best scene was after the boy discovers his friends in the apartment and then rides his skateboard through all the remarkable lights of the city. You really feel for this guy.

When `` Madame '' decides to let her cats inherit her it spells trouble . The snobbish Butler Edgar who was planning to be the beneficiary of Madame's fortune becomes consumed by envy and concocts a wicked scheme to sabotage the felines' newfound inheritance. Little does he know, the street-smart alley cat Thomas O'Malley and his resourceful gang of feline friends learn of his treacherous intentions and prepare to intervene. In a thrilling battle of wits, the valiant team of cats come together, demonstrating unbreakable camaraderie in order to foil Edgar's plan and protect their beloved Madame's wishes.

After spotting the boat at the end of the previous episode ( `` Three Minutes '' ) , the survivors split into two groups – one to meet the boat, the other to explore the island further. Upon the boat's arrival, they discovered it carried survivors from a second crashed plane. Shocked, the group began sharing their experiences, hoping to find answers to the strange events they had endured. On the other side of the island, the exploration team stumbled upon a mysterious cave. Venturing inside, they found relics that could hold secrets to the island's past.

A film about the relationship between a man and leopard that 's very reminiscent of `` The English Patient , '' and set amidst the backdrop of a stunning, exotic landscape. The plot delves into the intriguing connection between the main character, a widowed scientist studying leopard behaviors, and the leopard, whom he inadvertently saves from poachers. Throughout their journey together, they forge an unexpected, profound bond. Elements of loss, love, and sacrifice permeate the storyline as the characters grapple with complex emotions and confront their own vulnerabilities.

I thought I might be disappointed viewing this film again after so many years . On the contrary , I was pleasantly surprised to find that it has aged quite gracefully. In fact, watching it with a matured perspective actually brought new appreciation for its artistry, nuanced performances, and underlying themes. I realized that the aspects that might have appeared outdated could still resonate with the present, testifying to the timeless nature of the storyline. Subtleties I may have missed in my younger days were more evident, giving me a deeper understanding and connection with the characters and the narrative.

I love the TV contest. Hate to see it end. There are so many talented contestants. It's a shame that only 2 will be picked. I love watching the judges also. At times they are as entertaining as the contestants. I have been watching the show faithfully every Sunday night. Wouldn't miss it for the world. It's the best reality show that's ever been on television. Good luck to all the contestants, though I have already chosen the two who I would like to see play Danny and Sandy on Broadway.

We saw La Spettatrice last night @ the Chicago International Film Festival & we were both immensely moved by it. This is a haunting tale of loneliness & missed connection in which the longing for intimacy conflicts with our fear of revealing too much about ourselves to another. The three leads (Barbora Bobulova as Valeria, Brigitte Catillon as Flavia, Andrea Renzi as Massimo) are all excellent and the dynamic between them is very surprising. After all the movies which devalue older women, it's wonderful to see Flavia (who is a law professor at a university in Rome) presented as beautiful & sensual as well as seductive & powerful.

This movie is truly a classic 80s movie! A must have in any '80s' movie collection! Guns, Bad Guys, CREEPS, Gangs, CHARLES BRONSON and more CREEPS!!!! In my opinion, this is the best Death Wish movie. Tons of non-stop action! And keeping with the classic 80's "bad guy vs good guy" movie - this movie is about anything but the norm and all about guns and CREEPS! We see Bronson mowing down thugs and CREEPS with a 30 caliber Korean War heavy machine gun! A HEAVY MACHINE GUN FOR CRYING OUT LOUD!

Dr. Paul Flanner (Richard Gere), a successful surgeon, has his wife leave him, his son (an uncredited James Franco) not respect him and looses a patient he's operating on. Adrienne Willis (Diane Lane) has two children and discovers her husband has cheated on her. They both need to get away. She watches over a beautiful oceanside inn in Rodanthe at the same time he books a room. They're all alone together. You can pretty much figure out the rest.This is what's known as a weepie or a woman's film.

This movie gives us some WWII history along with some touching romance, a little fantasy and meaningful emotion - and beautiful scenery. Nicholas Cage never fails us, and here again does a great job. And so do the other principle characters. One key charater, the physician/father played by John Hurd, delivers (to his daughter) one of the best definitions of love I've ever heard. Some of the events are a bit too coincidental to be real, but I excused that, knowing that this is partly fairy tale and fantacy. My wife and I really liked the film.

Saw the film at the closing gala of the Ealing Film Festival in West London(England). Enjoyed it immensely. Although the Crow & the Chinese Policeman don't appear, and Dan Milligan becomes Dan Madigan (played by Sean Hughes (I)). The interaction between Dan and the Author (Writer/Director) voiced/played by Lord Richard Attenborough, works very well.The rumour is that Lord Attenborough and Elliott Gould (as Dr. Goldstein) appeared in the film for just a pint of beer.Spike was shown the film, on video before he died and by all accounts enjoyed it immensely.

Documentaries in which sons and daughters seek to understand a parent and , by the process , their own lives often delve into the intricacies of familial bonds and generational legacies. As these documentaries unravel, not only do the viewers get a unique glimpse into the complexities of family relationships, but also the individual involved gains insights into their own identities and personal growth. Navigating through the trials and tribulations of their parents' lives helps them relate better to their own experiences, bridge the emotional gaps, and find acceptance and closure in a beautiful confluence of empathy, love and understanding.

Charles Chaplin 's 'Shoulder Arms ' of 1918 was his longest film to date , though , at just over 45 minutes, it can hardly be called a feature-length movie. Nonetheless, 'Shoulder Arms' showcased Chaplin's comedic prowess in depicting the lives of soldiers during World War I. Starring as the infamous "Little Tramp" character, Chaplin manages to both lighten the bleak atmosphere of war and convey powerful anti-war messages. This war comedy showcases numerous mishaps and misadventures, highlighting the resilience of the human spirit. Overall, the film marked another milestone in Chaplin's career, further cementing his status as a cinematic icon.

Sit back and let Director Bharatbala lead us into a visual and sensual voyage of the mind and spirit of India. When was the last time you could say you really enjoyed a movie? This movie has pace and keeps us moving in directions that may only exist in India. If you didn't want to visit India before this movie will surely make you want to visit it now. This movie has dancing girls, a chase scene, and the mafioso involved. But it has a lot more. Thanks, Bharatbala, for taking us on such a spirited and wonderful tale.

Not sure why the other comment on this film was so negative, but I loved this movie. I am a student of Asian art with a particular love of Korean art, culture and history. I thought this movie borough a very controversial and interesting character to life. Jang Seung-up is one of the (maybe the most) famous Korean artist and continues to be revered as a master. Given the tumult of the time in which he painted and his own conflicted nature, it is amazing that he produced so much work, in so many styles and with such skill.

If you expect that this movie is full of action and grabbing you from the start then don't watch it. But if you like those kind of meditative movies which stick in your mind for a while, until you get the details, then you will love it. Now don't get me wrong there is action and there are things going on just not in the usual way. Basically the plot is in a post-apocalyptic world where anyone fights in his (or their) way for survival. In this fight they lost the ability to speak...

A beautifully photographed and paced short film. It evocatively captures the feeling of this family and much of the country during the period just prior to and after Pearl Harbor.I appreciated the visual look of the film -- naturalistic and simultaneously poetic. Great work by a great D.P., David Boyd.Though a family film, the story never becomes maudlin or saccharin. We understand and believe the motivation that propels the young boy on his odyssey. I understand the love of the younger brother for his older brother and do not question why he sets out to do what he does.

Obviously the previous reviewers here are not fans of this genre , but I think this one is done quite well. As an avid fan of the genre myself, I believe that this piece manages to hit the right chords with a carefully-crafted blend of relatable characters, enticing plot twists, and evocative world-building. It's evident that the author has a keen understanding of how to draw the audience in and keep their interest piqued. By exploring darker themes and complex emotional struggles, the story transcends a standard genre offering and captures readers with a wide range of tastes.

This is a well directed Columbo episode, with also some good character but the story just doesn't really know to interest enough and doesn't appear as well layered and constructed as was often the case with a Columbo movie. This also goes for the killer's plot to kill his uncle. It's quite simple and doesn't seem as well thought out. Perhaps this movie didn't really took itself serious enough, since the atmosphere of the movie is mostly light. At least when compared to different Columbo movies.For instance the movie features quite a large amount of comical relief, mostly coming from the Columbo character himself.

I hope, from his seat on Heaven's comedic throne, Spike Milligan can see and can enjoy this film, as Terence Ryan and Ken Tuohy have taken a book that the author himself said writing it "nearly turned me mad" into a joy to watch.The film tells the story of the Irish town of Puckoon and the problems befallen upon it when the partition between Northern Ireland and the Republic is drawn up, cutting its way through the centre of the village and, more worringly, through the middle of the churchyard.

I was 19 or 20 , years old at the time and living in Salt Lake City , Utah and had recently moved into a small apartment downtown. The city, with its stunning mountain backdrop and bustling energy, was a refreshing change for a small-town boy like me. I began attending classes at the local university and exploring the diverse neighborhoods, clubs, and cafes, eventually meeting an eclectic group of friends who shared my interests. We would spend hours visiting art galleries, skiing, and discovering the vibrant and exciting nightlife scene.

Accepted is one of the best teenage comedies I have seen in a long time. It has an original script, talented cast and it delivers an hour and a half of pure unadulterated fun.It tells the story of a high school graduate Bartleby "B" Gains (Justin Long) who is not accepted in any of the collages he applied to, so to avoid his parents' disappointment he creates a fictional collage. In the attempt to fool his parents completely he creates a fake website and turns an old psychiatric hospital into a school.

Warning -- this film has some amazingly graphic images and should never be seen by kids.The artist who this story is based on pushed the boundaries of creativity, often intertwining horror and the grotesque with thought-provoking themes. This film brilliantly captures their unique approach, but may not be suitable for those with a sensitive disposition. Viewers should prepare themselves for a truly immersive experience into the mind of the artist, where every detail and color adds a chilling layer to their terrifying creations. Despite the explicit visuals, there is an undeniable beauty and artistic genius to appreciate.

I'm not sure why this film is averaging so low on IMDb when it's absolutely everything you could ever want in a horror film. This is the definition of being a horror film. I consider myself to be a big horror fan and I must say that this house delivers the goods. House of wax Is the story of a group of college kids on their way to a football game whom decide to camp out for the night and have a run in with a local weirdo. Upon waking the next morning they make a gruesome discovery and decide to go into town for a broken car part.

Frank Langella steals my heart in everything he has ever been in ! I love watching him ! ! i simply cannot get enough of his amazing performances. Time and again, he demonstrates his incredible talent and versatility, mastering various characters across different genres. He brings life to his roles with such precision and depth, making them incredibly realistic and unforgettable. From playing the mysterious vampire, Count Dracula, to the mastermind politician, Richard Nixon, Langella has truly captured the essence of each character he has portrayed. He exudes elegance and magnetism on screen, always keeping the audience thoroughly captivated.

Then again, I like Rachael Ray. She is fun, sweet, fresh, and such a joy to watch. I have to alter just about everything she makes as I am a vegetarian...but it's great to see her with a program that shows more of her personality. After all, she is a television personality. I think it's cool that she is so inviting with her fans and still appears to be down-to-earth. The studio audience appears to be rather small, but that just makes for a cozier environment. Some people have posted that the show sucks.

What's the point of this messages if not to discuss and share thoughts about the next season... Here is my forecast: 1. The hatch was indeed blown, but somehow everybody inside survived. Buts lets see about that. 2. The episode at the end with the tent is an observation team monitoring the tracking device installed on Desmonds boat by Penny. Now that the magnetic shield around the island was lifted, the signal was picked up by the observation station and they are going to send a rescue mission. 3.

We loved this movie because it was so entertaining and off beat -- Not your usual Hollywood drivel.My husband had previously complained about the lack of originality in the film industry, so watching this was a breath of fresh air for both of us. The quirky characters and unique storyline captured our interest right from the start. There were some hilarious moments that had us laughing out loud and some tender moments that tugged at our heartstrings. It also had a memorable and thought-provoking underlying message. In today's world where every other movie seems to be a sequel or remake, it was a delightful change to enjoy something original and unconventional.

I thought this was movie was great, Richard Greico and Yasmine Bleeth have great chemistry in this movie. Yasmine Bleeth's character plays a women who has fallen head over heals in love with Richard Greico's character. They end up getting married and everything seems perfect except Yasmine Bleeth wants a baby more than anything, however she has a hard time trying to conceive. Richard Greico will do anything to make her happy, and will go to extreme measures to make her happy. I thought the acting was great in this movie, and it keeps you guessing.

What a great film! I never knew much about Buddy Holly, but was familiar with his lively and fun music. This is a wonderful biography of someone who helped change the music in the 1950's. Although I never cared for Gary Bussey, he was fabulous as Buddy Holly! I don't know how accurate the movie is, but assume at least for the most part it is accurate, which makes the movie all the more interesting. The music throughout the movie just adds the pizazz to this biography. I don't think I would change a thing in this film, it was all good!

What a surprise. A basic copycat of the comedy classic 'The Nutty Professor' only naughtier. Funny guy Tim Thomerson (who steals the show as Blinkin in Robin Hood-Men In Tights) is downright hilarious as the anal retentive Dr. Jekyll and the sex crazed Hyde. The one scene that is really funny is when Dr. Lanyon (Mark Blankfield) catches Jekyll in bed with his daughter and says: "how dare you take advantage of my innocent daughter." Jekyll replies, "but sir, I'm going ahead with the operation. "Lanyon replies back, "oh.

One of the most magnificent movies ever made . The acting of Charles Buchinski ( later known as Bronson ) One of the most magnificent movies ever made features the acting of Charles Buchinski (later known as Charles Bronson). Bronson's spellbinding performance demonstrates his versatility and remarkable ability to convey complex emotions without uttering a single word. He navigates his character through thrilling and poignant moments, capturing the essence of what makes a film unforgettable. In a cast full of talented actors, Bronson stands out as a tour de force in cinematic brilliance.

1930 's comedy mystery about `` The Crooked Circle '' a band of hooded crooks who set about plotting the demise of a prominent detective named Sheridan Adams. Tasked with uncovering their identities, Adams and his witty sidekick, Samuel Taylor, face a slew of madcap situations, from suspenseful séances to fast-paced car chases. Together, they delve deeper into the underworld to dismantle the crime syndicate. But the closer they come to uncovering the truth, the more tangled the web of deception grows. As hidden allegiances and unexpected twists pile up, it seems every laugh is tempered by danger.

So it's not an award winner, so what? Have you ever wanted to see a film that was just silly? "The Villain" and this one could top the list.My husband says that "Jekyll and Hyde Together Again" is one of those movies that if "you've been there and done that" you'll think this spoof on the 80's cocaine culture is a riot. I think the whole film is just fun. Nothing is sacred; hospitals, plastic surgery, Howard Hughes.... There are ongoing gags that you have to watch for to appreciate.

Saw the film at the closing gala of the Ealing Film Festival in West London ( England ) . Enjoyed it thoroughly, especially since it showcased the incredible talent of local and international filmmakers. The captivating plot and stunning cinematography effortlessly captivated the audience, making the whole experience a memorable one. The film featured brilliant performances by both the lead actors and supporting cast, offering the perfect balance of emotion, humor, and suspense. Overall, attending the closing gala of the Ealing Film Festival proved to be an excellent opportunity to appreciate indie cinema while also getting to witness the vibrant filmmaking culture of West London.

I just can't understand why people are surprised this movie makes no sense. It was never supposed to make sense. (Duh! The writers were completely wasted on Frodis at the time.) It was just supposed to entertain and mock, and it does both wonderfully.The Monkees are good actors. They wouldn't have been hired if they weren't good actors. Mike has a thing for deadpan and darkness, Micky is the best at sheer psychotic comedy, Davy is a Broadway veteran, and Peter actually had people believing he was that dumb in real life.

The last film by underrated director Alberto De Martino ( `` The Antichrist '' , `` The Killer is on the Phone'' ), "Hades Project: Invasion Earth," had all the markings of a blockbuster that never quite made it to the mainstream. This forgotten gem of Italian cinema delves into a unique narrative combining science fiction and paranormal suspense, as it uncovers the complexities of the human mind in a world where time is not linear. Martino’s masterful ability to instill genuine emotion and paranoia has led this work to garner a small, dedicated following in the years since its release.

Chucky's back...and it's about time! This time, with the help of Jennifer Tilly and a little spell from Voodoo For Dummies. Well, at least with this installment, the camp is back. This was the more gruesome of this series, so far. It has some good twists and some good action scenes. This one was by far, the most fun of the series, and successfully, if unintentionally, bridges the gap between pure horror to horror/comedy. I am looking forward to Seed of Chucky. It'll be a hoot!

Exclusively for Coop 's lovers , though Clint Eastwood very strong though unobtrusive presence is a great asset of this film, Cooper's extraordinary acting skills truly steal the show. As a protagonist, Coop effortlessly navigates complex emotional landscapes and brings out the subtleties in every scene, leaving viewers in awe of his abilities. Coupled with Eastwood's raw and subdued charisma, these two legends combine to create an intense on-screen chemistry that audiences will cherish. The film itself seamlessly blends romance, adventure, and heart-pounding thrills into a cinematic masterpiece, with stunning visuals that elevate every twist and turn.

If you like who-dun-its , you will like this film , considered the best Italian detective story ( giallo ) ever made. Known for its captivating plot, skillful storytelling, and remarkable cinematography, this giallo masterpiece brings an impressive blend of suspense, thrill, and intrigue. Filled with surprising twists and turns, the movie enthralls viewers as they attempt to solve the mysterious case along with the film's memorable detective protagonist. Exploring both the dark alleys and picturesque landscapes of Italy, this engaging tale never fails to entertain and mystify, making it a must-watch for all lovers of classic detective cinema.

Louis Khan was one of the most influential architects of our time , and this film speaks volumes about how his unique approach to architecture left an indelible mark on the industry. The documentary dives deep into Khan's extraordinary journey, detailing his humble beginnings in Estonia to his innovative designs that transformed the world of architecture. Khan's work showcased the importance of human values, emotional connection, and natural materials in constructing memorable buildings, with examples like the Salk Institute and National Assembly Building of Bangladesh serving as a testament to his mastery.

This is one of the finest TV movies you could ever see . The acting , writing and production values are all top-notch, leaving viewers completely captivated from start to finish. The storyline is intriguing and thought-provoking, taking viewers on a rollercoaster ride of emotions throughout the film. The talented cast delivers powerful performances that tug at the heartstrings, with incredible chemistry among the ensemble. Furthermore, the captivating visuals, seamless editing, and skillful direction only elevate this cinematic experience. Rarely do we come across a TV movie that leaves such a profound impact on its audience, making it a must-see for film enthusiasts and casual viewers alike.

They Made Me a Criminal is a remake of an earlier Warner Brothers film, The Life of Jimmy Dolan which starred Douglas Fairbanks, Jr. as the prizefighter on the lam.Even with the restrictions now upon production by the Hays Office, this remake actually turns out to be better than the original. Douglas Fairbanks, Jr., is horribly miscast as a pugilist. John Garfield with his background and style steps into a part he was born to play.They Made Me a Criminal was directed by Busby Berkeley who Jack Warner believed in keeping busy in between musicals. Berkeley in fact would soon be leaving Warner Brothers for MGM.

Jenny Lewis plays an awkward girl called Jade. She smokes and drinks. She doesn't have a lot of friends and she has a nagging mother(Beverly D'Angelo). Jade finds herself growing closer to her mom's boyfriend Billy(Rob Estes), maybe she is attracted to him. Of course, I don't need to tell you what happens after that. This is probably my favorite TV movie. This movie shows that sometimes everyone is to blame. This movie also has the best acting that I have seen in TV movies.

When I saw this film at a festival years ago I was very impressed and I started to looking for more works from the same director. What stood out the most about this film was its unique storyline, brilliant character development, and exceptional cinematography. It was unlike anything I had seen before, taking viewers on an emotional roller-coaster with plot twists and surprises around every corner. The director's approach to storytelling pushed the boundaries of traditional narratives and experimented with various innovative techniques. Each character's complexity and growth over the film evoked strong empathy from the audience.

I thought that the storyline came into place very well . I liked this movie a lot . If you enjoy engaging plots, well-developed characters, and compelling themes, then I highly recommend giving this movie a watch. The pacing was steady and kept me hooked throughout, leaving little room for dull moments. The director brilliantly showcased the elements of surprise, romance, and drama to keep the audience thoroughly entertained. The stellar performances of the lead actors undoubtedly carried the movie, providing ample depth to the storyline. It truly evoked a plethora of emotions that made me invested in the journey of these characters.

Mark Blankfield played Jekyll and Hyde.Michael McGuire was the dad.Tim Thomerson was the plastic surgeon.Did you even see this movie Mark Blankfield brilliantly portrayed the dual roles of Jekyll and Hyde in the classic tale of human duality, while Michael McGuire shined as the strict yet caring dad. Tim Thomerson delivered an outstanding performance as the skilled and unorthodox plastic surgeon. Many people missed out on this unique cinematic experience, so if you haven't seen this film yet, it's time to consider adding it to your must-watch list. With unforgettable characters and unforgettable scenes, this movie will definitely capture your attention and make for an entertaining time.

This movie felt so real . I actually felt all of the emotions portrayed here during my life at various points. The storyline was relatable, and the actors did an exceptional job of bringing their characters to life. Each scene had a profound impact, truly hitting close to home as it uncovered raw feelings that had been long tucked away. The cinematography beautifully enhanced the narrative, and the soundtrack complemented every emotion that washed over me throughout the film. Ultimately, this movie was an emotional rollercoaster that brought back poignant memories and allowed me to feel connected with the characters onscreen, creating an unforgettable experience.

I thought it was brilliant! It was great watching the presenter tracking each one of them down. Dwight Schultz still looked the same, he had hardly changed in looks, neither had Dirk Benedict, he still looked just as dishy! I thought that Mr T looked thinner though, but it was still great to see how he looked after all this time. I thought that it took some doing tracking down the other members of the cast, such as the one who played Decker, and the lady who played Amy. It was just a shame that Mr T could'nt make the actual reunion.

* May Contain Spoilers * The first time I saw this movie was when it was re-released on video when I was a teenager. It immediately captivated me with its thrilling story, compelling characters, and stunning visuals. I remember being on the edge of my seat as the movie progressed, anxiously anticipating what twists and turns awaited. As the years have passed and I have revisited this film, I've discovered new layers to its narrative, helping me to appreciate it even more. In today's saturated market of predictable plots and cookie-cutter characters, the magic of this particular movie remains a breath of fresh air.

This is probably the second best of the Death Wish movies . Death Wish 5 is the best one.Death Wish 5 stands out as it builds upon the foundation set by its predecessor, refining the action sequences and developing the storylines further. While Death Wish 4 presented the grittier side of the series, Death Wish 5 manages to perfectly balance suspense, emotional depth, and gripping plotlines that engage viewers from start to finish. Bronson delivers a powerhouse performance in this compelling fifth installment. This time, he sets out to eradicate the criminals that prey on his family, showcasing new depths of determination and prowess as a fearless vigilante.

I've read a lot of reviews about Showtime on IMDb and many seem to miss the mark. I've noticed a lot of reviewers calling this the typical "buddy" film. De Niro is in no way Murphy's buddy throughout most of this movie. In fact, part of the comedy of this film is De Niro's reluctance to be friends with anybody.Murphy really shines in this one. He is back at doing what he does best, acting like a complete ham. He is a cop who wants so much to be an actor and enjoys being in the reality show.

Surprisingly effective British drama about two very different people who find common ground, and in particular the "flowering" of one of them. An embittered, "Spike"-type youth (McAvoy) with Deuchennes MD is placed in a home for the disabled and quickly makes friends with a youth (Robertson) with cerebral palsy. Robertson has never known anything outside of the home, but McAvoy has and he is bound and determined to get back into the real world. Together, they manage to do just that in this funny and heartwarming and often heartbreaking tale of inner strength overcoming physical shortcomings.

When I saw this movie i expected it to be a cheesy American movie done on the cheap with appalling acting, clichéd storylines, and terrible special effects. Much to my surprise, this film turned out to be a thoroughly enjoyable and refreshing cinematic experience. The ensemble cast delivered outstanding performances, injecting their characters with authenticity and heart. The director artfully captured each poignant moment and stunning location, making each scene impactful and engaging. Additionally, the well-thought-out storyline deviated from conventional tropes and delved into genuine human emotions, creating a truly memorable experience.

I believe that this is one of Elizabeth Montgomery's best performances in a movie, and I have seen most of her movies.I saw this for the first time on television when I was around fourteen, and I was so scared.I watch this movie every now and then, and I still enjoy it very much.I know that these days that this movie would probably not scare people too much.That just goes to show that the public movie and television audience has seen too much graphic violence in the last thirty years or so.I love movies that do not show the graphic details, you let your imagination do the work for you.

Mark Blankfield ( from the old late night TV show `` Fridays '' ) plays Dr. Daniel Jekyll , a kind-hearted and introverted scientist who is desperate to solve his social awkwardness. Obsessed with the works of his ancestor Dr. Henry Jekyll, Dr. Daniel Jekyll develops a formula intended to suppress his shyness and unleash a more outgoing persona. The formula, however, turns him into the wild and chaotic party animal known as Mr. Heidi Hyde. Hilarity ensues as Dr. Jekyll's respectable professional and personal life is increasingly disrupted by the outrageous behavior of Mr. Hyde.

The story starts out with a soldier being transported to a desert town then goes back in time to tell the tale of his journey. Growing up in a small village, the young soldier had always yearned for adventure, wanting to explore beyond the boundaries set by his circumstances. As soon as he could, he enlisted in the army, driven by a mixture of ambition, hope, and naivety. Gradually, his perspective on the world shifted as he underwent rigorous training and heard haunting tales of battle from seasoned veterans.

OK , so I loved Rachael Ray before , but now , I ADORE her ! How innovative . I cannot believe how she continuously comes up with such creative recipes and fantastic kitchen hacks. It's like she has an endless pool of culinary genius! Each dish has her special twist and amazing flavor that leaves you craving more. The way she teaches her techniques on her show makes it feel so doable for even the most inexperienced cooks like myself. Rachael Ray truly makes cooking fun and accessible for everyone, breaking barriers and encouraging people to enjoy their time in the kitchen.

Although this film never attained commercial notoriety, my experience has led me to conclude that many well-done pieces of artistic expression often do not gain mass appeal. The story line depicts a young boy stealing a car and embarking on a surreal, dream-like adventure with very little basis in our conceptualization of time and space. Therefore, anyone who attempts to view this film from the perspective of its conformity to reality will likely be disappointed; it is not intended to be "realistic." It is, however, intended to be metaphoric with extensive symbolism apparent to those with superb attention to detail.

Considering all of the comedies with a military situation that have been done in history, someone had to be the first. One could make a case that in Shoulder Arms, Charlie Chaplin invented the genre.Hard to believe that back then this was a daring move. When you consider that some of the best films involving such people as Bob Hope, Abbott&Costello, Laurel&Hardy involved military service and made during war time, it's just something you accept and laugh at.In the First World War Chaplin along with fellow stars Douglas Fairbanks and Mary Pickford went out on bond tours.

Years ago when I first read John Irving 's The World According to Garp , I was astounded that most people didn't seem to appreciate the humor and depth of the book. As the story unfolds, we follow Garp through his often peculiar experiences and relationships, which give a rich and sometimes heart-wrenching depiction of his life's journey. Although it deals with serious issues like death, gender inequality, and a deteriorating society, The World According to Garp had moments that made me laugh out loud, ultimately becoming one of my favorite novels.

I just thought I would add another observation , here . While there are a couple of visual sub-references , there is also a notable audio component that seems to be of significant importance in the overall experience. It's interesting to see how these audio elements work in tandem with the visuals, creating a richer and more immersive experience for the viewer or user. The blend of sound and visuals can evoke a certain mood, and sometimes even generate an emotional response. In many cases, these carefully orchestrated audiovisual elements enhance our engagement and comprehension, while making the material more memorable and appealing.

This movie was great . It had everything a true action fan could want . Plenty of people getting shot , incredible car chases, and massive explosions that kept me on the edge of my seat. The storyline was well thought out and executed, keeping me fully invested in the characters and their motivations. The hero, in particular, was charismatic and skilled, facing every challenge head-on and fighting to save the day. Excellent acting and fantastic choreography lent credibility to the action scenes. Visually stunning, it felt like a comic book coming to life.

Double Shock is one of the many good Columbo episodes which reaches the level of a good movie.It has all the classic elements of a suspenseful and engaging mystery, while also showcasing Peter Falk's inimitable portrayal of the brilliant yet disheveled Lieutenant Columbo. In this episode, a wealthy widow's sudden death reveals an unexpected, sordid web of intrigue involving deceit and treachery within the family. What truly sets Double Shock apart is the clever use of a twin-brother duo, masterfully played by guest star Martin Landau, creating a double-layered challenge for Columbo to untangle.

When I first saw this movie , I also expected `` our boys '' to be cute , and more endearing than threatening, based on the promotional material. However, as the film unfolded, it took a rather surprising turn. It became a harrowing exploration of the fragile psyches of these "cute" youngsters, diving deep into their internal battles with identity, belonging, and even psychological warfare. Contrary to its packaging, "our boys" brought forth the vulnerability that resides within all of us, breaking away from the stereotype of innocent cuteness to address more thought-provoking, mature themes that challenged the audience's understanding and sympathy.

What I enjoyed most in this film was the scenery of Corfu, being Greek I adore my country and I liked the flattering director's point of view. Based on a true story during the years when Greece was struggling to stand on her own two feet through war, Nazis and hardship. An Italian soldier and a Greek girl fall in love but the times are hard and they have a lot of sacrifices to make. Nicholas Cage looking great in a uniform gives a passionate account of this unfulfilled (in the beginning) love.

This is another film where the cinematography is the best thing to recommend it. That would be fine if the film were a travelogue, but as a dramatic exercise in cinematic artistry, that is not good enough. The theme of inter-species respect and co-operation ventures timidly into the forbidden world of inter-species love, but its approach is stereotypical, indicating a lack of understanding of the behavior motives of either species. As with many films, one always wonders what could have been achieved by a more innovative director and a more creative screenwriter. Alas, we probably will never know.

This movie possesses something most other movies of its genre do not: intelligence and good messages. Accepted, is the story of a kid named Bartleby (Justin Long) who gets rejected by every college he applies to. His parents are incredibly strict, frustrated and disappointed. So, Bartleby and a few other students who face similar problems start a fake college, to pawn themselves off to their parents as college kids. Not everything goes to plan, and the movie is about them winging it. But behind this plot which sounds ridiculous, there are good messages, morals and a new outlook on the American educational system.

Based on a William Faulkner short story , Two Soldiers is a top notch short film , a movie that captivates audiences with its poignant tale of love, sacrifice, and courage. Set during the tumultuous time of World War II, Two Soldiers follows the heartwrenching journey of two brothers as they navigate the challenges of war and separation. Through stunning cinematography and powerful storytelling, the film explores themes of family bonds, loyalty, and the cost of freedom, providing a sobering glimpse into the sacrifices made by those who fought for our nation.

This is one of those films where it is easy to see how some people wouldn't like it. My wife has never seen it, and when I just rewatched it last night, I waited until after she went to bed. She might have been amused by a couple small snippets, but I know she would have had enough within ten minutes.Head has nothing like a conventional story. The film is firmly mired in the psychedelic era. It could be seen as filmic surrealism in a nutshell, or as something of a postmodern acid trip through film genres.

Enchanting. The best time to see this movie is sometime when unhappy or sad. It's all just so cute, all, even the way that white bear loves the Queen in secret and gets Her in the end, also the achievement the two young actors of Gerda and Kai gave. It's music is also very nice. The two of us will always be one combined with sad piano tones in some places gives a very touching result and if one watches both parts at once, he'll see the Snow Queen is not so bad.

For all those people who believe the dialog is worth something, and who appreciate a farce that is clever enough for you to take it seriously, this movie will surprise you. It is not a 'whodunit' for people who can't aren't able to follow the verbal exchange of our hero, Professor Dexter Cornell (Dennis Quaid).Cornell teaches in Southern California, near the tar pits. He has not published a novel in four years, his wife is divorcing him, he drinks a bit much, and is blessed or cursed with caustic wit, which he freely dispenses to his students.

WTF!! Do any of his books/movies end in a happy ending?? The Notebook was good...but sheesh, enough with the depressing endings already. I'm told that he writes about realistic situations that people deal with in real life. Understandable...but sometimes it's nice to see people who have sacrificed their whole lives to only get to a mediocre unhappy time in their lives - to finally find the true meaning of happiness and are able to live it out for the rest of their days. Don't we already know what really happens in real life?

In this era when almost everything makes it on to DVD (I'm expecting to see the My Mother the Car collection any day now) this film has been unfairly neglected. There are innumerable stupid comedies from the 60's as well as many other eras that have received at least a cursory DVD treatment. This one wasn't even released on VHS to my knowledge, despite the talents involved in the making (Arthur Hiller, Eli Wallach, Anne Jackson, Murray Shisgal (notable later for co-writing Tootsie), even Dustin Hoffman in his debut).

I was surprised and touched by this emotional movie which moved me very strange. I was confused, sad and happy in the same moment. I guess that too less people will pay attention to this movie. But I hope that at least a few will see it and get something out of it. The story of two friends, linked by their suffers of bodily disability, whom (as a team) beat the medical well-fare system and fight for their rights. This movie shows a side which some of us would never understand, not too exaggerated but emotional presented.

I would say 'Bride of Chucky' is a "return to greatness" but the series was never really great. Very good #1 was, #2-3 were throwaways, and I think this 4th installment is equal to or even better than the first movie. And it contains the best subtitle/tagline: "Chucky Gets Lucky." So he does, in the role of Jennifer Tilly, who thoroughly rejuvenated this series as Jeri Ryan did for 'Star Trek: Voyager.' Tilly didn't just create a presence; she added much needed humor, back-story, drama, tension and a great little sidekick/play-thing for Chucky.

James Franco is totally cool in this movie. Not just handsome and charismatic but genuinely open and vulnerable in a sincere kind of way. At the Tristan screening some folks were on his back for being pouty and sullen and doing the whole James Dean thing but I don't think this true. Blind Spot is proof positive of his tremendous talent. In this film he carries himself with a different sort of weight entirely. It's a unique performance. Bittersweet and really moving. The lines from his journal cut you like a knife. You sense a sharp intelligence of observation behind his words.

Ross Hunter 's musical remake of the 1937 fantasy , based on James Hilton 's enduring bestseller , was written by screenwriter John Patrick and features an all-star cast. The film takes place in the enchanted paradise of Shangri-La, hidden within the mystical mountains of the Himalayas. With captivating tunes composed by the illustrious team of Burt Bacharach and Hal David, the remake immerses audiences in the fascinating tale of a group of stranded survivors who stumble upon the idyllic utopia during a fateful plane crash. Within Shangri-La's blissful sanctum, the newcomers gradually uncover life-altering secrets that forever transform their perspectives on love, destiny, and the essence of true happiness.

SPOILERSI love the Simpsons , and I have seen every single episode that had ever come out . I must admit that throughout its incredible run of over 30 seasons, the show has consistently managed to capture the hearts and minds of fans around the world. The hilarious and often thought-provoking antics of the Simpson family and their colorful town of Springfield never fail to keep audiences engaged. From classic moments like Homer becoming an astronaut, to Mr. Burns' elaborate schemes, to Marge taking on pressing social issues, The Simpsons truly delivers a slice of modern life with a healthy dose of humor and wit.

I first saw "Signs of Life" on PBS as an American Playhouse presentation. It's a wonderfully written, ensemble production with terrific performances by Michael Lewis as Joey and Vincent D'Onofrio as his brother, Daryl. Arthur Kennedy, in one of his last roles, is also excellent as an aging shipbuilder whose family business is about to close. The rest of the cast which includes Beau Bridges, Kathy Bates and Mary-Louise Parker give remarkable clarity and substance to their characters.The direction is subtle and effective. I've watched this movie several times over the years and would very much recommend it.

I remember seeing this film when I was fairly young & being quite disturbed by it. I found the storyline very distressing and can still remember the various bullying techniques used. One in particular was when the other school children spat in his soup before he could even taste a spoonful. They also bound him and shaved his private parts. This was all because he was unpopular. Why was he unpopular? Because he was bad at games. I have a feeling though that even if he was good at games he would have been bullied because it's hard to decide what makes someone popular.

This film had about everything one could wish when viewing it originally, at the end of the 1960's decade. It was immensely entertaining, and provided a contemporary view of the many changes which had occurred during that period - and were still ongoing - in terms of the Black Power movement, Vietnam, and the volatile movement which followed the quieter, preceding postwar 1950's.All of this and one of the funniest films, then or now.Viewing it for the second time recently, I was surprised to find it as engrossing as when seen originally.

The film isn't perfect by any means but despite this it is very fun and amusing to watch. I am the first one to agree that Victor Fox isn't really that attractive and his music and style are pretty cheesy. I also agree that the film has some odd distractions and some scenes don't work well. So what? If it makes you smile and you enjoy it who cares? Does every film have to make sense? Does every film have to be perfect? No. A person could get razed admitting that they love this film. Again, so what?

Not sure why the other comment on this film was so negative , but I loved this movie . I felt it was thought-provoking, well-crafted, and visually stunning. The storyline managed to weave a meaningful and complex narrative without losing any engagement, truly showcasing the director's talent. Moreover, the performances of the lead actors were captivating and displayed a range of emotions that felt authentic and compelling. In terms of technical elements, the cinematography was top-notch and offered striking visuals which elevated the movie even more. It's rare to see a film like this these days, with so much passion and originality put into it.

"Caribe" is not a masterpiece in any of its storytelling aspects. However, it delivers a perfectly enjoyable story, along with a magnificent cinematography. The narrative structure is set around two narrative axes, one of them embedding the other, each one having elements that relate and co-exist in excellent harmony. The story never loses the right pacing, and it shows a very good blending of the human figure with its natural environment (which is a character in itself). The acting is great, and for that we owe credit to the emerging director, Esteban Ramírez.

What a surprise this film was. I've seen a good few of Fulci's horror and zombie flicks and was amazed that this was by the same director. He also wrote the screen play which shows that the chap was quite capable of crafting a detailed, complex story line. The dubbing on this is not good, but far from the appalling slop that only further hinders later howlers like 'Manhattan Baby'.The photography in this film is fantastic. A strange, almost futuristic highway appears throughout the film which focuses on a small town where young boys are being murdered.

I admit to being in awe of the Sea and have spent a number of years in the Navy , which only intensified my admiration for its incredible power and beauty. Its vastness is mesmerizing, a realm full of wonder and mystery that has captivated generations. Despite all the technological advancements we possess, the ocean still possesses a certain unpredictability that both humbles and challenges us. Many times, it's also provided an exhilarating sense of solitude and tranquility when nothing else could. Over the years, the experiences I had within the Navy have continually taught me new lessons in both life and in understanding the enigmatic allure of the Sea.

This film, like much of their music, is either underrated or unnoticed by the casual observer. It is terrific and, in many ways, ahead of its time.The images are funny, disturbing, and at the very least, engaging. The music is amazing. This is not the "candy pop" sound they are unfortunately associated with. This is the sound of a band in exploration and revolt.HEAD, alone, should put The Monkees into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Can anyone tell me why these guys are not in there?

by TyNesha Mells . In this drama , Ja Rule , who stars as Reggie , struggles with the loss of his beloved wife, Emma. Grief-stricken and emotionally broken, Reggie must also find the strength to navigate life as a single father to their three young children. Friends and family try to provide support, but often cause more stress than solace. Throughout this heart-wrenching journey, Reggie embarks on a soul-searching experience that uncovers family secrets, renews old friendships, and opens his heart to forgiveness and love. In a story of redemption and healing, Ja Rule beautifully portrays a character desperate to mend the pieces of his shattered life.

inspite of many movies dealing with great artists or a genius , chihaweseon pointed out the real dilemma in which these exceptional individuals often find themselves. While most films focus on their talent and achievements, Chihwaseon digs deeper into the internal conflict and complexities faced by these artistic minds. As we follow the life of Jang Seung-eop, a gifted 19th-century Korean painter, the film vividly portrays the challenging aspects of fame, ambition, and self-destruction. Often torn between societal expectations and their relentless pursuit of art, these geniuses can fall victim to immense pressure and their own obsessions.

It 's up there with Where 's Poppa , The Groove Tube , Putney Swope . It memorializes the NY of a bygone era – gritty, unpredictable, and brilliantly eccentric. As a cult classic, it remains cherished by an enthusiastic audience and loved by those seeking authentic depictions of urban culture. With a potent combination of wit and social commentary, it captivates viewers and transports them to a world of hustlers, dreamers, and unforgettable characters. This tribute to old-school New York irreverence lures newcomers to its charm and promises a memorable viewing experience that never gets old.

What a shame this movie was never released. (It is now playing on cable.) I tuned in based on my high regard for the stars and was rewarded by seeing a movie far better than the ones I've been paying to see in theatres recently. I like to be surprised. So often movies are marketed as "offbeat," but are in fact more of the same old recycled drivel. This movie is genuinely different, with the bonus of a heartwarming message. Jonathan Pryce sings like an angel.

This movie, based on a true story of Gerrit Wolfaardt, is one of the best films I've seen on race relations in South Africa; a very good history lesson of the turmoil of 80's South Africa. I put it in on the scale of American History X as far as it's depiction of how a young man can get seduced by the Aryan doctrine and how the "certain" segments of the Christian church taught a false doctrine regarding race to justify an injustice.It's strong message of forgiveness and redemption, is one of rarity in films today.

I was about 14 years old as I saw the musical version of Lost Horizon. I loved the film so much as well as the songs that I went several times to the cinema to see it again and again. My mother bought the LP and I learnt the songs off by heart, just as I did with "The sound of Music" (which people hardly know in Austria). I think the problem with some of these self-appointed critics who's comments get published is that they don't have a romantic soul and didn't see the film through the eyes of a young teenager.

I taped The Morrison Murders on Lifetime Movie network and I watched The Morrison Murders on Lifetime, Lifetime Movie network and on Courttv. Jonathan Scarfe and John Corbett did a great job of playing Luke and Walker Morrison. I am glad that Walker got his brother Luke to confess of murdering his parents and their brother Bobby. I enjoy watching True stories on Lifetime, Lifetime Movie network and on Courttv. The Morrison Murders is a good movie to watch. Next time The Morrison Murders is on Lifetime, Lifetime Movienetwork or Courttv I am going to watch The Morrrison Murders again because My favorite actor John Corbbett is in The Morrison Murders.

This was the greatest movie I have ever seen in my life, the action was great, and i was so scared, there was a lot of gore WHICH MADE It GREAT, i would see it 1,000 more times, and Paris Hilton, D*MN she fine in that movie. But anyway, i would recommend it to anybody, even kids(like me) Adults like it to. You would probably have nightmares at night though, but beside that, IT IS AWESOMe, I CANT STOP BRAGGING ABOUT IT.

The `` old dark house '' sub-genre that dominated the early talkies rarely fails to disappoint when we re-view the films today. Often filled with suspense, spine-tingling twists, and an array of memorable characters, these movies are still quite enchanting for fans of the genre. Drawing on familiar elements such as spooky mansions, ghastly secret passages, and eerie family curses, the "old dark house" films showcased impressive gothic set designs and moody atmospheres. Replete with ominous tension, surprise plot revelations, and an undertone of comic relief, these motion pictures remain beloved classics in the annals of cinematic history.

Better than it has any right to be, this movie died a quick and painful death at the American box office. At times sophomoric, at others, bitingly satirical and witty, Jekyll and Hyde is mostly just a near perfect reflection of the times, laden with drug and sexual humor, reminding one at one time or another of everything from the Woody Allen of "Everything You Always Wanted To know About Sex" to the Mel Brooks of "The Producers", Saturday Night Live to Monty Python, Carlin to Cheech and Chong.

Like a few people I know , I came in late on 'Stingers ' ; not until 2000 . Three years had already passed since its debut, yet the moment I started watching, I was immediately hooked. The thrilling storyline, featuring a group of undercover detectives working to unveil some of the most heinous crimes in the underbelly of society, kept me on the edge of my seat. Not only was the acting top-notch, but the character development and their interpersonal relationships felt organic and captivating. It's no wonder that 'Stingers' eventually became one of the longest-running Australian dramas.

"Back in the Day" is an interesting, but flawed effort. Ja Rule stars as Reggie Cooper, a honest but sad man trying to cope with the death of his father. He meets his old friend J-Bone (Ving Rhames) who tries to force Reggie into a life of crime. Reggie also falls in love with Alica (Tatyana Ali) who is the preacher's daughter. Now he has to choose: Love Or Crime.Ja Rule does a competent job as Reggie. At least he's trying to act. Ving Rhames is perfect as J-Bone.

This movie may be the best ever if you like watching movies and laughing and then subjecting your friends to watch those movies too. If you're anything like me, and you probably are, you'll be laughing for years to come at the jokes in this movie. One of the funniest parts is when Gus sharks some money off a guy with kids and then the guy takes those kids into the forest like Hansel and Gretel then he and his wife go home with them. The soup scene kitchen is rife with comic genius of buffoonery: "Inspection officer -- Here!"

I wasn't expecting a great deal from this film, so I was pleasantly surprised when I watched it and found it to be most noteworthy. It's noteworthiness is mainly due to the talent and appeal of it's star, John Garfield.Garfield plays Jack, a boxing star who is framed for murder.
